title: Pre-approval of courses
paragraphs: ImportantYou can only apply for pre-approval of courses at the same level as your own programme. E.g. if you are on a bachelor programme you can only apply for courses at bachelor level.If you want to take courses at another university in the future as a part of your degree at the IT University, you must apply for a pre-approval.
You can only apply for pre-approval of courses at the same level as your own programme. E.g. if you are on a bachelor programme you can only apply for courses at bachelor level.

Be aware that aside from applying for pre-approval from ITU, you also need to follow the guidelines for admission, if you are taking the courses at other Universities. Look for admission rules for guest students or exchange students on their website.
If your courses are to be part of an individual specialisation, remember you need to apply for an individual specialisation, and not just the pre-approval.
The deadline is every 1st of the month throughout the year (July not included)

How does it work?This means that all applications received up until (as an example) March 1 will be processed during March. The reply to the application will then follow around first of April (the standard processing time being 4 weeks.) Apply in good time?If you want to apply in good time, then aim at applying for Autumn courses already during Spring. And vice versa apply for Spring courses during the autumn semester leading up.For Individual specialisations be aware of thisKeep in mind that you will need to have the approval, to be able to register for a specific course the coming semester. Therefore apply in good time with regards to the registration periods. Find them here An approved specialisation does not guarantee you a spot on the course.
This means that all applications received up until (as an example) March 1 will be processed during March.
The reply to the application will then follow around first of April (the standard processing time being 4 weeks.)
If you want to apply in good time, then aim at applying for Autumn courses already during Spring.
And vice versa apply for Spring courses during the autumn semester leading up.
For Individual specialisations be aware of this
Keep in mind that you will need to have the approval, to be able to register for a specific course the coming semester.
Therefore apply in good time with regards to the registration periods. Find them here
An approved specialisation does not guarantee you a spot on the course.

How to apply Fill out the application form Make a provisional study plan Include the relevant documentation: Link to course descriptions including the number of credits awarded for the course Course title and course code (add an English course title to be used on your final ITU diploma). Conversion to ECTS (if the course is not in ECTS). Please add a link to document how the conversion is made. Link to where the level of the course is documented (BSc or MSc). Students on Master and Diploma (part time programmes) will also have to submit documentation that they have had two years of full-time work experience prior to following the course. This is NOT a requirement for BSc and MSc students.
You must enclose documentation as links (e.g. to a university’s course catalogue). Make sure that links are stable.
You do not need to send us ITU-Diplomas or course descriptions for ITU-courses. We only need documentation from other universities.
Send the application to Student Affairs and Programmes at sap@itu.dk.

The handling of your application begins after the deadline. It involves different tasks in order to secure the academic output for you, when taking courses outside of ITU. This involves evaluating and comparing the courses that are listed for pre-approval, to guarantee that it matches you programme.

Because different people are involved at different times, and because of the amount of applications we normally receive, the processing time is 4 weeks. We always work hard to have a reply for you as soon as possible.

Useful informationHow to convert credits to ECTS when studying abroadIf the course(s) you want to have pre-approved are not ECTS-based, you must document how many credits/points/units cover a full time semester at the foreign university. For example: University X requires 120 credits to obtain a bachelor degree. The bachelor degree takes 8 semesters to complete (4 years). Hence, 120 credits is divided by 8 semesters, which is equal to 15 credits pr. semester.After you have passed the pre-approved coursesThe pre-approval of courses is a preliminary approval. It is not the actual transfer of credits from another educational institution. You must submit documentation of passed and non-passed courses that have been pre-approved by the university. You should do this as soon as you receive a transcript of your records. Send the documentation along with the original pre-approval letter from Student Affairs and Programmes by email to sap@itu.dk. If you are not going to use your pre-approvalYou must notify the IT University if you are not using your pre-approval, as you must be registered for study activities at the IT University instead. If you forget to tell us, the pre-approval will block you from registering for other courses.
How to convert credits to ECTS when studying abroad
If the course(s) you want to have pre-approved are not ECTS-based, you must document how many credits/points/units cover a full time semester at the foreign university.
For example: University X requires 120 credits to obtain a bachelor degree. The bachelor degree takes 8 semesters to complete (4 years).
Hence, 120 credits is divided by 8 semesters, which is equal to 15 credits pr. semester.
After you have passed the pre-approved courses
The pre-approval of courses is a preliminary approval. It is not the actual transfer of credits from another educational institution.
You must submit documentation of passed and non-passed courses that have been pre-approved by the university. You should do this as soon as you receive a transcript of your records.
Send the documentation along with the original pre-approval letter from Student Affairs and Programmes by email to sap@itu.dk.
If you are not going to use your pre-approval

You must notify the IT University if you are not using your pre-approval, as you must be registered for study activities at the IT University instead. If you forget to tell us, the pre-approval will block you from registering for other courses.
If your application is rejected or only partly approved, you can file a complaint.
You must send the complaint within two weeks from the day you received the decision.
No matter who you are complaining to you send the complaint in an email to sap@itu.dk and we will direct it to the department responsible.

It can take up to 4 weeks processing your application. For more information about complaints concerning pre-approval of courses please check out these links: Overview of Credit Transfer appeals Appeals regarding pre-approval of credit transfer Meritankenævnsbekendtgørelsen University Programme Order
This page was last updated August, 2023

title: Working in Groups

headings.text: The benefits of working in a group
Getting off to a good start

paragraphs: Working in groups can be a great enrichment and has many advantages.
The academic results are often better because you will get the opportunity to discuss the subject matter from multiple perspectives and angles.

You can read more about groups and study technique in these books: 'Studieteknik - eller kunsten at studere', Thomas Harboe & Jakob Ravn 'Metode i projektarbejde - problemorientering og gruppearbejde', Helle Algreen-Ussing & Niels O. Fruensgaard
Group agreement and expectations
Collaboration agreement
Handling group conflicts
Clear agreement as a tool
If you cannot solve your conflict within your group, consider booking a session with a student advisor.
We offer group sessions where we frame a constructive dialogue to help you get through your problems.
full_text: Working in Groups Working in groups The benefits of working in a group Getting off to a good start Book a group session Working in groups can be a great enrichment and has many advantages. The academic results are often better because you will get the opportunity to discuss the subject matter from multiple perspectives and angles. You can read more about groups and study technique in these books: 'Studieteknik - eller kunsten at studere', Thomas Harboe & Jakob Ravn 'Metode i projektarbejde - problemorientering og gruppearbejde', Helle Algreen-Ussing & Niels O. Fruensgaard Group agreement and expectations Collaboration agreement Handling group conflicts Clear agreement as a tool If you cannot solve your conflict within your group, consider booking a session with a student advisor. We offer group sessions where we frame a constructive dialogue to help you get through your problems.

title: After you return
paragraphs: After you finish your exchange you must

You are responsible the final transfer of course credits to your ITU degree. You do this by emailing us a transcript of records for the courses you have completed. Please do this as soon as possible upon return from the host university.
Some universities may send the transcript directly to ITU, and if so, we will ask you to come by and get your original transcript.
All grades obtained abroad are transferred to your degree certificate as passed. However, you will get a separate certificate from your host university showing your results in their grade scale.

Upon your return, you are required to write a travel report about your experiences abroad. This will enable other students to make use of and be inspired by your experiences. Note that the travel report will be uploaded to ITUstudent so consider leaving out sensitive data. See a list of travel reports here.
Template for travel report.

Some universities may send the transcript directly to ITU, and if so, we will ask you to come by and get your original transcript. All grades obtained abroad are transferred to your degree certificate as passed. However, you will get a separate certificate from your host university showing your results in their grade scale. Upon your return, you are required to write a travel report about your experiences abroad. This will enable other students to make use of and be inspired by your experiences. Note that the travel report will be uploaded to ITUstudent so consider leaving out sensitive data. See a list of travel reports here. Template for travel report.

title: Theses

headings.text: How to write your thesis or project - Guidance

paragraphs: Qualify your re question
Working with your supervisor
Project management and writing process
The IT University of Copenhagen has a number of labs that you are free to use as a student.
Here you can do experiments, build prototypes, get help realising your projects and meet like-minded students and faculty.
It is possible to reserve a space in the Reading Room on the 1st. floor at Rued Langgaards Vej when writing your thesis. Follow the link below for instructions.
There are also other places in town, where you will be able to work on your thesis in great surroundings.

title: Exemption to apply for elective courses outside the course list

headings.text: Exemption to apply for elective courses outside the course list

paragraphs: Students with a very different academic background compared to the norm of their programme can sometimes feel a need to look at courses outside of the course list offered for their programme. This is possible but only in very specific cases.
These four conditions must be meet:

How to apply DeadlineEvery 1st of the month throughout the year (July not included) You apply for the exemption in the same way you would apply for a pre-approval for a course outside ITU. Find the application form here.*
Every 1st of the month throughout the year (July not included)
You need to attach these documents to your application:
Send it to sap@itu.dk *Since you are applying for ITU courses you do not need to attach or link to course descriptions from ITU.

How to register If your application is approved, you will have to register for the course(s) in the registration period. Here you will need to tell SAP to register you, since the course will not be available to register for in My Study Activities.
You send an email with the request during the registration period.
Be aware Even if you are granted the right to register for an elective course(s) outside the course list for your programme, you are not guaranteed a seat on the course(s).

These four conditions must be meet: How to apply DeadlineEvery 1st of the month throughout the year (July not included) You apply for the exemption in the same way you would apply for a pre-approval for a course outside ITU. Find the application form here.* Every 1st of the month throughout the year (July not included) You need to attach these documents to your application: Send it to sap@itu.dk *Since you are applying for ITU courses you do not need to attach or link to course descriptions from ITU. How to register If your application is approved, you will have to register for the course(s) in the registration period. Here you will need to tell SAP to register you, since the course will not be available to register for in My Study Activities. You send an email with the request during the registration period. Be aware Even if you are granted the right to register for an elective course(s) outside the course list for your programme, you are not guaranteed a seat on the course(s).

title: How to run
paragraphs: If you want to run for election you should fill out and register a candidate list. The Election Committee recommends the following procedure when filling in the form for registration of candidates:
Print out the candidate list for the election, you want to run for:
Form for registration of candidates to Board of Directors, Academic Board, PhD Board, Board of Studies and Subject Area Team for Games.
Form for registration of candidates to Subject Area Teams for Digital Design, Computer Science and Business.
See an example on a filled out candidate list
A. Fill in the name of the collegiate body, you wish to be elected for.
B. Choose a unique name for the list (“The Humanists”, “SITU-List” or the likes). If you do not choose a name for the list, the Election Committee will choose for you e.g. “List 1”.
C. Cross off “Prioritised” or “Without priority”:

Please note that candidates to Subject Area Teams for Business, Digital Communication and Computer Science shall be nominated without priority, so the calculation of elected candidates can be carried out based on the number of personal votes obtained.

If you have chosen to run prioritised, you should sign up in the order you wish to be elected. Make sure that you have as many candidates on your list as there are seats in the collegiate body you run for, and a corresponding number of alternate candidates.

There must be at least five names on the list – the sum of “candidates” and “nominator” has to be at least 5 (each candidate is also a nominator for the list). Make sure that everyone on your candidate list is listed in the electoral roll for the collegiate body you are running for.
Everyone on your candidate list (candidates and nominators) must add their full name and birth of date and sign the form

title: Legal right & How to apply to a MSc

headings.text: Legal right & How to apply to a MSc

paragraphs: Applying for other ITU MSc programmesYou can off course apply to the MSc programmes you find interesting, even if you do not have legal right. Then you just apply on the same terms as every other student without legal right.If you are currently on the last semester of your BSc programme and you want to start studying an MSc programme at ITU this autumn, you must apply before March 1 at 23:59
Applying for other ITU MSc programmes
Please make sure to familiarize yourself with the admission requirements for the different MSc programmes and be aware that even if you have legal right, you still need to apply.
For more information on the MSc programmes, the admission requirements and procedures please go to the ITU website: How to apply for a MSc (GB or DK).
Make sure to read the instructions on how to apply and what to document carefully. Follow this link to go to the application portal.
The legal right is a guaranteed place on a specific MSc programme. All BSc programmes will have one MSc programmes, where the legal right guarantees the student a place on the programme.
You can look up the MSc programmes you have legal right for in the Appendix to the curricula.

Important To make use of your legal right to be admitted to the MSc that is open for your type of BSc, you need to apply for a seat within 3 years from finishing your BSc studies. When using your legal right you do not have to document what is listed for the normal admission process, but you still need to apply. You only use your legal right if you accept the offer of a place You can read about this on ITU.dk as well, when you look up the admission requirements: How to apply (GB or DK)
You can read about this on ITU.dk as well, when you look up the admission requirements: How to apply (GB or DK)

title: Specialisations

headings.text: You register for the courses - not the specialisation

paragraphs: During the course of your programme, you have to choose and pass a specialisation. This gives you a more distinctive profile and it is an opportunity to point your academic profile in the direction you wish to go after graduation. You can choose one of the specialisations in the table below, or you can apply for an individual specialisation (see below). For how to register, go to Study Administration / Registration

During the course of your programme, you have to choose and pass a specialisation. This gives you a more distinctive profile and it is an opportunity to point your academic profile in the direction you wish to go after graduation.
You can choose one of the specialisations in the table below, or you can apply for an individual specialisation (see below).
For how to register, go to Study Administration / Registration
Each specialisation amounts to a total of 22.5 ECTS points, and consists of three specific modules:
Module 1 is a 7.5 ECTS course that you attend during the second semester. Modules 2 and 3 are 7.5 ECTS courses that you attend during the third semester.
Click the title for a description of the specialisation
You register for the courses - not the specialisationYou cannot register for a specialisation. Instead, you must sign up for and pass the courses on the specialisation.
You cannot register for a specialisation. Instead, you must sign up for and pass the courses on the specialisation.
If the specialisation options do not meet your specific demands or ambitions, you can apply for an individual specialisation.

Before applying please do consult a lecturer/supervisor within the relevant academic area to get an indication of whether your plan for the individual specialisation looks reasonable. Please follow this link for information on how to apply.

An individual specialisation must meet the same official requirements as the predetermined specialisation. As the specialisation normally leads to the thesis, you need to ensure a progression within the individual specialisation. A specialisation is in total 22.5 ECTS.

title: Thesis

headings.text: When can you start your thesis?

paragraphs: The thesis is a 30 ECTS project, which must conclude your MSc programme. It is an independent project, which should show that you are able to work with a topic of your own choosing at a high academic level. The thesis is concluded with an oral defense. When can you start your thesis? Normally, you write your thesis in your 4th semester, as you can see in the study programme. In certain cases - e.g. if you have not been able to pass 30 ECTS each semester - you might have to consider writing the project in another semester. However, as a minimum you need to have passed 60 ECTS when writing your thesis. More detailed information For specific information about the thesis (registration, deadlines, supervisor etc.) go to Study Administration / Project work / Thesis.

title: Courses, electives and projects
paragraphs: Each programme consists of modules and study activities. Study activities are specific courses and projects that can fill out a module, and in order to fulfill the requirements in your curriculum, you must fill out all modules. The study activities that are available can change each semester, but the modules are always available. Some courses are mandatory, some you chose as electives and for some electives you can decide to convert the ECTS into an elective project. Mandatory Courses Some modules are filled with mandatory courses. Mandatory courses are courses that you have to take at specific points in a specific order during the course of your studies. The courses are often divided into lectures or class teaching and following exercises. 1st semester students are administratively registered for their mandatory courses on their first semester, but from there on students need to register for their mandatory courses in the registration periods. Electives Some modules are reserved for electives. Electives are courses that you decide on yourself but you must choose electives that are within the objectives of your programme. You can use an elective to steer your studies towards your individual interests, to inspire you for future projects or to supplement future specialisations. Special academic prerequisites?For some students their educational background might qualify them for courses outside the course list. Please read more here Courses to choose from You choose from the course list in LearnIT. The courses are all approved as electives for your programme . The courses are considered to be within the curricula of your programme and they are chosen from the perspective that the majority of students on the programme will have the basic qualifications to succeed on the course. Always check the pre-requisites However, it is always important to check the prerequisites and course descriptions for courses approved and offered. Some courses belong to a different study programme and they can require specific knowledge you might not have. In order to follow a course and sit for the exam, you must register for the course in the registration period.

Always check the pre-requisites However, it is always important to check the prerequisites and course descriptions for courses approved and offered. Some courses belong to a different study programme and they can require specific knowledge you might not have.
In order to follow a course and sit for the exam, you must register for the course in the registration period.
See the courses that have been approved as electives for GAMES Design Track here.
See the courses that have been approved as electives for GAMES Design Track here.

Study Abroad?You could also consider studying abroad. Please have a look at the Study Abroad section. You can also apply for pre-approval of a course at another university in Denmark. For more information on this, please go to Pre-approval of Courses. Useful information concerning coursesThe Course CatalogueYou can find descriptions of the current courses in the course catalogue in LearnIT / All courses. From October/April, you will be able to see a list of course titles for the coming semester. Full descriptions of the courses are available in November/May[date may be changed].Semester length and LearnITTeaching runs from Monday in week 5 and 35. Each course is taught for 14 weeks, though the course periods run for either 15 or 16 weeks, depending on bank holidays. The details for each course are available through LearnIT one week before the semester starts at the latest. You must be registered for a course in order to access it.Mandatory activitiesCourses may have mandatory activities that you need to pass in order to sit for the exam. Descriptions of the mandatory activities are available in the course base.Course evaluationsEach semester, you evaluate all your courses. You have ample possibility of sharing your opinion in the three-step course evaluation during each course. ECTS and workloadOne ECTS corresponds to 27.5 hours of work for the students which is in line with the official Bologna process A 7.5 ECTS course therefore represents around 206 hours of activity in total. It is difficult to be more specific when speaking about all courses, but it serves as a basis for calculation. Assuming it will take 40 hours to prepare for exam in a 14 week course, this leaves an average of 11.8 work hours per week in those 14 weeks. Projects Project work is an important part of the MSc programme. It offers the opportunity to delve deeper into specific areas that interest you or your project group. Project work also allows for a more in-depth engagement with case organisations. There are different kinds of projects on a MSc programme: Thesis (30 ECTS). Learn more about the Thesis Individual projects / Elective projects (7,5 or 15 ECTS). Summer Projects (7,5 or 15 ECTS). Projects as part of a course You can use elective modules for writing a project under supervision, rather than taking an elective. You register for the project in the registration period. You can chose to work on your own project entirely, collaborate with a company or do a group project.

Study Abroad?You could also consider studying abroad. Please have a look at the Study Abroad section. You can also apply for pre-approval of a course at another university in Denmark. For more information on this, please go to Pre-approval of Courses.

title: Course evaluation

headings.text: What happens after the course evaluation?

paragraphs: Evaluation reportsEach semester, a course evaluation report is made with scores by course and study programme. Reports are published in week 51 (Autumn courses) and 21 (Spring Courses). Find the Course evaluation reports. Your feedback is key to quality assurance and development of courses. Participating in course evaluations is your chance to influence aspects of courses that matter to you. Teachers go carefully through your feedback and use it to adjust courses. Future students attending the course benefit from your feedback - just like you benefit from previous evaluations. The impact of your participation in evaluations reaches far beyond the current semester.
Each semester, a course evaluation report is made with scores by course and study programme. Reports are published in week 51 (Autumn courses) and 21 (Spring Courses).
Find the Course evaluation reports.
The course evaluation process looks like this:

During the first half of a course, teachers invite you and your fellow students to participate in a formative evaluation in class. This is your time to make yourself heard and share your good ideas and suggestions on how to make the course even better. When your share your opinion, the teachers have the possibility to adjust the course while it runs, to help your learning.
Please note that not everything is up for change. This goes for the intended learning objectives and the exam format for example. The teachers have the last word in deciding what to adjust.
The online course evaluation survey contains four questions and a comment box:
Please state your agreement with the following statements from 1 (strongly disagree) to 6 (strongly agree).
Comment box: Please give feedback on the course and your learning experience. Thank you for keeping a civil tone.
Students are anonymous when participating in the online survey. You are not anonymous when participating in the Mutual Alignment of Expectations or a qualitative end-evaluation in class.

Once you have participated in the course evaluation, the follow-up process begins. In the illustration below, you can see how your input becomes part of quality assuring and developing courses at ITU.

Future students attending the course benefit from your feedback - just like you benefit from previous evaluations. The impact of your participation in evaluations reaches far beyond the current semester. Each semester, a course evaluation report is made with scores by course and study programme. title: Courses outside ITU

headings.text: Courses at other universities in Denmark
Courses passed before enrolling at ITU

paragraphs: You can take courses outside ITU as part of you programme. Courses at other universities in Denmark If you want to do courses at other universities in Denmark, you need to have the courses pre-approved. Be aware that besides applying for pre-approval from ITU you also need to follow the guidelines for admission at the University where you want to take your electives. Look for admission rules for guest students on their website. Courses passed before enrolling at ITUIf you have passed courses that are relevant for your studies at ITU before you enrolled at ITU, you can apply for a Credit Transfer. Studying abroad If you want to take courses at Universities outside Denmark, you can apply to go on Exchange. This involves getting a pre-approval well. Read about how to Study Abroad.

title: Illness at exams
paragraphs: ImportantIf you attend and complete your exam, your exam attempt cannot be cancelled based on illness. If you have fallen ill during your exam and cannot complete it, follow the instructions on this page.

If you fall ill during an exam, you can send a notification of illness and request to not use an exam attempt. You must be able to document your illness. If your notification of illness is approved, you will not use an exam attempt. Please note that there is no guarantee that your request will be approved, and that your exam attempt will be cancelled. We will process your request based on an assessment of your specific situation and medical documentation.

It is not a requirement that you send a notification of illness if you fall ill during an exam. You always have three exam attempts to pass an exam. There are slightly different requirements when reporting ill. In every scenario you will need to document your illness.

Illness and group examsWhen it comes to group exams please se this page about illness and group exams where we have outlined different scenarious and what to do. Ill before the examIf you are ill during the semester and cannot prepare for or participate in the exam, you must apply for an exemption to be deregistered from the exam. You must apply before the exam starts, and it is a requirement that you submit documentation of your illness. You can read more about exemptions and how to apply to be deregistered from an exam here. Ill on the day of the examIf you fall ill on the day of the exam before the exam starts, or before the submission deadline for a written exam expires, you can send a notification of illness and request to have the exam attempt cancelled. We can only cancel your exam attempt if you submit documentation of your illness. We recommend that you  your doctor as soon as possible to secure the required documentation. If your notification of illness is approved, you will not use an exam attempt. Use this form to send a notification of illness.Ill during a written exam on premisesIf you fall ill during a written exam on premises, you must notify the exam invigilator that you wish to leave the exam due to illness. You must then send in a notification of illness and request to have the exam attempt cancelled. We can only cancel your exam attempt if you submit documentation that you were ill on the day of the exam. We recommend that you  your doctor as soon as possible to secure the required documentation. If your notification of illness is approved, you will not use an exam attempt. Please note that you cannot have your exam attempt cancelled based on illness if you have submitted something for assessment. Use this form to send a notification of illness.Ill during an oral examIf you fall ill during an oral exam, you must notify the examiners that you wish to interrupt the exam due to illness. You must then send in a notification of illness and request to have the exam attempt cancelled. We can only cancel your exam attempt if you submit documentation of your illness. We recommend that you  your doctor as soon as possible to secure the required documentation. If your notification of illness is approved, you will not use an exam attempt. Use this form to send a notification of illness.Ill during a take-home examIf you fall ill during a take-home exam, you can send a notification of illness and request to have the exam attempt cancelled. We can only cancel your exam attempt if you submit documentation of illness during the period of the take-home exam. We recommend that you  your doctor as soon as possible to secure the required documentation. If your notification of illness is approved, you will not use an exam attempt. Please note that you cannot have your exam attempt cancelled based on illness if you have submitted something for assessment. Use this form to send a notification of illness.
Illness and group exams
If you are ill during the semester and cannot prepare for or participate in the exam, you must apply for an exemption to be deregistered from the exam.
You must apply before the exam starts, and it is a requirement that you submit documentation of your illness.
You can read more about exemptions and how to apply to be deregistered from an exam here.
Ill on the day of the exam

If you fall ill on the day of the exam before the exam starts, or before the submission deadline for a written exam expires, you can send a notification of illness and request to have the exam attempt cancelled. We can only cancel your exam attempt if you submit documentation of your illness. We recommend that you  your doctor as soon as possible to secure the required documentation. If your notification of illness is approved, you will not use an exam attempt.
Use this form to send a notification of illness.
Ill during a written exam on premises
Use this form to send a notification of illness.
Ill during an oral exam
Ill during a take-home exam
Re-submit?Be aware if you need to re-submit your course exam assignment Go to course re-exams.
Be aware if you need to re-submit your course exam assignment Go to course re-exams.

It is your own responsibility to procure and pay for the medical certificate documenting your illness. You must  your doctor as soon as possible to be able to document that you were ill during the exam. For more information about the documentation requirements for the medical certificate see here.
Register for re-examsDifferent rules apply when registering for re-exams for courses and projects and you can read about it here. Special rules also apply to the thesis. Please follow this link.
Different rules apply when registering for re-exams for courses and projects and you can read about it here.
Special rules also apply to the thesis. Please follow this link.
This page was last updated October 30 2025

title: Diversity and Inclusion
paragraphs: If you experience or observe offensive, discriminatory, sexist, or other behaviour that makes you feel unsafe or uncomfortable while being a student at ITU we are here to help you.
We have broken down the possible procedure into 1-2-3-4 steps, so you can deal with your experience in a manageable way, feeling supported and safe.

title: Specialisations

headings.text: You register for the courses - not the specialisation
INDIVIDUAL SPECIALISATION IF YOU GO ON STUDY EXCHANGE ABROAD

paragraphs: During the course of your programme, you have to choose and pass a specialisation. This gives you a more distinctive profile and it is an opportunity to point your academic profile in the direction you wish to go after graduation. You can choose one of the specialisations in the table below. For how to register, go to Study Administration / Registration.

During the course of your programme, you have to choose and pass a specialisation. This gives you a more distinctive profile and it is an opportunity to point your academic profile in the direction you wish to go after graduation.
You can choose one of the specialisations in the table below.
For how to register, go to Study Administration / Registration.
Each specialisation amounts to a total of 22.5 ECTS points, and consists of two specific modules:
Module 1 is a 7.5 ECTS course that you attend during the second semester. Module 2 is a 15 ECTS course that you attend during the third semester.
* The course was offered for the last time Autumn 2024. The replacement courses to register for instead is: Readings in Data Systems & How to build Data Systems.
* The course was offered for the last time Autumn 2024. The replacement courses to register for instead is: Language-Based Security & Data-Driven Security
Please notice: The specialisation in Security is not recommended for students with no knowledge of basic principles of computer security (eg. acquired from Security1)

* The course was offered for the last time Autumn 2024. The replacement courses to register for instead is: Advanced Machine Learning for Natural Language Processing & Advanced Machine Learing for Computer Vision
Please notice: The specialisation in Machine Learning is not recommended for students with a background in data science
* The course was offered for the last time Autumn 2024. The replacement courses to register for instead is: AI Robotics & Advanced Topics in Robotics
* The course was offered for the last time Autumn 2024. The replacement courses to register for instead is: Advanced Programming with Types & Practical Software Analysis

You register for the courses - not the specialisationYou cannot register for a specialisation. Instead, you must sign up for and pass the courses on the specialisation. A course registration for the 1st part of the specialisation is a prerequisite for signing up for the 2nd part in the following semester.

You cannot register for a specialisation. Instead, you must sign up for and pass the courses on the specialisation. A course registration for the 1st part of the specialisation is a prerequisite for signing up for the 2nd part in the following semester.

If you go on study exchange abroad, you may experience difficulties in getting courses that match the courses on the predetermined specialisations. If this happens, you can apply for an individual specialisation.

An individual specialisation must meet the same official requirements as the predetermined specialisation. As the specialisation normally leads to the thesis, you need to ensure a progression within the individual specialisation. A specialisation is in total 22.5 ECTS. For more information and how to apply
Please note: At the MSc CS program this option of designing an individual specialisation only applies to students going on study exchange abroad.

title: Exam Complaints

headings.text: What are the possible outcomes of a complaint?

paragraphs: Exam complaints do not include teaching, supervision, or other factors that are not part of the actual exam.
If you wish to complain about these matters, you should submit a separate complaint. Read more about complaining about teaching or supervision.
Examination complaints can be about the following issues:
If we decide in favour of you, we can either offer a new assessment of the exam that you have done or we can offer you a new examination.
If the exam was an oral exam, we will always offer you a new examination.

Read more about what happens after you have complained. How to applyIf you do not agree with the assessment at an exam, we recommend that you start by ing your examiner and discuss the reasons for your grade or assessment before making an official complaint. Many students understand the assessment better once they have spoken with the examiner. However, you do not have a statutory right to a statement from your examiner. Please note, that you need to file your complaint within the deadline (see below) no matter whether you have received feedback from the examiner or not. If you still wish to file an official complaint, you should use this form and structure your complaint as follows: Begin by specifying what you wish to achieve through the complaint. Substantiate your complaint - it may be a good idea to describe how your exam answer met the requirements stated in the goal description for the course or project. If the course language is English, the complaint must be written in English. If the course language is Danish, you can write your complaint in either Danish or English. Send it to sap@itu.dk.
If you do not agree with the assessment at an exam, we recommend that you start by ing your examiner and discuss the reasons for your grade or assessment before making an official complaint.
Many students understand the assessment better once they have spoken with the examiner. However, you do not have a statutory right to a statement from your examiner.
If you still wish to file an official complaint, you should use this form and structure your complaint as follows:
If the course language is English, the complaint must be written in English. If the course language is Danish, you can write your complaint in either Danish or English. Send it to sap@itu.dk.

The deadline is two weeks after the grade is announced. This applies even if you have ed your examiner and are awaiting an eventual reply. You need to file your complaint within the deadline even if you haven't heard from your examiner.
Read about when grades are announced.

title: Courses, electives and projects
paragraphs: Each programme consists of modules and study activities. Study activities are specific courses and projects that can fill out a module, and in order to fulfill the requirements in your curriculum, you must fill out all modules. The study activities that are available can change each semester, but the modules are always available. Some courses are mandatory, some you chose as electives and for some electives you can decide to convert the ECTS into an elective project. Mandatory Courses Some modules are filled with mandatory courses. Mandatory courses are courses that you have to take at specific points in a specific order during the course of your studies. The courses are often divided into lectures or class teaching and following exercises. 1st semester students are administratively registered for their mandatory courses on their first semester, but from there on students need to register for their mandatory courses in the registration periods. Electives Some modules are reserved for electives. Electives are courses that you decide on yourself but you must choose electives that are within the objectives of your programme. You can use an elective to steer your studies towards your individual interests, to inspire you for future projects or to supplement future specialisations. Special academic prerequisites?For some students their educational background might qualify them for courses outside the course list. Please read more here Courses to choose from You choose from the course list in LearnIT. The courses are all approved as electives for your programme . The courses are considered to be within the curricula of your programme and they are chosen from the perspective that the majority of students on the programme will have the basic qualifications to succeed on the course. Always check the pre-requisites However, it is always important to check the prerequisites and course descriptions for courses approved and offered. Some courses belong to a different study programme and they can require specific knowledge you might not have. In order to follow a course and sit for the exam, you must register for the course in the registration period.

The course list See the courses that have been approved as electives for SWU students here. Be aware that if you are on an older curricula, some courses might not be approved for you.
The course list See the courses that have been approved as electives for SWU students here.

Study Abroad?You could also consider studying abroad. Please have a look at the Study Abroad section. You can also apply for pre-approval of a course at another university in Denmark. For more information on this, please go to Pre-approval of Courses. Useful information concerning coursesThe Course CatalogueYou can find descriptions of the current courses in the course catalogue in LearnIT / All courses. From October/April, you will be able to see a list of course titles for the coming semester. Full descriptions of the courses are available in November/May[date may be changed].Semester length and LearnITTeaching runs from Monday in week 5 and 35. Each course is taught for 14 weeks, though the course periods run for either 15 or 16 weeks, depending on bank holidays. The details for each course are available through LearnIT one week before the semester starts at the latest. You must be registered for a course in order to access it. Mandatory activitiesCourses may have mandatory activities that you need to pass in order to sit for the exam. Descriptions of the mandatory activities are available in the course base.Course evaluationsEach semester, you evaluate all your courses. You have ample possibility of sharing your opinion in the three-step course evaluation during each course. ECTS and workloadOne ECTS corresponds to 27.5 hours of work for the students which is in line with the official Bologna process A 7.5 ECTS course therefore represents around 206 hours of activity in total. It is difficult to be more specific when speaking about all courses, but it serves as a basis for calculation. Assuming it will take 40 hours to prepare for exam in a 14 week course, this leaves an average of 11.8 work hours per week in those 14 weeks. Projects Project work is an important part of the BSc programme. It offers the opportunity to delve deeper into specific areas that interest you or your project group. Project work also allows for a more in-depth engagement with case organisations. There are different kinds of projects on a BSc programme: Bachelor project (15 ECTS). Learn more about the Bachelor project Individual projects / Elective projects (7,5 or 15 ECTS). Summer Projects (7,5 or 15 ECTS) Projects as part of a course You can use elective modules for writing a project under supervision, rather than taking an elective. You register for the project in the registration period. You can chose to work on your own project entirely, collaborate with a company or do a group project.

links.text: the three-step course evaluation during each course.

full_text: Courses, electives and projects Courses, electives and projects Mandatory Courses Electives Projects Each programme consists of modules and study activities. Study activities are specific courses and projects that can fill out a module, and in order to fulfill the requirements in your curriculum, you must fill out all modules. The study activities that are available can change each semester, but the modules are always available. Some courses are mandatory, some you chose as electives and for some electives you can decide to convert the ECTS into an elective project. Mandatory Courses Some modules are filled with mandatory courses. Mandatory courses are courses that you have to take at specific points in a specific order during the course of your studies. The courses are often divided into lectures or class teaching and following exercises. 1st semester students are administratively registered for their mandatory courses on their first semester, but from there on students need to register for their mandatory courses in the registration periods. Electives Some modules are reserved for electives. Electives are courses that you decide on yourself but you must choose electives that are within the objectives of your programme. You can use an elective to steer your studies towards your individual interests, to inspire you for future projects or to supplement future specialisations. Special academic prerequisites?For some students their educational background might qualify them for courses outside the course list. Please read more here Courses to choose from You choose from the course list in LearnIT. The courses are all approved as electives for your programme . The courses are considered to be within the curricula of your programme and they are chosen from the perspective that the majority of students on the programme will have the basic qualifications to succeed on the course. Always check the pre-requisites However, it is always important to check the prerequisites and course descriptions for courses approved and offered. Some courses belong to a different study programme and they can require specific knowledge you might not have. In order to follow a course and sit for the exam, you must register for the course in the registration period. Each programme consists of modules and study activities. title: Notes
paragraphs: Taking notes can be a useful way to help you remember the things you have learned. When you are writing notes, you are already processing the information in new ways. You can take notes for different purpose during your studies.

If you become aware of the different ways to take notes and you find the methods that matches your ways of studying – then you can save a lot of time and at the same time remember a larger part of what you read.
As a eyeopener we have tried to list some of the different ways, that you can try to incorporate notetaking and processing of your knowledge in the different parts your everyday studylife.

When you read a text, it can be helpful to take notes to help highlight the important sections in the text. You can do this by highlighting words or sentences, or by writing notes in the margins. No matter how you do it, you should not overdo it - less is more. If you create too many highlights, it will be difficult to return to the text later on and easily access the information you are looking for. A god method could be to write notes in the margin for every 2-4 pages – this way you don’t risk taking to many notes and by doing this you will also have a processed more of the text before writing in the margin. You can also help your own studying and notetaking by “making your own questions for the text”. By during this you can help your notetaking, because you then only need to write down aspect that are important in relation to this question. A way of during this is to ask questions based on the different headlines: What is X / How does X relate to Y – or doing it based on the outline in your curriculum.
When you read a text, it can be helpful to take notes to help highlight the important sections in the text. You can do this by highlighting words or sentences, or by writing notes in the margins.

No matter how you do it, you should not overdo it - less is more. If you create too many highlights, it will be difficult to return to the text later on and easily access the information you are looking for.

A god method could be to write notes in the margin for every 2-4 pages – this way you don’t risk taking to many notes and by doing this you will also have a processed more of the text before writing in the margin.

You can also help your own studying and notetaking by “making your own questions for the text”. By during this you can help your notetaking, because you then only need to write down aspect that are important in relation to this question. A way of during this is to ask questions based on the different headlines: What is X / How does X relate to Y – or doing it based on the outline in your curriculum.

During a lecture, notes can help you focus and process the new knowledge you have acquired from your lecturer. You should not write everything the lecturer says - only the most important aspects. Writing too much down can make you lose focus. It is important to remember that you are writing the notes to yourself. It is not a matter of how perfectly they are formulated or how well-written, but rather how they allow you to revisit the content of the lecture later. Therefore, it can be helpful to use abbreviations and illustrations in your notes. You can also use your notes from the lectures to test your understanding of the given text. Maybe your notes from the lecture indicates, that you should read the text again, because your understanding of the text differ from your lecturer/class discussion. Hereby you can use your notetaking as an active tool for studying. It is also important to dare trying new ways of taking notes – is it most beneficial for you to take notes on your PC or taking handwritten notes?

During a lecture, notes can help you focus and process the new knowledge you have acquired from your lecturer. You should not write everything the lecturer says - only the most important aspects. Writing too much down can make you lose focus. It is important to remember that you are writing the notes to yourself.

It is not a matter of how perfectly they are formulated or how well-written, but rather how they allow you to revisit the content of the lecture later. Therefore, it can be helpful to use abbreviations and illustrations in your notes.

You can also use your notes from the lectures to test your understanding of the given text. Maybe your notes from the lecture indicates, that you should read the text again, because your understanding of the text differ from your lecturer/class discussion. Hereby you can use your notetaking as an active tool for studying.
It is also important to dare trying new ways of taking notes – is it most beneficial for you to take notes on your PC or taking handwritten notes?

When you are preparing for an exam, notes can help you get an overview of theories and literature, just as it will help you keep focus on the most important parts of the syllabus. It will help you structure the knowledge you have. Making a Mind Map could help you to get a better insight into your own knowledge – are you lacking some knowledge when you look at your mind map and should therefore study some more within certain parts of your curriculum? This way you can also get an insight into your own knowledge - are lacking some knowledge when you look at your mind map and should therefore study some more within certain parts of your curriculum? It is correct, “good” notes are important when preparing for an exam – but you shouldn’t forget, that what you are tested in at an exam is tested on your ability to communicate and present your knowledge. It could be a good idea not just to perceive your “notes” as tool to remembering, but also as a way of preparing your argumentation – so try reading your notes out loud or rewrite them, as a way of processing the information.

When you are preparing for an exam, notes can help you get an overview of theories and literature, just as it will help you keep focus on the most important parts of the syllabus. It will help you structure the knowledge you have.

Making a Mind Map could help you to get a better insight into your own knowledge – are you lacking some knowledge when you look at your mind map and should therefore study some more within certain parts of your curriculum?
This way you can also get an insight into your own knowledge - are lacking some knowledge when you look at your mind map and should therefore study some more within certain parts of your curriculum?

It is correct, “good” notes are important when preparing for an exam – but you shouldn’t forget, that what you are tested in at an exam is tested on your ability to communicate and present your knowledge. It could be a good idea not just to perceive your “notes” as tool to remembering, but also as a way of preparing your argumentation – so try reading your notes out loud or rewrite them, as a way of processing the information.

Taking notes during group work is a way to document your work process. This way, you can always come back and see what you have previously decided in your group. Taking notes in groups can serve as a way to always be on the same page and avoid misunderstandings and conflicts. You can take turns being the note-taker.
Taking notes during group work is a way to document your work process. This way, you can always come back and see what you have previously decided in your group.
Taking notes in groups can serve as a way to always be on the same page and avoid misunderstandings and conflicts. You can take turns being the note-taker.
Try to make a Mind Map over you knowledge - this exercise can help you to structure your knowledge and help you with "blindspots".
Processing your notes
It is important that you work actively with your notes, so you better can remember them and hereby can help your own exam preparation.

title: Courses outside ITU

headings.text: Courses at other universities in Denmark
Courses passed before enrolling at ITU

paragraphs: You can take courses outside ITU as part of you programme. Courses at other universities in Denmark If you want to do courses at other universities in Denmark, you need to have the courses pre-approved. Be aware that besides applying for pre-approval from ITU you also need to follow the guidelines for admission at the University where you want to take your electives. Look for admission rules for guest students on their website. Courses passed before enrolling at ITUIf you have passed courses that are relevant for your studies at ITU before you enrolled at ITU, you can apply for a Credit Transfer. Studying abroad If you want to take courses at Universities outside Denmark, you can apply to go on Exchange. This involves getting a pre-approval well. Read about how to Study Abroad.

title: Thesis

headings.text: When can you start your thesis?

paragraphs: The thesis is a 30 ECTS project, which must conclude your MSc programme. It is an independent project, which should show that you are able to work with a topic of your own choosing at a high academic level. The thesis is concluded with an oral defense. When can you start your thesis? Normally, you write your thesis in your 4th semester, as you can see in the study programme. In certain cases - e.g. if you have not been able to pass 30 ECTS each semester - you might have to consider writing the project in another semester. However, as a minimum you need to have passed 60 ECTS when writing your thesis. More detailed information For specific information about the thesis (registration, deadlines, supervisor etc.) go to Study Administration / Project work / Thesis.

title: Courses, electives and projects
paragraphs: Each programme consists of modules and study activities. Study activities are specific courses and projects that can fill out a module, and in order to fulfill the requirements in your curriculum, you must fill out all modules. The study activities that are available can change each semester, but the modules are always available. Some courses are mandatory, some you chose as electives and for some electives you can decide to convert the ECTS into an elective project. Mandatory Courses Some modules are filled with mandatory courses. Mandatory courses are courses that you have to take at specific points in a specific order during the course of your studies. The courses are often divided into lectures or class teaching and following exercises. 1st semester students are administratively registered for their mandatory courses on their first semester, but from there on students need to register for their mandatory courses in the registration periods. Electives Some modules are reserved for electives. Electives are courses that you decide on yourself but you must choose electives that are within the objectives of your programme. You can use an elective to steer your studies towards your individual interests, to inspire you for future projects or to supplement future specialisations. Special academic prerequisites?For some students their educational background might qualify them for courses outside the course list. Please read more here Courses to choose from You choose from the course list in LearnIT. The courses are all approved as electives for your programme . The courses are considered to be within the curricula of your programme and they are chosen from the perspective that the majority of students on the programme will have the basic qualifications to succeed on the course. Always check the pre-requisites However, it is always important to check the prerequisites and course descriptions for courses approved and offered. Some courses belong to a different study programme and they can require specific knowledge you might not have. In order to follow a course and sit for the exam, you must register for the course in the registration period.

Please read more here

Courses to choose from You choose from the course list in LearnIT. The courses are all approved as electives for your programme . The courses are considered to be within the curricula of your programme and they are chosen from the perspective that the majority of students on the programme will have the basic qualifications to succeed on the course.

Always check the pre-requisites However, it is always important to check the prerequisites and course descriptions for courses approved and offered. Some courses belong to a different study programme and they can require specific knowledge you might not have.
In order to follow a course and sit for the exam, you must register for the course in the registration period.
See the courses that have been approved as electives for SD students here. Be aware that if you are on an older curricula, some courses might not be approved for you.

Be aware that if you are on an older curricula, some courses might not be approved for you.

Study Abroad?You could also consider studying abroad. Please have a look at the Study Abroad section. You can also apply for pre-approval of a course at another university in Denmark. For more information on this, please go to Pre-approval of Courses. Useful information concerning coursesThe Course CatalogueYou can find descriptions of the current courses in the course catalogue in LearnIT / All courses. From October/April, you will be able to see a list of course titles for the coming semester. Full descriptions of the courses are available in November/May[date may be changed].Semester length and LearnITTeaching runs from Monday in week 5 and 35. Each course is taught for 14 weeks, though the course periods run for either 15 or 16 weeks, depending on bank holidays. The details for each course are available through LearnIT one week before the semester starts at the latest. You must be registered for a course in order to access it.Mandatory activitiesCourses may have mandatory activities that you need to pass in order to sit for the exam. Descriptions of the mandatory activities are available in the course base.Course evaluationsEach semester, you evaluate all your courses. You have ample possibility of sharing your opinion in the three-step course evaluation during each course. ECTS and workloadOne ECTS corresponds to 27.5 hours of work for the students which is in line with the official Bologna process A 7.5 ECTS course therefore represents around 206 hours of activity in total. It is difficult to be more specific when speaking about all courses, but it serves as a basis for calculation. Assuming it will take 40 hours to prepare for exam in a 14 week course, this leaves an average of 11.8 work hours per week in those 14 weeks. Projects Project work is an important part of the MSc programme. It offers the opportunity to delve deeper into specific areas that interest you or your project group. Project work also allows for a more in-depth engagement with case organisations. There are different kinds of projects on a MSc programme: Thesis (30 ECTS). Learn more about the Thesis Re project (7,5 ECTS) Individual projects / Elective projects (7,5 or 15 ECTS). Summer Projects. (7,5 or 15 ECTS) Projects as part of a course You can use elective modules for writing a project under supervision, rather than taking an elective. You register for the project in the registration period. You can chose to work on your own project entirely, collaborate with a company or do a group project. Re Project The re project is intended as the bridge between your specialisation and your thesis. It allows you to focus very narrowly and in great detail on the particular sub-topics of your specialisation that will then be used in your thesis. The re project is formally a project like any other, however, we do offer some help and guidelines for finding a supervisor. The content of the project is not limited, but is intended to feed into your thesis. The re project very often takes the form of a narrowly focused literature study or a prototype implementation or use of particular software tools. See here for more information about the Re Project Specially for KCS- and KSD-students studying abroad If you are going abroad in the semester just before writing your thesis, you can take an elective abroad instead of writing the Re Project – preapproval for the elective is still necessary. Additionally, you are recommended to attend the Re Project Introduction meeting at ITU in week 35. The introduction meeting will is informative with regards to the Master thesis as well. If this is not possible then check up on the general information about the Re project, since it also shares details about the thesis. (See link just above)

Project work is an important part of the MSc programme. It offers the opportunity to delve deeper into specific areas that interest you or your project group. Project work also allows for a more in-depth engagement with case organisations.
There are different kinds of projects on a MSc programme:

You can use elective modules for writing a project under supervision, rather than taking an elective. You register for the project in the registration period. You can chose to work on your own project entirely, collaborate with a company or do a group project.

The re project is intended as the bridge between your specialisation and your thesis. It allows you to focus very narrowly and in great detail on the particular sub-topics of your specialisation that will then be used in your thesis.

The re project is formally a project like any other, however, we do offer some help and guidelines for finding a supervisor. The content of the project is not limited, but is intended to feed into your thesis. The re project very often takes the form of a narrowly focused literature study or a prototype implementation or use of particular software tools.
See here for more information about the Re Project

Specially for KCS- and KSD-students studying abroad If you are going abroad in the semester just before writing your thesis, you can take an elective abroad instead of writing the Re Project – preapproval for the elective is still necessary.
Additionally, you are recommended to attend the Re Project Introduction meeting at ITU in week 35. The introduction meeting will is informative with regards to the Master thesis as well.
If this is not possible then check up on the general information about the Re project, since it also shares details about the thesis. (See link just above)

title: Weekly Schedule
paragraphs: Duration of lectures (Academic quarter)In TimeEdit, lectures and exercises are scheduled for whole hours but the average duration of a “teaching hour” is 50 minutes. From Autumn 2022, teachers are expected to begin the class 15 minutes after the hour (and end on the dot), to ensure a smooth transition between classes.Time slotsThe time slots for lectures and exercises start from 8.00 am and can run al through to 18.00 pm. (Friday from 8.00 - 16.00)You can find the weekly schedule for courses in ITU's timetable tool, TimeEdit.
Duration of lectures (Academic quarter)
In TimeEdit, lectures and exercises are scheduled for whole hours but the average duration of a “teaching hour” is 50 minutes.
From Autumn 2022, teachers are expected to begin the class 15 minutes after the hour (and end on the dot), to ensure a smooth transition between classes.
The time slots for lectures and exercises start from 8.00 am and can run al through to 18.00 pm. (Friday from 8.00 - 16.00)

title: Study Abroad
paragraphs: The IT University hosts an ExploreIT event every fall semester in November, and Open office sessions in the end of every semester and close to the fall semester start.
Exchange Student (at partner universities)

Studying can be expensive, but it does not need to be. If you apply for one of our partner universities, no tuition fee is required (unless otherwise stated). This is often not the case if you choose to study abroad without an agreement. In either case, you will have to cover travel expenses, housing, visa, insurance and living expenses yourself.
Fortunately, there are several possibilities for financial support
Lemvigh Müeller Foundation
After returning from your stay abroad, you need to fill out a travel report and send it to sap@itu.dk. Find the templates under: Practicalities - after
We use the Travel reports as evaluation and inspiration for other students. It is mandatory to fill out the Travel report.
Find the Travel reports for Exchange students, Freemovers, Summer school and other activities here.
full_text: Study Abroad Study Abroad Explore IT and Open Office Two ways of going abroad Practicalities Economy abroad Travel reports The IT University hosts an ExploreIT event every fall semester in November, and Open office sessions in the end of every semester and close to the fall semester start. Exchange Student (at partner universities) Studying can be expensive, but it does not need to be. If you apply for one of our partner universities, no tuition fee is required (unless otherwise stated). This is often not the case if you choose to study abroad without an agreement. In either case, you will have to cover travel expenses, housing, visa, insurance and living expenses yourself. Fortunately, there are several possibilities for financial support Lemvigh Müeller Foundation After returning from your stay abroad, you need to fill out a travel report and send it to sap@itu.dk. Find the templates under: Practicalities - after We use the Travel reports as evaluation and inspiration for other students. It is mandatory to fill out the Travel report. Find the Travel reports for Exchange students, Freemovers, Summer school and other activities here.

title: Withdrawal
paragraphs: If you are considering to withdraw and thereby end your studies at ITU, please carefully think through if you need to  the Study and Career Guidance beforehand.
There is no guarantee you can be re-enrolled at a later point, so talking to someone about your situation might be very helpful.

How to withdrawYou send a request for withdrawal from My Study Activities. Look under Adresses / Enrolment. You fill in the requested information by ticking of your programme and adding a date and reason for your withdrawal. We will send a confirmation to your ITU e-mail, when your request has been processed and your withdrawal has been completed.
You send a request for withdrawal from My Study Activities. Look under Adresses / Enrolment.
You fill in the requested information by ticking of your programme and adding a date and reason for your withdrawal.
We will send a confirmation to your ITU e-mail, when your request has been processed and your withdrawal has been completed.

Get a transcript of your passed examsBefore you withdraw, you can print a transcript of your exams from My Study Activities, and bring it to Student Affairs and Programmes to get it stamped and signed.The date you choose for your withdrawal can have impact on issues related to both exams and SU. We have listed the most important things for you to just have in mind when setting the date for your withdrawal.
Get a transcript of your passed exams
Before you withdraw, you can print a transcript of your exams from My Study Activities, and bring it to Student Affairs and Programmes to get it stamped and signed.

Exams and registrations Once you withdraw from your studies, your registrations for exams, scheduled after the date of your withdrawal are cancelled. Only exam attempts before the withdrawal date are graded. If you have not been graded for all the activities, you completed, please await the grades before you withdraw. SU If you withdraw from your enrolment on the first day of the month, you are not entitled to SU that month. If you withdraw on the second day or later, of the month, you are entitled to SU that month. If you withdraw in the last half of the month, the SU payment for the following month is likely to have been generated already, and you might have to refund SU for that month. If you end your studies at ITU because you are admitted to another study somewhere else, please remember to apply for SU again.
Exams and registrations
After 30 days from the termination of your studies your ITU-mail will close down, as will your access to all other ITU platforms that require your .
Remember to download and save all the information you might need access to at a later point, before everything is closed down.

title: Study hacks
paragraphs: There isn´t just one way to tackle study motivation and study techniques, but we have tried to give you some inspirational Study Hacks that you can try out.

If you become aware of the different ways to take notes and you find the methods that matches your ways of studying – then you can save a lot of time and at the same time remember a larger part of what you read.

It is normal to feel like, that you are spending most of your time on studying, but if you become aware of the different ways that you "read" during your study sessions - then you can optimize your reading to free up more time.
full_text: Study hacks Study Hacks Study hacks There isn´t just one way to tackle study motivation and study techniques, but we have tried to give you some inspirational Study Hacks that you can try out. If you become aware of the different ways to take notes and you find the methods that matches your ways of studying – then you can save a lot of time and at the same time remember a larger part of what you read. It is normal to feel like, that you are spending most of your time on studying, but if you become aware of the different ways that you "read" during your study sessions - then you can optimize your reading to free up more time.

title: After you return
paragraphs: After you finish your exchange you must

You are responsible the final transfer of course credits to your ITU degree. You do this by emailing us a transcript of records for the courses you have completed. Please do this as soon as possible upon return from the host university.
Some universities may send the transcript directly to ITU, and if so, we will ask you to come by and get your original transcript.
All grades obtained abroad are transferred to your degree certificate as passed. However, you will get a separate certificate from your host university showing your results in their grade scale.

Upon your return, you are required to write a travel report about your experiences abroad. This will enable other students to make use of and be inspired by your experiences. Note that the travel report will be uploaded to ITUstudent so consider leaving out sensitive data. See a list of travel reports here.
Template for travel report.

title: Exams and re-exams
