If you due to special circumstances cannot fulfil the progression requirement, you can apply for an exemption from this rule. Calculating the one-year period In case you have been granted leave of absence, this period is excluded when calculating the one-year period. Any credit transfer from courses taken prior to admission is excluded from the one-year period. If you have passed an exam at another university as part of your ITU study programme, this exam will be included in the one-year period. When is an exemption a possibility? The university can grant you an exemption if you can document that special circumstances apply to your situation. The special circumstances must relate to you as a student and must be externally imposed and something that you could not anticipate or plan for. This could for instance be illness affecting yourself or illness in your immediate family - or other personal special circumstances. Look here more information about How to apply for an exemption. What is special circumstances? Examples of what can qualify as special circumstances:Examples of what can qualify as special circumstances: Documented illness or an accident affecting yourself Documented illness in your immediate family (a spouse/partner, a sibling, a parent or a child) Death in your immediate family (see below) Childbirth Pregnancy-related complications A worsening of a chronic illness Or other special circumstances related to you individually which you could not anticipate or plan for Examples of what cannot qualify as special circumstances:Examples of what cannot qualify as special circumstances: Vacation Challenges or problems with attending classes and/or exams because of work Exams or courses scheduled at the same time or close to each other Academic challenges Lack of knowledge of rules and deadlines The fact that you will be delayed in completing your studies is not in itself a special circumstance The fact that you plan to start a master’s programme as a direct extension of your bachelor programme is not a special circumstance. Other circumstances which are not special, but can provide a basis for an exemption:There can also be other circumstances, which are not special, but can provide a basis for an exemption: Civic duties as a lay judge or member of a jury Athlete of elite sports Entrepreneurship of a certain scale Examples of what can qualify as special circumstances: Examples of what can qualify as special circumstances: Examples of what cannot qualify as special circumstances: Examples of what cannot qualify as special circumstances: Other circumstances which are not special, but can provide a basis for an exemption: There can also be other circumstances, which are not special, but can provide a basis for an exemption: Medical certificateSee the detailed requirements for the Medical certificate The requirements are aligned with executive order no. 908 of 18/08/2011 regarding "Executive Order on the issuance of medical certificates, etc." You must pay for the medical certificate yourself.Please note that the special circumstance, you describe in your application, must have taken place at a time and been of a duration that corresponds with the exemption you are applying for. See the detailed requirements for the Medical certificate The requirements are aligned with executive order no. 908 of 18/08/2011 regarding "Executive Order on the issuance of medical certificates, etc." You must pay for the medical certificate yourself. Death in the immediate family Death in the immediate family includes a spouse/partner, a parent, a sibling or a child. You can document this special circumstance with a copy of a death certificate. If you lose someone who is not your immediate family (see above) but someone you are very close to, you can apply for an exemption, if the death affects your ability to study. You must submit medical documentation which describes the close relationship with the person as well as how the death affects you and your ability to study. Can I deregister a course after a used attempt? Deregistration after used attemptAccording to the Danish Education Order it is not possible to be deregistered a study activity after you have used one or more exam attempts. ITU can make an exemption from this rule if there are special circumstances and these circumstances: are directly linked to the study activity, over a longer period of time prevents you from completing the course or project. Please note that an exemption from this rule is rarely granted, since both of the above-mentioned criteria must apply to your situation. Deregistration after used attempt According to the Danish Education Order it is not possible to be deregistered a study activity after you have used one or more exam attempts. ITU can make an exemption from this rule if there are special circumstances and these circumstances: Please note that an exemption from this rule is rarely granted, since both of the above-mentioned criteria must apply to your situation. This page was last updated January 2025

title: Old progression requirement
paragraphs: Below you will find the progression requirement outlined as from before 1 September, 2025
You are required to pass a certain amount of ECTS points each year, called the progression requirement.

BSc programmes after your 2nd semester: You must have passed 45 ECTS after your 4th semester: You must have passed 90 ECTS after your 6th semester: You must have passed 135 ECTS after your 8th semester: You must have passed 180 ECTS
MSc programmes after your 2nd semester: You must have passed 45 ECTS after your 4th semester: You must have passed 90 ECTS after your 6th semester: You must have passed 120 ECTS

Read moreCredits transferred from previous studiesIf you automatically have credits transferred from previous studies to your ITU programme before study start, these credits will count as part of the fulfillment of the progression requirement. However, if you apply for a credit transfer during your studies, these credits will not count as part of the fulfillment of the progression requirement. If ITU is not able to offer a coherent study plan with 30 ECTS each semester, you can apply for an exemption from the progression requirement. Failing to meet the requirementsIf you due to special circumstances cannot meet the progression requirement, you can apply for an exemption from the rule. paragraphs: When you have begun your studies, you have already started your career path. The choices you make during your studies will all together affect your CV and the skills you gain before you enter the job market after graduation.

Knowing your skills and competencies

In order to enhance your job opportunities after graduation, you should use all the possibilities you have to build your personal profile during your studies - it's all about considering how to gain and develop valuable skills.
You are always welcome to stop by the Study and Career Guidance for a talk about your future career.
Kickstart your career or develop your personal and professional skills by participating in IT Match Making or one of the many career related activities, events & workshops.

title: Exam Nervousness and Anxiety

headings.text: Get help with handling your exam anxiety

paragraphs: Many students are nervous about exams. A little nervousness is often an advantage, and it will actually help you perform better. Nervousness helps you to sharpen your senses and be mentally ready to perform. In other words, nervousness is often a natural, good, biological thing that can help you achieve more.

However, some students experience how this positive nervousness can turn into anxiety, which is detrimental to your exam preparation and performance. This can be very stressful, and for some it can hinder the preparation for the exam or even the participation in the exam.
Signs of exam anxiety can be both physical and mental.
Typical symptoms are: headache stomach pain hear palpitations sweaty palms loss of appetite fatigue sleeping difficulties concentration difficulties sadness
Mandy different things can cause exam anxiety, and there is no explanation as to why some think it is a breeze to take the exam, while others think it is terribly difficult.

If you experience fear or anxiety in relation to exams, it is important to try to understand where it stems from. What is it that makes you fear the exam? Here is a short list of tips you can consider if you experience exam anxiety:
You can also DOWNLOAD THE EXAM STRESS APP, to help you deal with the exams
You are always welcome to  the Study and Career Guidance if you experience troubles with exam nervousness or fear.
You can also  the Student Counselling Service, who offer free professional help and treatment for university students. Read more on their website, or ask the student advisors.

title: Study Abroad
paragraphs: The IT University hosts an ExploreIT event every fall semester in November, and Open office sessions in the end of every semester and close to the fall semester start.
Exchange Student (at partner universities)

Studying can be expensive, but it does not need to be. If you apply for one of our partner universities, no tuition fee is required (unless otherwise stated). This is often not the case if you choose to study abroad without an agreement. In either case, you will have to cover travel expenses, housing, visa, insurance and living expenses yourself.
Fortunately, there are several possibilities for financial support
Lemvigh Müeller Foundation
After returning from your stay abroad, you need to fill out a travel report and send it to sap@itu.dk. Find the templates under: Practicalities - after
We use the Travel reports as evaluation and inspiration for other students. It is mandatory to fill out the Travel report.
Find the Travel reports for Exchange students, Freemovers, Summer school and other activities here.

title: (No) registration requirement
paragraphs: A semester of full time studies corresponds to 30 ECTS. The study activities is everything you are registered for: all courses and all projects.
As a maximum you can register for study activities corresponding to 37,5 ECTS in total in one semester.
Structuring your studies If you choose to register for less than 30 ECTS you need to be aware of the following:

Important to be aware of Please see here for detailed information about the rules to be aware of. It can come in handy if you are in need of adjusting your study plan. The article will also talk you through the new process related to registration for courses, which has been a natural way to go considering the registration requirement has been discontinued starting September 2024.

Exemption from the rule If you do not meet the different rules or requirements, you will need an exemption to continue your studies at ITU. Go to this page for a full overview of the rules for your studies and information about applying for an exemption.

title: Credit Transfer

headings.text: How to apply for a credit transfer

paragraphs: If you have passed courses before your current enrolment you might qualify for a compulsory credit transfer. If not you can apply for a credit transfer in order to have your prior study activities be part of your ITU programme.

If you have acquired skills at a similar level and with similar content through previously uncompleted study programme, you will have already had to include this in your application. Based on your information, we will determine if you qualify for a compulsory credit transfer. The compulsory credit transfer we might grant you when starting your studies only relates to the mandatory courses on your programme. If you want courses taken in the past, to substitute elective modules here at ITU, you must apply for a credit transfer. If awarded this, you cannot take the course in question (ECTS) at ITU. Please follow this link for information on the requirements for progression.

The compulsory credit transfer we might grant you when starting your studies only relates to the mandatory courses on your programme. If you want courses taken in the past, to substitute elective modules here at ITU, you must apply for a credit transfer. If awarded this, you cannot take the course in question (ECTS) at ITU.
Please follow this link for information on the requirements for progression.

If relevantCredit transfer for Cross-disciplinary teamwork? See here for the detailsA credit transfer will be awarded if the study board of your programme considers your previously acquired skills to be equivalent to skills students will acquire in the current programme. You can apply to have credits transferred for both mandatory courses and elective modules.
Credit transfer for Cross-disciplinary teamwork?
See here for the details
When applying for a credit transfer related to elective modules, you do not need to describe the ITU electives.
If you have passed a course during your BSc programme that is similar to a course you need to take on your MSc programme, you cannot apply for a credit transfer.
Courses from a bachelor’s degree cannot be part of both your bachelor and MSc degree. A credit transfer only involves courses at a similar level.

How to apply for a credit transfer Fill out the application form informing us about your past course and stating the title of course in question at ITU.Or, if the course is an elective module, simply state this. Make a provisional study plan Include the relevant documentation: Link to course descriptions including the number of credits awarded for the course Course title and course code (add an English course title to be used on your final ITU diploma). Transcript of records Link to where the level of the course is documented (BSc or MSc). Students on part-time programmes such as Master and Diploma will also have to submit documentation that they have had two years of full-time work experience prior to following the course. This is NOT a requirement for BSc and MSc students.
The deadline is every 1st of the month throughout the year (July not included)

How does it work?This means that all applications received up until (as an example) March 1 will be processed during March. The reply to the application will then follow around first of April (the standard processing time being 4 weeks.) Apply in good time?If you want to apply in good time, then aim at applying for Autumn courses already during Spring. And vice versa apply for Spring courses during the autumn semester leading up.
This means that all applications received up until (as an example) March 1 will be processed during March.
The reply to the application will then follow around first of April (the standard processing time being 4 weeks.)
If you want to apply in good time, then aim at applying for Autumn courses already during Spring.
And vice versa apply for Spring courses during the autumn semester leading up.
NoticeIf you send us documents, please send as word or pdf-files. NO zip-files. You can enclose documentation as links (e.g. to a university’s course catalogue). Make sure that links are stable.
If you send us documents, please send as word or pdf-files.
You do not need to send us ITU Diplomas or course descriptions for ITU-courses.
Email the application to Student Affairs and Programmes at sap@itu.dk.

Credit Transfers and GradesThe grade for courses taken on foreign Universities will be converted to "passed" in your diploma. If you want to transfer courses you have taken while studying at ITU, that have already been pre-approved by ITU, you do not have to apply for a credit transfer. Simply send a transcript of the exams along with a copy of the pre-approval to sap@itu.dk.
Credit Transfers and Grades
The grade for courses taken on foreign Universities will be converted to "passed" in your diploma.
BSc students can transfer courses from other educational institutions up to a maximum of 120 ECTS. MSc students can transfer courses from other educational institutions up to a maximum of 60 ECTS.

Whether it concerns your compulsory credit transfer or the application made by you for a credit transfer (rejected or only partly approved), you can file a complaint. You must send the complaint within two weeks from the day you received the decision.

No matter who you are complaining to you send the complaint in an email to sap@itu.dk and we will direct it to the department responsible. It can take up to 4 weeks processing your application. For more information about complaints concerning credit transfer please check out these links: Overview of Credit Transfer appeals Meritankenævnsbekendtgørelsen University Programme Order

title: Welcome from SAP & the Study and Career Guidance

headings.text: Welcome from SAP & the Study and Career Guidance

paragraphs: Welcome to the IT University of Copenhagen!

The Student Affairs and Programmes Department (SAP) is the study administrative office at the IT University. We offer two different services for you as a student: Support in administrative matters and Study & Career Guidance.

The SAP Front Office offer you support in administrative matters, e.g. SU, admission, course registration, exams, exemptions or credit transfer. This means that if you cannot find the answer to your question at ITUstudent, you are very welcome to  the SAP Front Office. Call, write or find us just outside the 2E wing.

The Study & Career Guidance offer you guidance related to your studies and career, e.g. if you are in doubt about the direction of your studies, want to study abroad or need guidance to clarify your skills and competencies. We also offer guidance on personal issues, thesis- and project writing, exam anxiety, group matters and more.

As a new student there is a lot of information you need to process and it takes some time to feel "at home" at ITU. One way of speeding up that process is to become well acquainted with the content of the website ITUstudent. You will use the site a lot during your studies. Moreover, especially for new students, it can be beneficial to read more in detail about how to develop your study skills, how you are evaluated at exams and how to get involved in student organisations and / or student politics. You find this, and much more, information in the Study & Career Guidance tab and the Campus tab at ITUstudent.
The Study & Career Guidance is here to help so please, do not hesitate to  us.
We are looking forward to seeing you at ITU and wish you good luck with your studies!
Kind Regards, Student Affairs and Programmes

title: After you return
paragraphs: After you finish your exchange you must

You are responsible the final transfer of course credits to your ITU degree. You do this by emailing us a transcript of records for the courses you have completed. Please do this as soon as possible upon return from the host university.
Some universities may send the transcript directly to ITU, and if so, we will ask you to come by and get your original transcript.
All grades obtained abroad are transferred to your degree certificate as passed. However, you will get a separate certificate from your host university showing your results in their grade scale.

Upon your return, you are required to write a travel report about your experiences abroad. This will enable other students to make use of and be inspired by your experiences. Note that the travel report will be uploaded to ITUstudent so consider leaving out sensitive data. See a list of travel reports here.
Template for travel report.

title: Pre-approval of courses
paragraphs: ImportantYou can only apply for pre-approval of courses at the same level as your own programme. E.g. if you are on a bachelor programme you can only apply for courses at bachelor level.If you want to take courses at another university in the future as a part of your degree at the IT University, you must apply for a pre-approval.
You can only apply for pre-approval of courses at the same level as your own programme. E.g. if you are on a bachelor programme you can only apply for courses at bachelor level.

Be aware that aside from applying for pre-approval from ITU, you also need to follow the guidelines for admission, if you are taking the courses at other Universities. Look for admission rules for guest students or exchange students on their website.
If your courses are to be part of an individual specialisation, remember you need to apply for an individual specialisation, and not just the pre-approval.
The deadline is every 1st of the month throughout the year (July not included)

How does it work?This means that all applications received up until (as an example) March 1 will be processed during March. The reply to the application will then follow around first of April (the standard processing time being 4 weeks.) Apply in good time?If you want to apply in good time, then aim at applying for Autumn courses already during Spring. And vice versa apply for Spring courses during the autumn semester leading up.For Individual specialisations be aware of thisKeep in mind that you will need to have the approval, to be able to register for a specific course the coming semester. Therefore apply in good time with regards to the registration periods. Find them here An approved specialisation does not guarantee you a spot on the course.
This means that all applications received up until (as an example) March 1 will be processed during March.
The reply to the application will then follow around first of April (the standard processing time being 4 weeks.)
If you want to apply in good time, then aim at applying for Autumn courses already during Spring.
And vice versa apply for Spring courses during the autumn semester leading up.
For Individual specialisations be aware of this
Keep in mind that you will need to have the approval, to be able to register for a specific course the coming semester.
Therefore apply in good time with regards to the registration periods. Find them here
An approved specialisation does not guarantee you a spot on the course.

How to apply Fill out the application form Make a provisional study plan Include the relevant documentation: Link to course descriptions including the number of credits awarded for the course Course title and course code (add an English course title to be used on your final ITU diploma). Conversion to ECTS (if the course is not in ECTS). Please add a link to document how the conversion is made. Link to where the level of the course is documented (BSc or MSc). Students on Master and Diploma (part time programmes) will also have to submit documentation that they have had two years of full-time work experience prior to following the course. This is NOT a requirement for BSc and MSc students.
You must enclose documentation as links (e.g. to a university’s course catalogue). Make sure that links are stable.
You do not need to send us ITU-Diplomas or course descriptions for ITU-courses. We only need documentation from other universities.
Send the application to Student Affairs and Programmes at sap@itu.dk.

The handling of your application begins after the deadline. It involves different tasks in order to secure the academic output for you, when taking courses outside of ITU. This involves evaluating and comparing the courses that are listed for pre-approval, to guarantee that it matches you programme.

Because different people are involved at different times, and because of the amount of applications we normally receive, the processing time is 4 weeks. We always work hard to have a reply for you as soon as possible.

Useful informationHow to convert credits to ECTS when studying abroadIf the course(s) you want to have pre-approved are not ECTS-based, you must document how many credits/points/units cover a full time semester at the foreign university. For example: University X requires 120 credits to obtain a bachelor degree. The bachelor degree takes 8 semesters to complete (4 years). Hence, 120 credits is divided by 8 semesters, which is equal to 15 credits pr. semester.After you have passed the pre-approved coursesThe pre-approval of courses is a preliminary approval. It is not the actual transfer of credits from another educational institution. You must submit documentation of passed and non-passed courses that have been pre-approved by the university. You should do this as soon as you receive a transcript of your records. Send the documentation along with the original pre-approval letter from Student Affairs and Programmes by email to sap@itu.dk. If you are not going to use your pre-approvalYou must notify the IT University if you are not using your pre-approval, as you must be registered for study activities at the IT University instead. If you forget to tell us, the pre-approval will block you from registering for other courses.
How to convert credits to ECTS when studying abroad
If the course(s) you want to have pre-approved are not ECTS-based, you must document how many credits/points/units cover a full time semester at the foreign university.
For example: University X requires 120 credits to obtain a bachelor degree. The bachelor degree takes 8 semesters to complete (4 years).
Hence, 120 credits is divided by 8 semesters, which is equal to 15 credits pr. semester.
After you have passed the pre-approved courses
The pre-approval of courses is a preliminary approval. It is not the actual transfer of credits from another educational institution.
You must submit documentation of passed and non-passed courses that have been pre-approved by the university. You should do this as soon as you receive a transcript of your records.
Send the documentation along with the original pre-approval letter from Student Affairs and Programmes by email to sap@itu.dk.
If you are not going to use your pre-approval

You must notify the IT University if you are not using your pre-approval, as you must be registered for study activities at the IT University instead. If you forget to tell us, the pre-approval will block you from registering for other courses.
If your application is rejected or only partly approved, you can file a complaint.
You must send the complaint within two weeks from the day you received the decision.
No matter who you are complaining to you send the complaint in an email to sap@itu.dk and we will direct it to the department responsible.

It can take up to 4 weeks processing your application. For more information about complaints concerning pre-approval of courses please check out these links: Overview of Credit Transfer appeals Appeals regarding pre-approval of credit transfer Meritankenævnsbekendtgørelsen University Programme Order
This page was last updated August, 2023

title: Weekly Schedule
paragraphs: Duration of lectures (Academic quarter)In TimeEdit, lectures and exercises are scheduled for whole hours but the average duration of a “teaching hour” is 50 minutes. Teachers are expected to begin the class 15 minutes after the hour (and end on the dot), to ensure a smooth transition between classes.You can find the weekly schedule for courses in ITU's timetable tool, TimeEdit.
Duration of lectures (Academic quarter)
In TimeEdit, lectures and exercises are scheduled for whole hours but the average duration of a “teaching hour” is 50 minutes.
Teachers are expected to begin the class 15 minutes after the hour (and end on the dot), to ensure a smooth transition between classes.

title: After you return
paragraphs: After you finish your exchange you must

You are responsible the final transfer of course credits to your ITU degree. You do this by emailing us a transcript of records for the courses you have completed. Please do this as soon as possible upon return from the host university.
Some universities may send the transcript directly to ITU, and if so, we will ask you to come by and get your original transcript.
All grades obtained abroad are transferred to your degree certificate as passed. However, you will get a separate certificate from your host university showing your results in their grade scale.

Upon your return, you are required to write a travel report about your experiences abroad. This will enable other students to make use of and be inspired by your experiences. Note that the travel report will be uploaded to ITUstudent so consider leaving out sensitive data. See a list of travel reports here.
Template for travel report.

title: Specialisation and DADIU

headings.text: You register for the courses - not the specialisation
DADIU - All Games Students can apply

paragraphs: During the course of your programme, you have to choose and pass a specialisation. This gives you a more distinctive profile and it is an opportunity to point your academic profile in the direction you wish to go after graduation. You can choose one of the specialisations in the table below, or you can apply for an individual specialisation (see below). For how to register, go to Study Administration / Registration

During the course of your programme, you have to choose and pass a specialisation. This gives you a more distinctive profile and it is an opportunity to point your academic profile in the direction you wish to go after graduation.
You can choose one of the specialisations in the table below, or you can apply for an individual specialisation (see below).
For how to register, go to Study Administration / Registration
The specialisation Each specialisation amounts to a total of 30 ECTS credits, and consists of three specific modules:

Module 1 is a 7.5 ECTS course that you attend during the second semester. Module 2 is a 15 ECTS course that you attend during the third semester. Module 3 is a 7.5 ECTS course that you attend during the third semester.
You register for the courses - not the specialisationYou cannot register for a specialisation. Instead, you must sign up for and pass the courses on the specialisation.
You cannot register for a specialisation. Instead, you must sign up for and pass the courses on the specialisation.
If the specialisation options do not meet your specific demands or ambitions, you can apply for an individual specialisation.

An individual specialisation must meet the same official requirements as the predetermined specialisation. As the specialisation normally leads to the thesis, you need to ensure a progression in the individual specialisation. A specialisation is in total 30 ECTS.

DADIU (The National Academy of Digital, Interactive Entertainment) educates students in all aspects of producing a computer game. It is a collaboration between universities and art schools across Denmark, and the education is coordinated by the National Film School of Denmark.

ApplicationDADIU handles the application process. Read more about the education and how to apply on DADIU's websiteDADIU is an individual specialisation, which means that you have to apply for admission even though you are already accepted on the Games programme at ITU.
The DADIU individual specialisation consists of two courses:
You can find the course details in the Course catalogue in LearnIT ( under all courses)

The specialisation is only available in the autumn, and will cover all of your third semester courses. As the DADIU courses are 30 ECTS in total you cannot take more than 7,5 ECTS at the same time, e.g. if you are following courses for your third exam attempt.

How do I sign up for these courses?If you are admitted into the DADIU, Student Affairs and Programmes will register you for the two courses.During the first four weeks, you will get both a theoretical and a practical starting point for developing computer games. You learn about the important aspects of game development and are introduced to the various roles and responsibilities of the needed competencies. During October, you have the opportunity to focus on a specific aspect in game development that relates to your own specific competencies. The DADIU Curriculum consists of a series of individual courses organized by DADIU.
How do I sign up for these courses?

You spend the last two months of the DADIU semester on developing and completing a real computer game. Each team of approximately 15 students will have a production room with computers and software available.

title: Registration in Denmark
paragraphs: Life in DenmarkA practical guide to a number of things relevant when you are going to study in Denmark. The registration process upon arrival in Denmark depends on your citizenship. Whether you are a Nordic citizen, an EU/EEA citizen, or a non-EU/EEA citizen, different procedures apply.

For full details and to begin your application, please visit the official website: New to Denmark - Higher Education Programmes Getting a CPR-number Your CPR number is your personal social security number in Denmark. It grants you access to free public healthcare and is essential for many everyday tasks, such as opening a bank account, registering at public libraries, and obtaining MitID, which is used for secure communication with public authorities.

How to apply for a CPR number You can apply at the International House website. Once your application is approved, you will receive an email invitation to collect your CPR number. Sharing you CPR-number with SAP After receiving your CPR number, please visit the Student Affairs and Programmes front desk at the IT University so we can update your information in our administrative system. Be prepared to show proof of your CPR number by bringing the health card and photo ID. If you send it through, always use your ITU email for security reasons and remember to attach the relevant documentation.

title: Course evaluation

headings.text: What happens after the course evaluation?

paragraphs: Evaluation reportsEach semester, a course evaluation report is made with scores by course and study programme. Reports are published in week 51 (Autumn courses) and 21 (Spring Courses). Find the Course evaluation reports. Your feedback is key to quality assurance and development of courses. Participating in course evaluations is your chance to influence aspects of courses that matter to you. Teachers go carefully through your feedback and use it to adjust courses. Future students attending the course benefit from your feedback - just like you benefit from previous evaluations. The impact of your participation in evaluations reaches far beyond the current semester.
Each semester, a course evaluation report is made with scores by course and study programme. Reports are published in week 51 (Autumn courses) and 21 (Spring Courses).
Find the Course evaluation reports.
The course evaluation process looks like this:

During the first half of a course, teachers invite you and your fellow students to participate in a formative evaluation in class. This is your time to make yourself heard and share your good ideas and suggestions on how to make the course even better. When your share your opinion, the teachers have the possibility to adjust the course while it runs, to help your learning.
Please note that not everything is up for change. This goes for the intended learning objectives and the exam format for example. The teachers have the last word in deciding what to adjust.
The online course evaluation survey contains four questions and a comment box:
Please state your agreement with the following statements from 1 (strongly disagree) to 6 (strongly agree).
Comment box: Please give feedback on the course and your learning experience. Thank you for keeping a civil tone.
Students are anonymous when participating in the online survey. You are not anonymous when participating in the Mutual Alignment of Expectations or a qualitative end-evaluation in class.

Once you have participated in the course evaluation, the follow-up process begins. In the illustration below, you can see how your input becomes part of quality assuring and developing courses at ITU.
full_text: Course evaluation Course evaluation Why evaluate? How do I evaluate courses? Mutual alignment of expectations Course evaluation questions Anonymity What happens after the course evaluation? What can be changed? Evaluation reportsEach semester, a course evaluation report is made with scores by course and study programme. Reports are published in week 51 (Autumn courses) and 21 (Spring Courses). Find the Course evaluation reports. Your feedback is key to quality assurance and development of courses. Participating in course evaluations is your chance to influence aspects of courses that matter to you. Teachers go carefully through your feedback and use it to adjust courses. Future students attending the course benefit from your feedback - just like you benefit from previous evaluations. The impact of your participation in evaluations reaches far beyond the current semester. Each semester, a course evaluation report is made with scores by course and study programme. Reports are published in week 51 (Autumn courses) and 21 (Spring Courses). Find the Course evaluation reports. The course evaluation process looks like this: During the first half of a course, teachers invite you and your fellow students to participate in a formative evaluation in class. This is your time to make yourself heard and share your good ideas and suggestions on how to make the course even better. When your share your opinion, the teachers have the possibility to adjust the course while it runs, to help your learning. Please note that not everything is up for change. This goes for the intended learning objectives and the exam format for example. The teachers have the last word in deciding what to adjust. The online course evaluation survey contains four questions and a comment box: Please state your agreement with the following statements from 1 (strongly disagree) to 6 (strongly agree). Comment box: Please give feedback on the course and your learning experience. Thank you for keeping a civil tone. Students are anonymous when participating in the online survey. You are not anonymous when participating in the Mutual Alignment of Expectations or a qualitative end-evaluation in class. Once you have participated in the course evaluation, the follow-up process begins. In the illustration below, you can see how your input becomes part of quality assuring and developing courses at ITU.

title: The oral exam

headings.text: Structure, length and content of the oral exam

paragraphs: Online oral examIf necessary and agreed upon with your Course manager/examiner you can attend your oral exam online via zoom. Please see here for detailsOn the day of the exam, make sure that you arrive in due time before the exam.
If necessary and agreed upon with your Course manager/examiner you can attend your oral exam online via zoom.
Please see here for details
It is also your responsibility to check which aids are provided and allowed at the exam and in the exam preparation room.

You can see in the course catalogue how the oral exam for your course is conducted. If you have questions about the exam, you should  the course manager, so that you know which elements the exam will consist of, and what is expected of you.

No recordingStudents are not allowed to do any kind of auditory or visual recording during the exam.If you are attending a group exam, the specific option used for that particular exam will be described in the course catalogue.
You can find a description of the five different exam forms here. See also the time and date of your exams in TimeEdit.

Oral exams are publicOral examinations are public, but the Board of Studies at ITU have decided that examinations will take place behind closed doors on the examinee’s request. Moreover, the Board of Studies may decide in particular cases that an examination is not public, and specify who may be present during the examination. Only the internal and external examiners may be present during the voting. The Board of Studies may, however, decide that future examiners may be present at the voting as well.

title: Courses, electives and projects
paragraphs: Each programme consists of modules and study activities. Study activities are specific courses and projects that can fill out a module, and in order to fulfill the requirements in your curriculum, you must fill out all modules. The study activities that are available can change each semester, but the modules are always available. Some courses are mandatory, some you chose as electives and for some electives you can decide to convert the ECTS into an elective project. Mandatory Courses Some modules are filled with mandatory courses. Mandatory courses are courses that you have to take at specific points in a specific order during the course of your studies. The courses are often divided into lectures or class teaching and following exercises. 1st semester students are administratively registered for their mandatory courses on their first semester, but from there on students need to register for their mandatory courses in the registration periods. Electives Some modules are reserved for electives. Electives are courses that you decide on yourself but you must choose electives that are within the objectives of your programme. You can use an elective to steer your studies towards your individual interests, to inspire you for future projects or to supplement future specialisations. Special academic prerequisites?For some students their educational background might qualify them for courses outside the course list. Please read more here Courses to choose from You choose from the course list in LearnIT. The courses are all approved as electives for your programme . The courses are considered to be within the curricula of your programme and they are chosen from the perspective that the majority of students on the programme will have the basic qualifications to succeed on the course. Always check the pre-requisites However, it is always important to check the prerequisites and course descriptions for courses approved and offered. Some courses belong to a different study programme and they can require specific knowledge you might not have. In order to follow a course and sit for the exam, you must register for the course in the registration period. The course list See the courses that have been approved as electives for CS students here. Be aware that if you are on an older curricula, some courses might not be approved for you.

Each programme consists of modules and study activities. Study activities are specific courses and projects that can fill out a module, and in order to fulfill the requirements in your curriculum, you must fill out all modules. The study activities that are available can change each semester, but the modules are always available.
Some courses are mandatory, some you chose as electives and for some electives you can decide to convert the ECTS into an elective project.

1st semester students are administratively registered for their mandatory courses on their first semester, but from there on students need to register for their mandatory courses in the registration periods.
Some modules are reserved for electives. Electives are courses that you decide on yourself but you must choose electives that are within the objectives of your programme.
You can use an elective to steer your studies towards your individual interests, to inspire you for future projects or to supplement future specialisations.
Special academic prerequisites?
For some students their educational background might qualify them for courses outside the course list.
Please read more here

Courses to choose from You choose from the course list in LearnIT. The courses are all approved as electives for your programme . The courses are considered to be within the curricula of your programme and they are chosen from the perspective that the majority of students on the programme will have the basic qualifications to succeed on the course.

Always check the pre-requisites However, it is always important to check the prerequisites and course descriptions for courses approved and offered. Some courses belong to a different study programme and they can require specific knowledge you might not have.
In order to follow a course and sit for the exam, you must register for the course in the registration period.
The course list See the courses that have been approved as electives for CS students here.
Be aware that if you are on an older curricula, some courses might not be approved for you.

Study Abroad?You could also consider studying abroad. Please have a look at the Study Abroad section. You can also apply for pre-approval of a course at another university in Denmark. For more information on this, please go to Pre-approval of Courses. Useful information concerning coursesThe Course CatalogueYou can find descriptions of the current courses in the course catalogue in LearnIT / All courses. From October/April, you will be able to see a list of course titles for the coming semester. Full descriptions of the courses are available in November/May[date may be changed].Semester length and LearnITTeaching runs from Monday in week 5 and 35. Each course is taught for 14 weeks, though the course periods run for either 15 or 16 weeks, depending on bank holidays. The details for each course are available through LearnIT one week before the semester starts at the latest. You must be registered for a course in order to access it.Mandatory activitiesCourses may have mandatory activities that you need to pass in order to sit for the exam. Descriptions of the mandatory activities are available in the course base.Course evaluationsEach semester, you evaluate all your courses. You have ample possibility of sharing your opinion in the two-step Course evaluation during each course.ECTS and workloadOne ECTS corresponds to 27.5 hours of work for the students which is in line with the official Bologna process A 7.5 ECTS course therefore represents around 206 hours of activity in total. It is difficult to be more specific when speaking about all courses, but it serves as a basis for calculation. Assuming it will take 40 hours to prepare for exam in a 14 week course, this leaves an average of 11.8 work hours per week in those 14 weeks. Projects Project work is an important part of the MSc programme. It offers the opportunity to delve deeper into specific areas that interest you or your project group. Project work also allows for a more in-depth engagement with case organisations. There are different kinds of projects on a MSc programme: Thesis (30 ECTS). Learn more about the Thesis Re project (7,5 ECTS) Individual projects / Elective projects (7,5 or 15 ECTS). Summer Projects. (7,5 or 15 ECTS) Projects as part of a course You can use elective modules for writing a project under supervision, rather than taking an elective. You register for the project in the registration period. You can chose to work on your own project entirely, collaborate with a company or do a group project. Re Project The re project is intended as the bridge between your specialisation and your thesis. It allows you to focus very narrowly and in great detail on the particular sub-topics of your specialisation that will then be used in your thesis. The re project is formally a project like any other, however, we do offer some help and guidelines for finding a supervisor. The content of the project is not limited, but is intended to feed into your thesis. The re project very often takes the form of a narrowly focused literature study or a prototype implementation or use of particular software tools. See here for more information about the Re Project Specially for KCS- and KSD-students studying abroad If you are going abroad in the semester just before writing your thesis, you can take an elective abroad instead of writing the Re Project – preapproval for the elective is still necessary. Additionally, you are recommended to attend the Re Project Introduction meeting at ITU in week 35. The introduction meeting will is informative with regards to the Master thesis as well. If this is not possible then check up on the general information about the Re project, since it also shares details about the thesis. (See link just above)

Project work is an important part of the MSc programme. It offers the opportunity to delve deeper into specific areas that interest you or your project group. Project work also allows for a more in-depth engagement with case organisations.
There are different kinds of projects on a MSc programme:

You can use elective modules for writing a project under supervision, rather than taking an elective. You register for the project in the registration period. You can chose to work on your own project entirely, collaborate with a company or do a group project.

The re project is intended as the bridge between your specialisation and your thesis. It allows you to focus very narrowly and in great detail on the particular sub-topics of your specialisation that will then be used in your thesis.

The re project is formally a project like any other, however, we do offer some help and guidelines for finding a supervisor. The content of the project is not limited, but is intended to feed into your thesis. The re project very often takes the form of a narrowly focused literature study or a prototype implementation or use of particular software tools.
See here for more information about the Re Project

Specially for KCS- and KSD-students studying abroad If you are going abroad in the semester just before writing your thesis, you can take an elective abroad instead of writing the Re Project – preapproval for the elective is still necessary.
Additionally, you are recommended to attend the Re Project Introduction meeting at ITU in week 35. The introduction meeting will is informative with regards to the Master thesis as well.
If this is not possible then check up on the general information about the Re project, since it also shares details about the thesis. (See link just above)

title: Re-enrolment
paragraphs: DeadlineBSc: The deadline is March 15 We are processing the applications continuously, but if you apply after the deadline we cannot guarantee that your application will be processed before semester start You can only re-enrol for the Autumn semester. MSc: The deadline is February 15 We are processing the applications continuously, but if you apply after the deadline we cannot guarantee that your application will be processed before semester start You can only re-enrol for the Autumn semester. If you have resigned from an education that you now wish to resume, you can apply for re-enrolment.
BSc: The deadline is March 15
We are processing the applications continuously, but if you apply after the deadline we cannot guarantee that your application will be processed before semester start
You can only re-enrol for the Autumn semester.
MSc: The deadline is February 15
We are processing the applications continuously, but if you apply after the deadline we cannot guarantee that your application will be processed before semester start
You can only re-enrol for the Autumn semester.

You can only apply for re-enrolment in the newest curriculum of the study programme. If the programme has changed significantly or is not offered any longer, you might not be able to re-enrol in the programme. Please note, it is not possible to re-enrol in a dimensioned programme (BSc DDIT, MSc DDIT and Games). All re-enrolments will come into effect by semester start - last Monday of August.
We recommend that you get help from The Study and Career Guidance to make a realistic plan. You can use this template for the Study Plan.
Remember to submit all relevant documentation to the email.

title: Study Activity requirements

headings.text: It is the ECTS that counts

paragraphs: Extra SUIf you are delayed in your studies due to illness or special circumstances for a temporary period, you may be eligible for extra SU grant portions. Read more about extra SU grant portions on su.dk.Notice that the SU study activity requirement (according to the SU rules) is solely based on the amount of ECTS you have passed. It does not matter if you are an active student in the sense that you attend classes, study a lot, or are in compliance with the university’s requirement for study activity.
If you are delayed in your studies due to illness or special circumstances for a temporary period, you may be eligible for extra SU grant portions.
Read more about extra SU grant portions on su.dk.
All that matters is the amount of ECTS you have passed.
You are not allowed to be more than 30 ECTS delayed compared to full-time study progression (30 ECTS per semester)

Study activity checkTwice a year (Spring/Autumn) your study activity will be checked. If you do not fullfil the SU study activity requirement, you will be notifiedIf you are considered study inactive, you must pass exams so that you are no longer behind by more than 30 ECTS. Alternatively, you can apply for extra SU grant portions at minSU, if your delay is due to illness or special circumstances. You can easily keep track of your study progress regarding your SU on minSU / Se din SU / Studiefremdrift. Here you will find a visual overview of how many ECTS you have obtained and how many SU grant portions you have used. If you follow the black dots you can see whether you are delayed or not. You must apply for SU again when you have passed enough ECTS to be considered an active student (30 ECTS or less delayed); your SU will not resume automatically. Below you can also see examples of the allowed delay in your studies. Read more about study activity on su.dk
Twice a year (Spring/Autumn) your study activity will be checked.
If you do not fullfil the SU study activity requirement, you will be notified
Students enrolled July 2016 and later - Allowed delay is 6 months

Read more about extra SU grant portions on su.dk.Notice that the SU study activity requirement (according to the SU rules) is solely based on the amount of ECTS you have passed. It does not matter if you are an active student in the sense that you attend classes, study a lot, or are in compliance with the university’s requirement for study activity. If you are delayed in your studies due to illness or special circumstances for a temporary period, you may be eligible for extra SU grant portions. Read more about extra SU grant portions on su.dk. All that matters is the amount of ECTS you have passed. You are not allowed to be more than 30 ECTS delayed compared to full-time study progression (30 ECTS per semester) Study activity checkTwice a year (Spring/Autumn) your study activity will be checked. If you do not fullfil the SU study activity requirement, you will be notifiedIf you are considered study inactive, you must pass exams so that you are no longer behind by more than 30 ECTS. Alternatively, you can apply for extra SU grant portions at minSU, if your delay is due to illness or special circumstances. You can easily keep track of your study progress regarding your SU on minSU / Se din SU / Studiefremdrift. Here you will find a visual overview of how many ECTS you have obtained and how many SU grant portions you have used. If you follow the black dots you can see whether you are delayed or not. You must apply for SU again when you have passed enough ECTS to be considered an active student (30 ECTS or less delayed); your SU will not resume automatically. Below you can also see examples of the allowed delay in your studies. Read more about study activity on su.dk Twice a year (Spring/Autumn) your study activity will be checked. If you do not fullfil the SU study activity requirement, you will be notified Students enrolled July 2016 and later - Allowed delay is 6 months

title: Summer University

headings.text: Student Access Card for Summer University

paragraphs: From Student Affairs and Programmes we give you all a warm welcome to ITU!
LearnIT introduction video
When starting at ITU you will receive a username and your ITU e-mail address. This information is send to you in your welcome letter.
Your username + password + ITU email (your ITU account) is used to access all the systems at the IT-University of Copenhagen – e.g. LearnIT, email, printers and network drives.
You need to activate you ITU account with your MitID.
Before you can use your ITU-, you need to set up the Multi Factor Authentication.
We strongly recommend that you register a secondary authentication method, to avoid being locked out of your account.
The student Access Card will give you round the clock access to the IT University and you can use it for copying and printing. You need to pick up the card in the information desk.
Remember to pick it up no later than September 10.
AIR Lab Listen Up! Session #3: The Avenue of Sound by Steen Lund Holbek
PhD Defense by Olga Iarygina
Graduate Programme Event

title: The project page
paragraphs: Please Note: If your project is cancelled or pushed the project page will be shut down. If you need your work for later, you need to save and store it yourself.

The preliminary problem statement is where you zoom in on the scope of your project, giving a more precise description of your subject area, topic, hypothesis etc. Your supervisor must approve your problem statement and thereby also agree to supervise your project. After your supervisor approve your preliminary problem statement, it cannot be edited on the project page. However, you can still elaborate on it in the actual project. The preliminary problem statement will not be part of the assessment of your project. Therefore, your preliminary problem statement needs to be generic enough to allow for your scope to change as the project progresses, while at the same time be specific enough for your supervisor to be able to assess and approve of the scope of the project. This description is also used in the process of allocating an external examiner for your oral exam (where applicable). Therefore, we recommend that you spend some time to work on the preliminary problem statement before submitting.

Elective projects, Bachelor projects and Thesis: Friday in week 5 (for Spring) / 35 (for Autumn) Re project (CS, DS & SD): Friday in week 8 (for Spring) / 39 (for Autumn) Summer project: Friday week 26 Project agreements have a deadline running until 14:00 on the date given above.
Elective projects, Bachelor projects and Thesis: Friday in week 5 (for Spring) / 35 (for Autumn)
Re project (CS, DS & SD): Friday in week 8 (for Spring) / 39 (for Autumn)
Summer project: Friday week 26

Late registration If you register for a project, bachelor project or thesis in the registration change period, the deadline for the preliminary problem statement is moved to Friday in week 8 / week 39.

The title you registered in My Study Activities is the name of the project page and the default project title which will go on your diploma. To change the title of your project, you must write to sap@itu.dk and they will be happy to change the title for you. SAP will not be able to change the title of your project page, but only change the project title as it will appear on your diploma.
Please note, the title should be changed before you submit your project.

Projects are submitted on the project page, similar to course exams. See how to submit written work. Submission deadlines can be found here. When set, you can find the time and date for the oral exam in the calendar function on the project page. For more details on formal requirements for projects, see this overview Project work

title: Specialisations

headings.text: You register for the courses - not the specialisation

paragraphs: During the course of your programme, you have to choose and pass a specialisation. This gives you a more distinctive profile and it is an opportunity to point your academic profile in the direction you wish to go after graduation.
You can choose one of the specialisations in the table below, or you can apply for an individual specialisation (see below).
For how to register, go to Study Administration / Registration
The details Each specialisation amounts to a total of 22.5 ECTS points, and consists of two specific modules:
Module 1 is a 7.5 ECTS course that you attend during the second semester. Module 2 is a 15 ECTS course that you attend during the third semester.
Click the title for a description of the specialisation

*From Spring 2024, the course Data-Driven Design & Development will replace KAKRDAT1KU Crtitical Data Analysis as part 1 of the Data-driven Design specialisation. This is not reflected in the PDF description. **From Spring 2024, only the DIM Service Design specialisation will be offered. Read more.

You register for the courses - not the specialisationYou cannot register for a specialisation. Instead, you must sign up for and pass the courses on the specialisation. A course registration for the 1st part of the specialisation is a prerequisite for signing up for the 2nd part in the following semester.

You cannot register for a specialisation. Instead, you must sign up for and pass the courses on the specialisation. A course registration for the 1st part of the specialisation is a prerequisite for signing up for the 2nd part in the following semester.
If the specialisation options do not meet your specific demands or ambitions, you can apply for an individual specialisation.

An individual specialisation must meet the same official requirements as the predetermined specialisation. As the specialisation normally leads to the thesis, you need to ensure a progression within the individual specialisation. A specialisation is in total 22.5 ECTS.
Please follow this link for information on how to apply.

title: Labs
paragraphs: At ITU, we have awesome labs that you are free to use as a student.

In the labs, you can do experiments, build prototypes, get help realizing your projects, get help to connect with industry, attend extracurricular activities and meet like-minded students and faculty.
The Air Lab explores affective designs for living with digital technologies, and how such affective interactions can change our relations to the world, each other and ourselves.

AIR lab supports bachelor projects, master thesis projects, and re projects. These projects can develop prototypes, set up tests, borrow equipment, and get support for prototyping and working with our equipment and technical infrastructures.
Monday 10:00 - 15:00 Wednesday 12:30 - 16:30 Thursday 10:00 - 15:00
BUILD, the data innovation lab, seeks to provide an environment for students, industry, and reers, where innovation can be driven by data learnings in both the qualitative and quantitative sense.

BUILD Lab supports scoping and finding the appropriate case for a: course, bachelor and master thesis, or re project. By getting in touch, you can get access to the network of cases and a variety of data with the purpose of finding one that is suitable for your project.
Drop in: Wednesday 11:00 - 14:30
Appointment only: Tuesday 11:00 - 14:30 Thursday 12:30 - 16:00

The ITU brAIn lab is a space and a group of people with a common interest in re and education at the crossroads between machine learning, psychophysiology, neuroscience and cognition. Within the lab, reers and students collaborate to develop computational models of different aspects of the human mind and design experiments to capture and synthesise the user experience in complex digital media like video games and virtual reality.

At the DASYA Lab (Data-Intensive Systems and Applications) Lab, we build the infrastructure of data science. Our focus is on scalable and efficient systems supporting the data lifecycle, including collection, transfer, storage, processing, analytics and curation.

Here, you will find support and resources from arduino to android, from raspberry to regular expressions, from UI to IoT, from 3D printing to data portals, from soldering to sensors to smart things to servers.

The Human Data Interaction Lab (or hdilab in short) focuses on the human factors in the conception, use, and understanding of data. The lab functions as a venue for discussing matters related to human data interaction broadly and invites students and faculty to join forces to better understand these aspects

ETHOS Lab is an experimental space for exploring data and data landscapes in contemporary society. Here you will find room for methodological and analytical exploration. Each semester, the Lab offers workshops, tools training, and public talks about methods. Students can apply for a position as Junior Reer in the lab and join one of our study groups.
Tuesday 12:30 - 16:00 Thursday 12:30 - 16:00

The Game Lab is a space for exploring playful ideas. Whether you want to work on a VR game, run a machine learning experiment or test a multiplayer toy on the big screen, this room offers equipment to work on your games and playful experiences. Each semester, the Game Lab hosts a number of workshops and talks and it is also home of the Demo Night, a bi-monthly event where students as well as industry guests show and discuss unfinished projects.

At IxD Lab, we focus on physical interaction design, material exploration and modern fabrication technologies. We support courses that demand tools such as 3D printing, laser cutting, Arduino, Raspberry Pi, and we have a stock of sensors and actuators. In addition, we offer training and guidance in technical aspects of rapid prototyping and material choice, and occasionally we host talks about interaction design.
Drop in Thursday 9:00 - 12:00 (Tech and prototype support) Thursday 13:00 - 16:00 (Tech support)
Appointment only Wednesday 9:00 - 12:00

The Robotics, Evolution and Artificial Life (REAL) Lab hosts projects involving robotics, bio-inspired artificial intelligence, art and mechatronics. We have resources to build prototypes and robots: an industrial robotic arm (UR5), 8 small wheeled robots (Thymio), and 2 liquid handling robots. We can also provide access to computer clusters and high performance GPUs. You should  a member of the REAL to get access.
In Study Lab, teaching assistants help students with course topics that the students find difficult. Your teachers can tell you more.
See LearnIT for details about opening hours.
- Website with time slots

title: How to create your personal profile

headings.text: How to create your personal profile

paragraphs: Here are some examples of how you can create a personal profile in many different ways:
When you have the possibility to chose elective courses, projects and specialisations, you should consider how these will complement or deepen the skills and competencies you have already developed.
Are there for example any areas where you would like to develop your knowledge or practical skills? In terms of elective courses, you can also apply for a course at another university.
Read more about pre-approval for courses here.

Studying abroad is both academically and personally evolving, and can give you a unique academic profile, language skills, intercultural awareness and an international network for life. Many employers value international experience.
Read more about studying abroad here.
Collaborating with a company during your studies is an excellent way to learn about the job market, enhance your network and develop and practice your skills.
Read more about collaborating with companies here.

Are there for example any areas where you would like to develop your knowledge or practical skills? In terms of elective courses, you can also apply for a course at another university. Read more about pre-approval for courses here. Studying abroad is both academically and personally evolving, and can give you a unique academic profile, language skills, intercultural awareness and an international network for life. Many employers value international experience. Read more about studying abroad here. Read more about collaborating with companies here.

title: Pre-approval of courses
paragraphs: ImportantYou can only apply for pre-approval of courses at the same level as your own programme. E.g. if you are on a bachelor programme you can only apply for courses at bachelor level.If you want to take courses at another university in the future as a part of your degree at the IT University, you must apply for a pre-approval.
You can only apply for pre-approval of courses at the same level as your own programme. E.g. if you are on a bachelor programme you can only apply for courses at bachelor level.

Be aware that aside from applying for pre-approval from ITU, you also need to follow the guidelines for admission, if you are taking the courses at other Universities. Look for admission rules for guest students or exchange students on their website.
If your courses are to be part of an individual specialisation, remember you need to apply for an individual specialisation, and not just the pre-approval.
The deadline is every 1st of the month throughout the year (July not included)

How does it work?This means that all applications received up until (as an example) March 1 will be processed during March. The reply to the application will then follow around first of April (the standard processing time being 4 weeks.) Apply in good time?If you want to apply in good time, then aim at applying for Autumn courses already during Spring. And vice versa apply for Spring courses during the autumn semester leading up.For Individual specialisations be aware of thisKeep in mind that you will need to have the approval, to be able to register for a specific course the coming semester. Therefore apply in good time with regards to the registration periods. Find them here An approved specialisation does not guarantee you a spot on the course.
This means that all applications received up until (as an example) March 1 will be processed during March.
The reply to the application will then follow around first of April (the standard processing time being 4 weeks.)
If you want to apply in good time, then aim at applying for Autumn courses already during Spring.
And vice versa apply for Spring courses during the autumn semester leading up.
For Individual specialisations be aware of this
Keep in mind that you will need to have the approval, to be able to register for a specific course the coming semester.
Therefore apply in good time with regards to the registration periods. Find them here
An approved specialisation does not guarantee you a spot on the course.

How to apply Fill out the application form Make a provisional study plan Include the relevant documentation: Link to course descriptions including the number of credits awarded for the course Course title and course code (add an English course title to be used on your final ITU diploma). Conversion to ECTS (if the course is not in ECTS). Please add a link to document how the conversion is made. Link to where the level of the course is documented (BSc or MSc). Students on Master and Diploma (part time programmes) will also have to submit documentation that they have had two years of full-time work experience prior to following the course. This is NOT a requirement for BSc and MSc students.
You must enclose documentation as links (e.g. to a university’s course catalogue). Make sure that links are stable.
You do not need to send us ITU-Diplomas or course descriptions for ITU-courses. We only need documentation from other universities.
Send the application to Student Affairs and Programmes at sap@itu.dk.

The handling of your application begins after the deadline. It involves different tasks in order to secure the academic output for you, when taking courses outside of ITU. This involves evaluating and comparing the courses that are listed for pre-approval, to guarantee that it matches you programme.

Because different people are involved at different times, and because of the amount of applications we normally receive, the processing time is 4 weeks. We always work hard to have a reply for you as soon as possible.

Useful informationHow to convert credits to ECTS when studying abroadIf the course(s) you want to have pre-approved are not ECTS-based, you must document how many credits/points/units cover a full time semester at the foreign university. For example: University X requires 120 credits to obtain a bachelor degree. The bachelor degree takes 8 semesters to complete (4 years). Hence, 120 credits is divided by 8 semesters, which is equal to 15 credits pr. semester.After you have passed the pre-approved coursesThe pre-approval of courses is a preliminary approval. It is not the actual transfer of credits from another educational institution. You must submit documentation of passed and non-passed courses that have been pre-approved by the university. You should do this as soon as you receive a transcript of your records. Send the documentation along with the original pre-approval letter from Student Affairs and Programmes by email to sap@itu.dk. If you are not going to use your pre-approvalYou must notify the IT University if you are not using your pre-approval, as you must be registered for study activities at the IT University instead. If you forget to tell us, the pre-approval will block you from registering for other courses.
How to convert credits to ECTS when studying abroad
If the course(s) you want to have pre-approved are not ECTS-based, you must document how many credits/points/units cover a full time semester at the foreign university.
For example: University X requires 120 credits to obtain a bachelor degree. The bachelor degree takes 8 semesters to complete (4 years).
Hence, 120 credits is divided by 8 semesters, which is equal to 15 credits pr. semester.
After you have passed the pre-approved courses
The pre-approval of courses is a preliminary approval. It is not the actual transfer of credits from another educational institution.
You must submit documentation of passed and non-passed courses that have been pre-approved by the university. You should do this as soon as you receive a transcript of your records.
Send the documentation along with the original pre-approval letter from Student Affairs and Programmes by email to sap@itu.dk.
If you are not going to use your pre-approval

You must notify the IT University if you are not using your pre-approval, as you must be registered for study activities at the IT University instead. If you forget to tell us, the pre-approval will block you from registering for other courses.
If your application is rejected or only partly approved, you can file a complaint.
You must send the complaint within two weeks from the day you received the decision.
No matter who you are complaining to you send the complaint in an email to sap@itu.dk and we will direct it to the department responsible.

It can take up to 4 weeks processing your application. For more information about complaints concerning pre-approval of courses please check out these links: Overview of Credit Transfer appeals Appeals regarding pre-approval of credit transfer Meritankenævnsbekendtgørelsen University Programme Order
This page was last updated August, 2023

It involves different tasks in order to secure the academic output for you, when taking courses outside of ITU. This involves evaluating and comparing the courses that are listed for pre-approval, to guarantee that it matches you programme. Because different people are involved at different times, and because of the amount of applications we normally receive, the processing time is 4 weeks. We always work hard to have a reply for you as soon as possible. Useful informationHow to convert credits to ECTS when studying abroadIf the course(s) you want to have pre-approved are not ECTS-based, you must document how many credits/points/units cover a full time semester at the foreign university. For example: University X requires 120 credits to obtain a bachelor degree. The bachelor degree takes 8 semesters to complete (4 years). Hence, 120 credits is divided by 8 semesters, which is equal to 15 credits pr. semester.After you have passed the pre-approved coursesThe pre-approval of courses is a preliminary approval. It is not the actual transfer of credits from another educational institution. You must submit documentation of passed and non-passed courses that have been pre-approved by the university. You should do this as soon as you receive a transcript of your records. Send the documentation along with the original pre-approval letter from Student Affairs and Programmes by email to sap@itu.dk. If you are not going to use your pre-approvalYou must notify the IT University if you are not using your pre-approval, as you must be registered for study activities at the IT University instead. If you forget to tell us, the pre-approval will block you from registering for other courses. How to convert credits to ECTS when studying abroad If the course(s) you want to have pre-approved are not ECTS-based, you must document how many credits/points/units cover a full time semester at the foreign university. For example: University X requires 120 credits to obtain a bachelor degree. The bachelor degree takes 8 semesters to complete (4 years). Hence, 120 credits is divided by 8 semesters, which is equal to 15 credits pr. semester. After you have passed the pre-approved courses The pre-approval of courses is a preliminary approval. It is not the actual transfer of credits from another educational institution. You must submit documentation of passed and non-passed courses that have been pre-approved by the university. You should do this as soon as you receive a transcript of your records. Send the documentation along with the original pre-approval letter from Student Affairs and Programmes by email to sap@itu.dk. If you are not going to use your pre-approval You must notify the IT University if you are not using your pre-approval, as you must be registered for study activities at the IT University instead. If you forget to tell us, the pre-approval will block you from registering for other courses. If your application is rejected or only partly approved, you can file a complaint. You must send the complaint within two weeks from the day you received the decision. No matter who you are complaining to you send the complaint in an email to sap@itu.dk and we will direct it to the department responsible. It can take up to 4 weeks processing your application. For more information about complaints concerning pre-approval of courses please check out these links: Overview of Credit Transfer appeals Appeals regarding pre-approval of credit transfer Meritankenævnsbekendtgørelsen University Programme Order This page was last updated August, 2023

title: Courses outside ITU

headings.text: Courses at other universities in Denmark
Courses passed before enrolling at ITU

paragraphs: You can take courses outside ITU as part of you programme. Courses at other universities in Denmark If you want to do courses at other universities in Denmark, you need to have the courses pre-approved. Be aware that besides applying for pre-approval from ITU you also need to follow the guidelines for admission at the University where you want to take your electives. Look for admission rules for guest students on their website. Courses passed before enrolling at ITUIf you have passed courses that are relevant for your studies at ITU before you enrolled at ITU, you can apply for a Credit Transfer. Studying abroad If you want to take courses at Universities outside Denmark, you can apply to go on Exchange. This involves getting a pre-approval well. Read about how to Study Abroad.
