Study Abroad?You could also consider studying abroad. Please have a look at the Study Abroad section. You can also apply for pre-approval of a course at another university in Denmark. For more information on this, please go to Pre-approval of Courses. Useful information concerning coursesThe Course CatalogueYou can find descriptions of the current courses in the course catalogue in LearnIT / All courses. From October/April, you will be able to see a list of course titles for the coming semester. Full descriptions of the courses are available in November/May[date may be changed].Semester length and LearnITTeaching runs from Monday in week 5 and 35. Each course is taught for 14 weeks, though the course periods run for either 15 or 16 weeks, depending on bank holidays. The details for each course are available through LearnIT one week before the semester starts at the latest. You must be registered for a course in order to access it.Mandatory activitiesCourses may have mandatory activities that you need to pass in order to sit for the exam. Descriptions of the mandatory activities are available in the course base.Course evaluationsEach semester, you evaluate all your courses. You have ample possibility of sharing your opinion in the three-step course evaluation during each course.ECTS and workloadOne ECTS corresponds to 27.5 hours of work for the students which is in line with the official Bologna process A 7.5 ECTS course therefore represents around 206 hours of activity in total. It is difficult to be more specific when speaking about all courses, but it serves as a basis for calculation. Assuming it will take 40 hours to prepare for exam in a 14 week course, this leaves an average of 11.8 work hours per week in those 14 weeks. Projects Project work is an important part of the MSc programme. It offers the opportunity to delve deeper into specific areas that interest you or your project group. Project work also allows for a more in-depth engagement with case organisations. There are different kinds of projects on a MSc programme: Thesis (30 ECTS). Learn more about the Thesis Individual projects / Elective projects (7,5 or 15 ECTS). Summer Projects (7,5 or 15 ECTS). Projects as part of a course You can use elective modules for writing a project under supervision, rather than taking an elective. You register for the project in the registration period. You can chose to work on your own project entirely, collaborate with a company or do a group project.

Study Abroad?You could also consider studying abroad. Please have a look at the Study Abroad section. You can also apply for pre-approval of a course at another university in Denmark. For more information on this, please go to Pre-approval of Courses.

Project work is an important part of the MSc programme. It offers the opportunity to delve deeper into specific areas that interest you or your project group. Project work also allows for a more in-depth engagement with case organisations.
There are different kinds of projects on a MSc programme:

You can use elective modules for writing a project under supervision, rather than taking an elective. You register for the project in the registration period. You can chose to work on your own project entirely, collaborate with a company or do a group project.

title: Oral presentation

headings.text: Three steps to consider when preparing

paragraphs: During your studies, you will have to prepare oral presentations, either as part of a course or in an oral exam.
The more you train your oral presentation skills, the more calm and experienced you will become.
Just as being a good presenter can be useful during your studies, it can also be necessary in your student job or future career.
For information about the formalities about an online exam, please see here for course exams and here for thesis/projects exams
Read the exam guideGo through the guide for good advice
Train your communication skillsGo through the guide for good advice
Try to record a videoGo through the guide for good advice
Make a planGo through the guide for good advice
Remember!Go through the guide for good advice
Becoming a good presenter requires practice and preparation. The more you practice, the better you get.
Performing well in exams is not just about knowing all your stuff. It is very much about how you present your knowledge.
Consider the following 3 steps when you are preparing for your oral presentation:
Plan your presentation

- What are your main points? - How do you structure it? - How much time do you have? - Who are you talking to? - Who is your audience? - Introduce your presentation - Make your argumentation - Show your findings - Conclude your presentation (summarizing)
Practice your presentation

- Talk in short sentences - Divide your presentation into parts - Be specific - Speaking your presentation out loud (for instance to a friend or someone else) - Saying it out loud helps (it makes you aware of what it is you really want to say during your presentation)
Evaluate your presentation
- What went well? - How can you improve next time? - Get feedback from your audience (what did they think?)

Everyone can get nervous when they are going to do a presentation. No matter how many times you have done it, you can get nervous due to different biological, social and psychological factors. Often you get nervous because you want to perform well at the presentation.
One of the most important things when dealing with nervousness is accepting it! It is not going to disappear, and the more you focus on it, the more it will become apparent.
Consider if you are all going to talk, or if only one of you will do the presentation.
If you all participate in the presentation, make sure that all group members are engaged in the presentation - also when it is not their turn to talk.
Look at the person speaking, to help your audience focus and not draw attention away from the presentation.
When you do a presentation, it can be helpful to have tools to support you.
However, it is important that these tools do support, rather than draw attention from, your presentation.

Many presentations are done with slides. This can be a good way to engage your audience, and to support the structure of your presentation. It can also help you remember what you are going to say next. But be careful not to create slides that will disturb your presentation. Do not add too much text, as it will be hard for the audience to both read the text on the slides and listen to what you are saying.

Meta communication is when you communicate about your presentation at your presentation. It can be explaining the structure of the presentation from the beginning: "First, I will present you with ... Then we shall see how ... The presentation will be concluded with a summary ... And then you can ask questions ..." You can also meta communicate about other things. If you articulate it yourself, people can focus on what you are actually saying, rather than focusing on your nervousness.

Some people prefer having small cards with notes on them. This can be a great way to help you keep focus on the structure of the presentation. It can be helpful to have only one main point on each card.
For all oral exams you can choose to attend the exam online.
You need to agree on this with your examiners, so talk with your course manager or project supervisor about this.

The more you train your oral presentation skills, the more calm and experienced you will become. Just as being a good presenter can be useful during your studies, it can also be necessary in your student job or future career. title: Transcripts and documents
paragraphs: If you need documentation of your enrollment, a transcript of your records or documentation of your graduation, you need to print these from My Study Activities.
Once printed, you can email it to sap@itu.dk or stop by Student Affairs and Programmes (SAP) to get an official stamp and signature, if needed. See opening hours for SAP front here.

If you need documentation concerning something specific, you are welcome to formulate your own text on it, print it and come by to have us check, sign and stamp your information. Of course we can only sign for information we are able to control (i.e. use of exam attempts or that your programme is taught in English etc.).
If necessary, find the ITU letter template here: Danish version or English version.
If you are no longer a student at ITU and you need a transcript, please  sap@itu.dk

Once printed, you can email it to sap@itu.dk or stop by Student Affairs and Programmes (SAP) to get an official stamp and signature, if needed. See opening hours for SAP front here. If you need documentation concerning something specific, you are welcome to formulate your own text on it, print it and come by to have us check, sign and stamp your information. Of course we can only sign for information we are able to control (i.e. use of exam attempts or that your programme is taught in English etc.). If necessary, find the ITU letter template here: Danish version or English version. If you are no longer a student at ITU and you need a transcript, please sap@itu.dk

title: Courses outside ITU

headings.text: Courses at other universities in Denmark
Courses passed before enrolling at ITU

paragraphs: You can take courses outside ITU as part of you programme. Courses at other universities in Denmark If you want to do courses at other universities in Denmark, you need to have the courses pre-approved. Be aware that besides applying for pre-approval from ITU you also need to follow the guidelines for admission at the University where you want to take your electives. Look for admission rules for guest students on their website. Courses passed before enrolling at ITUIf you have passed courses that are relevant for your studies at ITU before you enrolled at ITU, you can apply for a Credit Transfer. Studying abroad If you want to take courses at Universities outside Denmark, you can apply to go on Exchange. This involves getting a pre-approval well. Read about how to Study Abroad.

title: Collegiate Bodies
paragraphs: Here you can learn more about the collegiate bodies at the IT University.

The Board of Directors The Board of Directors is the highest authority of the IT University. The Board of Directors is composed of 1 chairman and 8 members. The Board of Directors represents the interests of the university as an educational and scientific institution and establishes the guidelines for the organization, the long-range-activities and the development of the university.

As a member of the Board of Directors you will be participating at around 3 yearly meetings and at an annual seminar. To be able to run for membership of the Board of Directors you must be enrolled in a bachelor of science, master of science, master or a diploma programme at the university the first day in the month where the election has been called and at the time of the election.

The Board of Studies The Board of Studies is set up to ensure the students´ influence on education and teaching. The Board of Studies must ensure planning, completion and development of education and teaching at ITU. The Board of Studies is composed of 8 members appointed by the subject area teams and 2 members elected directly for the Board of Studies ITU.
Making statements and discuss issues on education and teaching, which the Vice Chancellor, or a person authorized by the Vice Chancellor, presents.

To be able to run for membership of the Board of Studies you must be enrolled in a bachelor of science, master of science, master or a diploma programme, within the area of the Board of Studies, the first day in the month where the election has been called and at the time of the election.

The Academic Board The Academic Board is set up by The Vice Chancellor and is composed of 1 chairman and 4 members. The Board makes statements to the vice chancellor concerning the internal allocation of funds and strategic science- and educational areas and plans for the knowledge sharing. It is also the Academic Board who gives out PhD- and doctor´s degrees. The Board can make statements on all academic issues of great concern for the activities at ITU and must discuss all issues presented by the vice chancellor.

To be able to run for membership of the Academic Board you must be enrolled in a bachelor of science, master of science, master or a diploma programme at the university the first day in the month where the election has been called and at the time of the election.

The PhD Board The PhD Board is set up to ensure influence on the PhD-studies for the students. The PhD Board is composed of 8 members. Half of the members are elected among the scientific staff and half of the members are elected among PhD-students. In the PHD Board you will be participating in:
To run for membership of the PhD Board you must be enrolled in the PhD-studies at the university the first day in the month where the election has been called and at the time of the election.

Subject Area Teams In the Subject Area Teams you will participate in developing your own education. You will be participating in developing courses, specializations and on the whole participate in ensuring coherence in the education. You might also get the possibility to be part of a appeals board, who handles complaints about examinations.
The Subject Area Team for Games consist of 2 VIP members and 2 students.
The Subject Area Team for Digital Design consist of 2 VIP members and 2 students.
The Subject Area Team for Computer Science (before Software) consist of 5 VIP members and 5 students.
The Subject Area Team for Business consist of 3 VIP members and 3 students.
2 members of each Subject Area Team, 1 VIP member and 1 student, represent the team in the Study Board ITU.

To be able to run for membership of a subject area team you must be enrolled in a bachelor of science, master of science, master or a diploma programme, within the area of the subject area team, the first day in the month where the election has been called and at the time of the election.

When seats are allocated in the Subject Area Teams for Business and Digital Design – please see the rules on calculation of votes in the Election regulations – one seat is reserved for each level of programme. In the Subject Area for Computer Science one seat is reserved for the Master of Science programme, one for each of Bachelor programmes and one for the part time programmes. In case these seat are not taken, those with most votes in other categories, will take the seat.

title: Course evaluation

headings.text: What happens after the course evaluation?

paragraphs: Evaluation reportsEach semester, a course evaluation report is made with scores by course and study programme. Reports are published in week 51 (Autumn courses) and 21 (Spring Courses). Find the Course evaluation reports. Your feedback is key to quality assurance and development of courses. Participating in course evaluations is your chance to influence aspects of courses that matter to you. Teachers go carefully through your feedback and use it to adjust courses. Future students attending the course benefit from your feedback - just like you benefit from previous evaluations. The impact of your participation in evaluations reaches far beyond the current semester.
Each semester, a course evaluation report is made with scores by course and study programme. Reports are published in week 51 (Autumn courses) and 21 (Spring Courses).
Find the Course evaluation reports.
The course evaluation process looks like this:

During the first half of a course, teachers invite you and your fellow students to participate in a formative evaluation in class. This is your time to make yourself heard and share your good ideas and suggestions on how to make the course even better. When your share your opinion, the teachers have the possibility to adjust the course while it runs, to help your learning.
Please note that not everything is up for change. This goes for the intended learning objectives and the exam format for example. The teachers have the last word in deciding what to adjust.
The online course evaluation survey contains four questions and a comment box:
Please state your agreement with the following statements from 1 (strongly disagree) to 6 (strongly agree).
Comment box: Please give feedback on the course and your learning experience. Thank you for keeping a civil tone.
Students are anonymous when participating in the online survey. You are not anonymous when participating in the Mutual Alignment of Expectations or a qualitative end-evaluation in class.

Once you have participated in the course evaluation, the follow-up process begins. In the illustration below, you can see how your input becomes part of quality assuring and developing courses at ITU.

title: Thesis re-exam
paragraphs: The below concerns the Thesis
Three attemptsYou have three attempts to pass the exam.
You have three attempts to pass the exam.
If you / your group fail to hand in your thesis before the deadline, The Study Administration will  you via email after the deadline and inform you of the following consequences:

Within 2 weeks after you have received the email you must make an adjustment to the existing problem statement in co-operation with your supervisor. The objective is to make it more realistic that you will be able to hand in the thesis by the new deadline. You upload the adjusted problem statement in a folder on your project page.

Within 2 weeks after you have received the email you must make an adjustment to the existing problem statement in co-operation with your supervisor. The objective is to make it more realistic that you will be able to hand in the thesis by the new deadline.
You upload the adjusted problem statement in a folder on your project page.
If you / your group fail to submit at the new deadline, The Study Administration will  you via email after the deadline and inform you of the following consequences:

In addition to updating your problem statement again, you must make a written plan for the rest of your thesis work, also within a 2-week-limit. The plan should contain an overview of subsidiary goals and planned meetings with your supervisor. The plan is meant to be a help for you to complete your thesis on time. You upload the adjusted problem statement and the written plan in a folder on your project page.

In addition to updating your problem statement again, you must make a written plan for the rest of your thesis work, also within a 2-week-limit. The plan should contain an overview of subsidiary goals and planned meetings with your supervisor.
The plan is meant to be a help for you to complete your thesis on time.
You upload the adjusted problem statement and the written plan in a folder on your project page.

title: Submitting written work
paragraphs: LearnIT Guides - how to submitCOURSE EXAM We have made a LearnIT guide on how to submit a course exam assignment. See here PROJECTS OR THESES We have made a LearnIT guide on how to submit a project or thesis. See here
LearnIT Guides - how to submit
COURSE EXAM We have made a LearnIT guide on how to submit a course exam assignment. See here
PROJECTS OR THESES We have made a LearnIT guide on how to submit a project or thesis. See here
When you finally submit, please be aware that you will no longer be able to update or add to your submission.
Therefore always doublecheck that you are submitting the right version and that all the additional documents are submitted.
See below for details on how to submit and if needed read the guides provided to your left.

Course examsRemember for the front pageYou must have a front page with the following information: Course titel Course code. You can find the course code in the relevant course page in LearnIT The names of all students submitting the assignment ITU-email for all students submitting the assignment (e.g. abcd@itu.dk) Where to submitYou submit under the relevant course in LearnIT and you will receive an auto-generated confirmation receipt by email.When to submitExam assignments for courses can be submitted two weeks before the submission deadline.
Remember for the front page
You must have a front page with the following information:

Video uploadVideo files are often quite large and can take a long time uploading to learnIT or even exceed the maximum file size permitted. Therefore we advice you to compress the file before submitting. There are various tools available to reduce video size. We recommend the free and open source tool, Handbrake which works on windows, linux and macOS. To get started, please take a look at the quick start guide for Handbrake.

Projects / ThesisRemember for the front pageYou must have a front page with the following information: Project title. If it has changed since you registered send the new title in an email to sap@itu.dk STADS code. You can find the STADS code in My Study Activities. The names of all students submitting the assignment ITU-email for all students submitting the assignment (e.g. abcd@itu.dk) Where to submitYou submit under the relevant project in LearnIT and you will receive an auto-generated confirmation receipt by email. When to submitProjects can be submitted when the problem statement has been approved. What about the appendix?For projects and the thesis you have to upload the assignment and the appendix separately.Plagiarism - automatic checksPlease note that all thesis/project submissions will be automatically checked for plagiarism via Ouriginal. Ouriginal is a software that matches text overlaps between different sources. You can find more information on plagiarism here under Academic misconduct
Remember for the front page
You must have a front page with the following information:
What about the appendix?
Plagiarism - automatic checks
Please note that all thesis/project submissions will be automatically checked for plagiarism via Ouriginal.
Ouriginal is a software that matches text overlaps between different sources.
You can find more information on plagiarism here under Academic misconduct

Problems with uploading in LearnIT? If you experience a problem, on the day of your exam, while trying to upload your exam assignment in LearnIT (i.e. related to your computer or the system), we need you to  SAP (sap@itu.dk)
Please write us an e-mail and attach the exam assignment as soon as possible. In the title-field please write: Urgent - Exam related
The time issue is vital, both in terms of receiving the assignment before the actual deadline, but also as close to the deadline, if it is exceeded.

Apply for an exemption We also need you to send an actual application for exemption to be able to submit, but you can send this afterwards. You use the application for an exemption form, and you tick of the box "other". Remember to enclose documentation (i.e. a screenshot) Again in the title-field please write: Urgent - Exam related and refer to your earlier e-mail.

FAQCan I edit the project page?The information that has travelled from when you registered is not editable on the project page in LearnIT. If you need your title for the project changed you need to write to sap@itu.dk. The title in STADS is the title that will go on your diploma. This goes for the supervisor as well. If you registered with a project description and your project has changed, you are not able to update it on the project page. The problem statement though can be added and edited until the formal deadline. Afterwards you cannot edit it. Important If you and your supervisor agree, you can implement any change you want in the actual project. Your project description or problem statement will not be part of the assessment. If you have substantial changes to the problem statement, method or the like, you may want to describe them in an appendix or a summary about the project process in the finished project.Courses: File size and typesIt is up to the Course manager to decide if students are allowed to upload 1 or 5 files, in LearnIT when submitting a course assignment. All students need to check the exam activity on LearnIT for information about this. The standard is that students can upload up until 5GB and all file types are allowed. If there are any restrictions it will say so on the course description in LearnIT. Also, to make sure your files do not exceed the maximum permitted, you can compress them in a .zip file. Here is a walk-through how to do that.Projects: File size and typesFor a project the standard file size has a maximum of 100MB. The different types of files can be: .odt,.pdf,.rtf,.docx,.doc,.pptx,.ppt,.html,.htm,.sxw,.txt Besides the one file that is the project you are able to upload 5 appendices, with a maximum size of 2GB for each. Always check the exam activity in LearnIT, when in doubt. Also, to make sure your files do not exceed the maximum permitted, you can compress them in a .zip file. Here is a walk-through how to do that. You must not upload files that are protected, i.e. password protected or encrypted. Can I submit after the deadline?No, the system will close down for any uploads after the deadline. You can apply for an exemption to hand in after the deadline, but it needs to be on the basis of Special circumstances If you want to apply, you should send the application as soon as possible and attach the assignment to the email. Remember to argue why you should be exempted. Also see above, if you did not hand-in due to problems related to uploading in LearnIT. If you do not submit within the deadline or if your application for exemption is rejected, a "not attended" (udeblevet) will be registered for the exam. Can I replace a submitted assignment/project with a newer version?At first, you will upload a draft. You can edit the draft or submit it. Once you have submitted, you cannot edit your submission. You can apply for an exemption from the rule, but this will often have to be on the basis of special circumstances. Do all group members have to upload a copy?When you submit an assignment as a group, you should upload the project just once. Any member of the group can upload the project, and he or she must add the other group members in the submission window in LearnIT.Should I submit a blank sheet, if I can't submit any work?No, you shouldn't submit anything. You will get a "u" for "udeblevet" (absent). It can mistakenly be registered as a submission for the exam, if you submit a blank sheet.What if my work is confidential?When you submit in LearnIT, you can choose to make the submission "confidential" and only the examiners will be able to see it. You can ask if the oral examination can be held behind closed doors, but kindly note that it’s up to the examiners if they accommodate your requests. Please use the possibility of confidentiality with care, as important knowledge sharing will be lost if it is used too often.
Can I edit the project page?
The information that has travelled from when you registered is not editable on the project page in LearnIT.
If you need your title for the project changed you need to write to sap@itu.dk. The title in STADS is the title that will go on your diploma. This goes for the supervisor as well.

If you registered with a project description and your project has changed, you are not able to update it on the project page. The problem statement though can be added and edited until the formal deadline. Afterwards you cannot edit it. Important If you and your supervisor agree, you can implement any change you want in the actual project. Your project description or problem statement will not be part of the assessment. If you have substantial changes to the problem statement, method or the like, you may want to describe them in an appendix or a summary about the project process in the finished project.
Courses: File size and types
It is up to the Course manager to decide if students are allowed to upload 1 or 5 files, in LearnIT when submitting a course assignment.
All students need to check the exam activity on LearnIT for information about this.
The standard is that students can upload up until 5GB and all file types are allowed.
If there are any restrictions it will say so on the course description in LearnIT.
Also, to make sure your files do not exceed the maximum permitted, you can compress them in a .zip file. Here is a walk-through how to do that.
Projects: File size and types
For a project the standard file size has a maximum of 100MB.
The different types of files can be: .odt,.pdf,.rtf,.docx,.doc,.pptx,.ppt,.html,.htm,.sxw,.txt
Besides the one file that is the project you are able to upload 5 appendices, with a maximum size of 2GB for each. Always check the exam activity in LearnIT, when in doubt.
Also, to make sure your files do not exceed the maximum permitted, you can compress them in a .zip file. Here is a walk-through how to do that.
You must not upload files that are protected, i.e. password protected or encrypted.
Can I submit after the deadline?
No, the system will close down for any uploads after the deadline. You can apply for an exemption to hand in after the deadline, but it needs to be on the basis of Special circumstances
If you want to apply, you should send the application as soon as possible and attach the assignment to the email. Remember to argue why you should be exempted.
Also see above, if you did not hand-in due to problems related to uploading in LearnIT.
If you do not submit within the deadline or if your application for exemption is rejected, a "not attended" (udeblevet) will be registered for the exam.
Can I replace a submitted assignment/project with a newer version?
At first, you will upload a draft. You can edit the draft or submit it. Once you have submitted, you cannot edit your submission.
You can apply for an exemption from the rule, but this will often have to be on the basis of special circumstances.
Do all group members have to upload a copy?

When you submit an assignment as a group, you should upload the project just once. Any member of the group can upload the project, and he or she must add the other group members in the submission window in LearnIT.
Should I submit a blank sheet, if I can't submit any work?
No, you shouldn't submit anything. You will get a "u" for "udeblevet" (absent). It can mistakenly be registered as a submission for the exam, if you submit a blank sheet.
What if my work is confidential?
When you submit in LearnIT, you can choose to make the submission "confidential" and only the examiners will be able to see it.
You can ask if the oral examination can be held behind closed doors, but kindly note that it’s up to the examiners if they accommodate your requests.
Please use the possibility of confidentiality with care, as important knowledge sharing will be lost if it is used too often.

We recommend the free and open source tool, Handbrake which works on windows, linux and macOS. To get started, please take a look at the quick start guide for Handbrake. Projects / ThesisRemember for the front pageYou must have a front page with the following information: Project title. If it has changed since you registered send the new title in an email to sap@itu.dk STADS code. You can find the STADS code in My Study Activities. The names of all students submitting the assignment ITU-email for all students submitting the assignment (e.g. abcd@itu.dk) Where to submitYou submit under the relevant project in LearnIT and you will receive an auto-generated confirmation receipt by email. When to submitProjects can be submitted when the problem statement has been approved. What about the appendix?For projects and the thesis you have to upload the assignment and the appendix separately.Plagiarism - automatic checksPlease note that all thesis/project submissions will be automatically checked for plagiarism via Ouriginal. Ouriginal is a software that matches text overlaps between different sources. You can find more information on plagiarism here under Academic misconduct Remember for the front page You must have a front page with the following information: What about the appendix? Plagiarism - automatic checks Please note that all thesis/project submissions will be automatically checked for plagiarism via Ouriginal. Ouriginal is a software that matches text overlaps between different sources. You can find more information on plagiarism here under Academic misconduct Problems with uploading in LearnIT? If you experience a problem, on the day of your exam, while trying to upload your exam assignment in LearnIT (i.e. related to your computer or the system), we need you to SAP (sap@itu.dk) Please write us an e-mail and attach the exam assignment as soon as possible. In the title-field please write: Urgent - Exam related The time issue is vital, both in terms of receiving the assignment before the actual deadline, but also as close to the deadline, if it is exceeded. Apply for an exemption We also need you to send an actual application for exemption to be able to submit, but you can send this afterwards. You use the application for an exemption form, and you tick of the box "other". Remember to enclose documentation (i.e. a screenshot) Again in the title-field please write: Urgent - Exam related and refer to your earlier e-mail. FAQCan I edit the project page?The information that has travelled from when you registered is not editable on the project page in LearnIT. If you need your title for the project changed you need to write to sap@itu.dk. The title in STADS is the title that will go on your diploma. This goes for the supervisor as well. If you registered with a project description and your project has changed, you are not able to update it on the project page. The problem statement though can be added and edited until the formal deadline. Afterwards you cannot edit it. Important If you and your supervisor agree, you can implement any change you want in the actual project. Your project description or problem statement will not be part of the assessment. If you have substantial changes to the problem statement, method or the like, you may want to describe them in an appendix or a summary about the project process in the finished project.Courses: File size and typesIt is up to the Course manager to decide if students are allowed to upload 1 or 5 files, in LearnIT when submitting a course assignment. All students need to check the exam activity on LearnIT for information about this. The standard is that students can upload up until 5GB and all file types are allowed. If there are any restrictions it will say so on the course description in LearnIT. Also, to make sure your files do not exceed the maximum permitted, you can compress them in a .zip file. Here is a walk-through how to do that.Projects: File size and typesFor a project the standard file size has a maximum of 100MB. The different types of files can be: .odt,.pdf,.rtf,.docx,.doc,.pptx,.ppt,.html,.htm,.sxw,.txt Besides the one file that is the project you are able to upload 5 appendices, with a maximum size of 2GB for each. Always check the exam activity in LearnIT, when in doubt. Also, to make sure your files do not exceed the maximum permitted, you can compress them in a .zip file. Here is a walk-through how to do that. You must not upload files that are protected, i.e. password protected or encrypted. Can I submit after the deadline?No, the system will close down for any uploads after the deadline. You can apply for an exemption to hand in after the deadline, but it needs to be on the basis of Special circumstances If you want to apply, you should send the application as soon as possible and attach the assignment to the email. Remember to argue why you should be exempted. Also see above, if you did not hand-in due to problems related to uploading in LearnIT. If you do not submit within the deadline or if your application for exemption is rejected, a "not attended" (udeblevet) will be registered for the exam. Can I replace a submitted assignment/project with a newer version?At first, you will upload a draft. You can edit the draft or submit it. Once you have submitted, you cannot edit your submission. You can apply for an exemption from the rule, but this will often have to be on the basis of special circumstances. Do all group members have to upload a copy?When you submit an assignment as a group, you should upload the project just once. Any member of the group can upload the project, and he or she must add the other group members in the submission window in LearnIT.Should I submit a blank sheet, if I can't submit any work?No, you shouldn't submit anything. You will get a "u" for "udeblevet" (absent). It can mistakenly be registered as a submission for the exam, if you submit a blank sheet.What if my work is confidential?When you submit in LearnIT, you can choose to make the submission "confidential" and only the examiners will be able to see it. You can ask if the oral examination can be held behind closed doors, but kindly note that it’s up to the examiners if they accommodate your requests. Please use the possibility of confidentiality with care, as important knowledge sharing will be lost if it is used too often. Can I edit the project page? title: Study Abroad
paragraphs: The IT University hosts an ExploreIT event every fall semester in November, and Open office sessions in the end of every semester and close to the fall semester start.
Exchange Student (at partner universities)

Studying can be expensive, but it does not need to be. If you apply for one of our partner universities, no tuition fee is required (unless otherwise stated). This is often not the case if you choose to study abroad without an agreement. In either case, you will have to cover travel expenses, housing, visa, insurance and living expenses yourself.
Fortunately, there are several possibilities for financial support
Lemvigh Müeller Foundation
After returning from your stay abroad, you need to fill out a travel report and send it to sap@itu.dk. Find the templates under: Practicalities - after
We use the Travel reports as evaluation and inspiration for other students. It is mandatory to fill out the Travel report.
Find the Travel reports for Exchange students, Freemovers, Summer school and other activities here.

title: Guidance and Help
paragraphs: Remember to ask for help, so you can get back on track as soon as possible.

First of all, you should try to talk to your supervisor about your worries. You can also  the Head of your programme or The Study and Career Guidance. If it is not possible to solve the conflict, you will have the opportunity to apply for another supervisor.

You might choose to involve your supervisor or The Study and Career Guidance who has experience with group conflicts. In extremely complicated situations, it is possible to withdraw from the group and continuing alone.

The Study and Career Guidance can help you handle many of the challenges that are normal during a project period. It is also possible to receive help if you are experiencing a serious illness or death in your family.
The Study and Career Guidance.
The Student Counselling offers free counseling and treatment to students attending Universities and University Colleges in Denmark.

The counsellors are psychologists, psychiatrists and social workers with psycho-therapeutic educations. All counsellors have a wide theoretic knowledge and many years of experience with students on their way through their student life. The counsellors are pledge to professional confidentiality.
the Student Counselling Service

title: Here to help

headings.text: Where to turn if you experience an incident that makes you feel unsafe
What to do and what to expect
1. Reach out to The Study and Career Guidance
3. The process of exploring an enquiry at ITU

paragraphs: At ITU we value a welcoming, inclusive, and respectful environment for all. We believe that all students and staff should contribute to creating and maintaining our shared environment by acting in ways that include, invite, and respect others. No one should behave in a way that offends, is intimidating or hostile, degrading, or humiliating to others. This applies to all activities at the ITU campus, in any related digital spaces, as well as ITU related social functions regardless of their location.
If you experience or observe offensive, discriminatory, sexist, or other behaviour that makes you feel unsafe or uncomfortable while being a student at ITU we are here to help you!
We handle all questions or enquiries with great concern.
Find out below where to turn for help and guidance and what you might expect in the process.
Reach out to the Study and Career Guidance
Nothing is too big or too small to come talk to us about!
Confidential conversation
We support and guide you no matter whether you decide not to pursue the issue any further or you allow for ITU to investigate further.
Exploring your enquiry
The incident will be investigated in-depth and Head of SAP, Lene Rehder, will be involved to help lead the further process.
Outcomes or sanctions
The concrete outcomes, consequences, or possible sanctions always relate to the severity of the case and the specific situation.

The Study- & Career Guidance is trained to handle challenging, diverse and sensitive topics. Offensive behaviour may be difficult to talk about, but please reach out even if you are in doubt about what you may have experienced.
Nothing is too big or too small to talk to us about! We offer initial and clarifying conversations that take place anonymously and are completely confidential.
Write to studentadvisors@itu.dk or  us by phone or in person. Students may choose to  the Head of Student Affairs & Programmes, Lene Rehder (lenr@itu.dk or +45 5164 3718), directly if they so prefer.
In the first clarifying and confidential conversation with a Student advisor, we may talk about what the next relevant steps should be.
If you find it helpful you are always welcome to bring a companion, friend, or family to join the meeting/conversation. It is important that you feel as safe and confident as possible.

We support and guide you no matter whether you decide to allow for ITU to investigate the enquiry more in depth – or if you choose not to pursue the issue any further (and the matter will remain fully confidential).

If we are to help and follow up by undertaking relevant measures as well as preventing similar incidents, in most cases we need to investigate the incident in-depth based on your experience. This means that Head of SAP, Lene Rehder, will be involved to help lead the further process.

Depending on the situation, this may involve dialogue with the involved parties. We strive to match and balance your needs at every step in the process, but at this stage it may not always be possible to remain fully anonymous.
Our values are based on policies and the work of committees. They are here to help ensure a diverse and inclusive work and study environment at ITU
As an ongoing initiative The Committee for Diversity and Inclusion have been established as well.
You can read about the policies and committees in detail by hitting the link

title: Oral Exam

headings.text: Structure and content of oral exams for group projects
Structure and content of oral exams in an individual project

paragraphs: Oral exam - online or at ITUYou have to decide and agree with your supervisor if you want your oral exam to be conducted online or physically at ITU. Have the talk with your supervisor in the start-up fase of your project. Please see here for details about the online oral examThe oral exam will be held no later than 4 weeks after the submission deadline. LearnIT will be updated with the exact time and place of the oral exam.
Oral exam - online or at ITU
You have to decide and agree with your supervisor if you want your oral exam to be conducted online or physically at ITU.
Have the talk with your supervisor in the start-up fase of your project.
Please see here for details about the online oral exam
On the day of the exam, make sure that you arrive in due time before the exam.
Projects Oral exams following ordinary projects last around 40 minutes per student, including the examiners’ voting and feedback to you. This also applies to the bachelor project.
The Master thesis The oral exam for the master thesis last around 50 minutes per student, including the examiners’ voting and feedback.

RememberIt is your responsibility to check which aids are provided and allowed at the exam and in the exam preparation room.Your graduation date is the day your examiners date the exam protocol, which is often on the same day as the oral exam. Read more about graduation and the diploma.

Formal requirements Apart from the length of the exam, there are no formal requirements to the structure and content of the oral exam. You should always turn to your supervisor / the examiner, to find out which elements the exam will consist of and what will be expected of you.

Structure and content of oral exams for group projectsThe oral group exam in a group project must be conducted in one the five ways described in this document. This is to ensure that it is possible to give each student an individual assessment. The group must choose between one of the five possibilities and let the supervisor know. The group shares the responsibility for the exam assignment.

The oral group exam in a group project must be conducted in one the five ways described in this document. This is to ensure that it is possible to give each student an individual assessment. The group must choose between one of the five possibilities and let the supervisor know.
The group shares the responsibility for the exam assignment.

Structure and content of oral exams in an individual projectApart from the length of the exam, there are no formal requirements to the structure and content of oral exams for individual projects. You should always talk to the examiner, so that you know which elements the exam will consist of and what will be expected of you. See also the time and date of your exams in TimeEdit.

Apart from the length of the exam, there are no formal requirements to the structure and content of oral exams for individual projects. You should always talk to the examiner, so that you know which elements the exam will consist of and what will be expected of you.
See also the time and date of your exams in TimeEdit.

Oral examinations are public, but the Board of Studies at ITU has decided that examinations will take place behind closed doors on the examinee’s request. Moreover, the Board of Studies may in particular cases decide that an examination is not public, and specify who may be present during the examination. Only the internal and external examiners may be present during the evaluation. The Board of Studies may, however, decide that future examiners may be present at the evaluation as well. Students are not allowed to do any kind of auditory or visual recording during the exam.

title: Handling your Complaint

headings.text: Complaint concerning the examination, the conduct of the examination or the grade

paragraphs: There are two different processes for handling your exam complaint. One has to do with the actual examination and is therefore presented to the assessors. The other is in relation to legal matters, where the IT University will make the ruling.

The procedureThe external examiner is obliged to take notes on the examination performance and grading procedure during the evaluation process, and he is obliged to keep these notes on file for one year. The IT University will send the assessors' statements to you, and you will have one week to comment on it. After having received your comments on the statement, the IT University will present the case to the head of programme. You will get one week to comment on this too, after which SAP will a make a ruling on the complaint. If your complaint concerns the basis for the examination, the conduction of the examination, or the grade awarded, your complaint will be presented to the assessors (the examiner and the external examiner).
The external examiner is obliged to take notes on the examination performance and grading procedure during the evaluation process, and he is obliged to keep these notes on file for one year.
The IT University will send the assessors' statements to you, and you will have one week to comment on it.
After having received your comments on the statement, the IT University will present the case to the head of programme.
You will get one week to comment on this too, after which SAP will a make a ruling on the complaint.
Usually the assessors will be given two weeks, but in some cases it might take longer. Please note that it is not possible to hand in a complaint anonymously.

If you wish to accept an offer of a re-assessment or re-examination, you must do so no later than two weeks after the ruling. If you accept the offer of re-examination, it will not count as a new examination attempt.
The re-assessment or re-examination will always be carried out by new assessors, and might result in the same or a lower grade. You can not file a complaint regarding this new grade."
You can appeal the IT University's ruling within two weeks of receiving the ruling. The appeal, like the original complaint, must be written, substantiated and sent to sap@itu.dk.
The IT University will then appoint a Board of Appeals. The Board of Appeals consists of two external examiners, a teacher and a student.
The Board of Appeals’ ruling can be:
The Board of Appeals will make a ruling on the basis of your arguments and that of the assessors. The IT University will inform you of The Board of Appeals’ decision.

The board has two months to process the appeal; July is never counted as one of the two months. If this time limit cannot be met, the IT University is obliged to inform you of the reasons for the delay, and of when you can expect a ruling. It is not unusual for the appeal case to take some time. You may continue your studies while the appeal is being processed.

The decision of the Board of Appeals is final. If you find that the ruling of the assessors or the Board of Appeals is insufficiently substantiated, or that errors in the legal matters have occurred, you may make a complaint to Student Affairs and Programmes at the IT University.
The university must have received the complaint no later than 2 weeks after you have received the ruling of the Board of Appeals.

The procedureWithin two weeks of receiving the ruling, you can submit your appeal to Student Affairs and Programmes. Based on this, the IT University will make a statement on your complaint allowing you to make your comments within one week. The IT University will then submit your complaint, the statement and any comments made to the Danish Agency for Science and Higher Education.Complaints concerning legal matters in relation to exams, e.g. formal errors in connection with the examination, or conflict of interests, require a separate procedure.
Within two weeks of receiving the ruling, you can submit your appeal to Student Affairs and Programmes.
Based on this, the IT University will make a statement on your complaint allowing you to make your comments within one week.
The IT University will then submit your complaint, the statement and any comments made to the Danish Agency for Science and Higher Education.
In such cases, it is the IT University that makes the ruling.
You can appeal the ruling of the IT University to the Danish Agency for Science and Higher Education.
See to your left for the procedure.

Please note that it is not possible to hand in a complaint anonymously. If you wish to accept an offer of a re-assessment or re-examination, you must do so no later than two weeks after the ruling. If you accept the offer of re-examination, it will not count as a new examination attempt. The re-assessment or re-examination will always be carried out by new assessors, and might result in the same or a lower grade. You can not file a complaint regarding this new grade." You can appeal the IT University's ruling within two weeks of receiving the ruling. The appeal, like the original complaint, must be written, substantiated and sent to sap@itu.dk. The IT University will then appoint a Board of Appeals. The Board of Appeals consists of two external examiners, a teacher and a student. The Board of Appeals’ ruling can be: The Board of Appeals will make a ruling on the basis of your arguments and that of the assessors. The IT University will inform you of The Board of Appeals’ decision. The board has two months to process the appeal; July is never counted as one of the two months. If this time limit cannot be met, the IT University is obliged to inform you of the reasons for the delay, and of when you can expect a ruling. It is not unusual for the appeal case to take some time. You may continue your studies while the appeal is being processed. The decision of the Board of Appeals is final. If you find that the ruling of the assessors or the Board of Appeals is insufficiently substantiated, or that errors in the legal matters have occurred, you may make a complaint to Student Affairs and Programmes at the IT University. The university must have received the complaint no later than 2 weeks after you have received the ruling of the Board of Appeals. The procedureWithin two weeks of receiving the ruling, you can submit your appeal to Student Affairs and Programmes. Based on this, the IT University will make a statement on your complaint allowing you to make your comments within one week. The IT University will then submit your complaint, the statement and any comments made to the Danish Agency for Science and Higher Education.Complaints concerning legal matters in relation to exams, e.g. formal errors in connection with the examination, or conflict of interests, require a separate procedure. Within two weeks of receiving the ruling, you can submit your appeal to Student Affairs and Programmes. Based on this, the IT University will make a statement on your complaint allowing you to make your comments within one week. The IT University will then submit your complaint, the statement and any comments made to the Danish Agency for Science and Higher Education. In such cases, it is the IT University that makes the ruling. You can appeal the ruling of the IT University to the Danish Agency for Science and Higher Education. See to your left for the procedure.

title: ITU Student
paragraphs: We want you to thrive

ITU wish to sustain a good study environment, where you and your fellow students thrive both academically, personally and socially. You can help us ensure the best settings for your education by participating in The Danish Student Survey. Find the survey in your ITU-mail Take the time to share your thoughts and insights. The survey is open until 26 November. It matters, we assure you.
Spring 2026 - when and what to register for

The weekly schedules and the exam dates for Spring 2026 are accessible in TimeEdit! The registration period for the next semester and Summer University is December 1 - December 10.In LearnIT you can find the courses approved for your study programme, by setting the filters to Spring 2026 and Elective to / click on your own study programme. Follow the link for all important details.
The online course evaluation survey is live

And yes, it’s another survey, but it’s different from the one mentioned on the left. This time we kindly ask you to evaluate the specific courses you attend this semester. Your responses are used by teachers and management to improve each course. Your answers are anonymous. Access the surveys (one for each course) from your course pages in LearnIT until 5 December. Thank you, Student Affairs and Programmes
Read the Latest Version of readIT

title: After you return
paragraphs: After you finish your exchange you must

You are responsible the final transfer of course credits to your ITU degree. You do this by emailing us a transcript of records for the courses you have completed. Please do this as soon as possible upon return from the host university.
Some universities may send the transcript directly to ITU, and if so, we will ask you to come by and get your original transcript.
All grades obtained abroad are transferred to your degree certificate as passed. However, you will get a separate certificate from your host university showing your results in their grade scale.

Upon your return, you are required to write a travel report about your experiences abroad. This will enable other students to make use of and be inspired by your experiences. Note that the travel report will be uploaded to ITUstudent so consider leaving out sensitive data. See a list of travel reports here.
Template for travel report.

title: the Study and Career Guidance

headings.text: You can receive guidance when you need it

paragraphs: We are here to guide you through your studies. We offer guidance in many different subjects related to your studies and your future career. It’s normal to have the need to talk to somebody. Talk to us about:
We also host several different events and workshops, for instance about exam- and study techniques. Check our events here and sign up
Phone: You are very welcome to give us a call every weekday from 10.00 - 11.00, except Thursday. Call: +45 7218 5440

Drop-in You are also welcome to drop by our office. The drop-in guidance can take up to 15 minutes and is typically guidance regarding small matters and practical questions. We are open on weekdays from 12.00 - 14. 00 at ITU in room 2A40, except Thursday.
Email: Write to studentadvisors@itu.dk. We answer e-mails every day, and we aim to answer your email within 5 workdays. If you are a student at ITU, please use your ITU-email when you write to us.

Book a meeting: All students at ITU can book a meeting at ITU or online via Zoom. The booked meeting can take up to 30 minutes and is aimed for complex challenges where you need the time to talk to an advisor.
The subject for your booked meeting could be study planning after illness, wellbeing and motivation or your future career.
Zoom works best in the browsers Chrome or Microsoft edge. You will receive a zoomlink in the confirmation on your booking, if you have booked an online meeting.
13-17 October Autumn break
In the Study and Career guidance at ITU our advisors are well-educated in giving guidance and we have professional secrecy.
The student advisors are here to help you, and you can talk to us about your wellbeing at the University or get guidance on where to go if we are not the right ones to help you.

title: Study Abroad
paragraphs: The IT University hosts an ExploreIT event every fall semester in November, and Open office sessions in the end of every semester and close to the fall semester start.
Exchange Student (at partner universities)

Studying can be expensive, but it does not need to be. If you apply for one of our partner universities, no tuition fee is required (unless otherwise stated). This is often not the case if you choose to study abroad without an agreement. In either case, you will have to cover travel expenses, housing, visa, insurance and living expenses yourself.
Fortunately, there are several possibilities for financial support
Lemvigh Müeller Foundation
After returning from your stay abroad, you need to fill out a travel report and send it to sap@itu.dk. Find the templates under: Practicalities - after
We use the Travel reports as evaluation and inspiration for other students. It is mandatory to fill out the Travel report.
Find the Travel reports for Exchange students, Freemovers, Summer school and other activities here.

title: Online oral exam

headings.text: This applies to all online oral exams:

paragraphs: The general rulesSee information about the oral exam here and also if needed have a look at the Appendix to the curriculaITU trusts that both students and teachers at ITU do what they can to maintain the integrity of online oral exams. The purpose of this page is to answer as many questions as possible upfront, so that you can focus on the actual exam.

Before the examPreparation for online examThis is a recommended minimum list to aid you prepare the exam. Technical Install Zoom on your computer Use an external microphone if you have one. They are usually better than built-in ones Ensure in advance that you have working web camera, microphone and internet connection Invite a fellow student to test equipment including speaker, microphone and setup with you in good time Install the latest Zoom app on a mobile device with data subscription in case of technical issues and weak or unstable connections Practical Practice your exam in Zoom to be familiar with the environment Arrange in advance how you will handle writing/drawing during the exam if needed. Get inspiration and useful advice on annotation with Zoom, whiteboard in zoom, sharing ipad screen for drawing in Zoom from these video tutorials regarding Zoom Place yourself so you have a balanced backlight so others can see you better. Avoid sunlight from the sides and back. Group exams Unless your teacher decides otherwise and communicates this at the latest 7 days before the group exam, students attending a group exam are allowed to be in the same room during the exam. The ITU recommendation is that students who are in the same room during a group exam log onto Zoom individually using their own device and mute their microphone when they do not speak in order to avoid feedback loop Security - online oral examsAll online oral exams take place on Zoom. IT security guidelines must be adhered to. ITU uses the licenced Zoom version provided by the Danish e-Infrastructure Cooperation (DeiC) which meets ITUs security requirements.Zoom tutorialsZoom tutorials Find all the tutorials regarding the below here in ITU Media Install Zoom Client and join a meeting Test speaker and microphone before a meeting in Zoom Test speaker and microphone during a meeting in Zoom Add Zoom Virtual Background Share screen, share window, share part of screen Presenting a powerpoint in Zoom without having a full screen blocking your view and notes Whiteboard in Zoom Annotate on Screen with Zoom Zoom push-to-talk The Push to Talkfeature allows you to remain muted throughout your Zoom meeting and hold down the spacebar when you want to be unmuted and talk. Android tutorials Install Zoom and  on Android Join Zoom meeting on Android Ipad tutorials Use Ipad as Whiteboard Zoom Which information will my teacher provide before the exam?At least 7 days before the exam, your teacher will via LearnIT provide you with the exact time, link to the meeting in Zoom and other relevant information
Preparation for online exam
Security - online oral exams
All online oral exams take place on Zoom. IT security guidelines must be adhered to.
ITU uses the licenced Zoom version provided by the Danish e-Infrastructure Cooperation (DeiC) which meets ITUs security requirements.
Find all the tutorials regarding the below here in ITU Media
Which information will my teacher provide before the exam?
At least 7 days before the exam, your teacher will via LearnIT provide you with the exact time, link to the meeting in Zoom and other relevant information

During the examGuidelinesThese guidelines were approved by Board of Studies 5 May 2020: Students and examiners must have the camera on during the entire examination (except when sharing screen as this setting does not allow using the camera at the same time) in order to make the online exam as close as possible to ordinary face-to-face exams. Having the camera permanently on also is a measure for the examiners to evaluate if students are cheating. Examiner starts the exam and goes through how the meeting will proceed. The identity of the student must be established. If asked by the examiners, student must show student card. ITU trusts that students adhere to the exam rules and that students do not receive any help during the exam. If asked by the examiners, student must show the room they are located in. The student can display a background picture to maintain privacy. E.g. this one of ITU. During presentation it is recommended that non-speakers microphones are unmuted. The examiner ends the exam when the time has expired and makes sure that students are not attending the voting. If any unforeseen incidents happen, it is a good idea to describe and document what happened. According to the Examination Order, audio or video recording of an exam is not allowed unless the recordings are part of the examination. In such cases, the University undertakes the recording. The recording must thus not take place if the sole aim is to use the recording in the case of an exam complaint or to reveal cheating. How to make the online conversation run smoothly Speak as clearly as possible Wait a little bit longer for people to finish sentences so you don't risk interrupting them Acknowledge what other people are saying with nods, not confirming sounds or words as the risk disturbing the speaker Raise your hand so others can see you want to say something Consider using Zoom's push-to-talk function to avoid broadcasting unintended noise. The Push to Talk feature allows you to remain muted throughout your Zoom meeting and hold down the spacebar when you want to be unmuted and talk Join the Zoom meeting Log on to the Zoom meeting using the link provided in LearnIT by your teacher/supervisor If you have technical issues, use the Zoom app on your mobile phone to join the meeting If the Zoom app on your phone does not work either, you can call the meeting via phone using the Zoom Dial-in number provided by your teacher/supervisor The exam itself Once joining the meeting, you will be automatically placed in a waiting room. To access the examination room, you will be invited in by the examiner You say your name and authenticate yourself. If asked by the examiners, you must show student ID card Depending on the exam there will be a method for drawing of exam question - not relevant for all exams You present Your teacher and the external examiner ask questions For answers requiring different tools to e.g., write code, draw a diagram, etc.: Share your screen (see tutorial) Use the shared whiteboard in Zoom With regards to writing code, you will be allowed to use the Integrated Development Environment of your choice With regards to drawing diagrams, you will be allowed to use the tool of your choice as long as this does not become a reason for delays. In case of delays or if you prefer, you will be allowed to draw diagrams on a sheet of paper that is afterwards shown to the camera Once the exam is completed, the examiner will place you in a Zoom breakout room Stay online and await in another Zoom breakout room while your teacher and external examiner discuss your performance The examiner invites you back into the exam breakout room for the result Group exams Like it is the case for face-to-face exams, students can ask to get their grade without the presence of the fellow students.What happens if there a technical issues? If the internet connection or camera fail: Install the Zoom app on your phone before the exam so you can move to a mobile device if needs be. Call the meeting via phone using the Zoom Dial-in number provided by your teacher/supervisor If you have problems with your WIFI connection: Use cable instead Place yourself close to the router Turn off other devices that use the router (streaming of film, music, etc.) It can be a solution to log on from two devices. Remember to move both devices between the Zoom breakout rooms. Also remember to mute one device (otherwise potential doom of feedback loop). No video - only audio If you experience issues with video but is still available to attend with audio, the examiners assess whether there is a risk of cheating or if the exam can be carried through with only audio. If one of the examiners experiences issues with video, the exam is carried through, unless the examiner depends on video to pursue the examination. Extension of exam If the duration of the interruption caused by technical problems corresponds to less than 1/5 of the exam, the examiner adds the time spent re-establishing communications to the exam.
These guidelines were approved by Board of Studies 5 May 2020:
How to make the online conversation run smoothly
Join the Zoom meeting
Once joining the meeting, you will be automatically placed in a waiting room. To access the examination room, you will be invited in by the examiner
You say your name and authenticate yourself. If asked by the examiners, you must show student ID card
Depending on the exam there will be a method for drawing of exam question - not relevant for all exams
Your teacher and the external examiner ask questions
For answers requiring different tools to e.g., write code, draw a diagram, etc.:
Share your screen (see tutorial)
Use the shared whiteboard in Zoom
With regards to writing code, you will be allowed to use the Integrated Development Environment of your choice

With regards to drawing diagrams, you will be allowed to use the tool of your choice as long as this does not become a reason for delays. In case of delays or if you prefer, you will be allowed to draw diagrams on a sheet of paper that is afterwards shown to the camera
Once the exam is completed, the examiner will place you in a Zoom breakout room
Stay online and await in another Zoom breakout room while your teacher and external examiner discuss your performance
The examiner invites you back into the exam breakout room for the result
Like it is the case for face-to-face exams, students can ask to get their grade without the presence of the fellow students.
What happens if there a technical issues?
If the duration of the interruption caused by technical problems corresponds to less than 1/5 of the exam, the examiner adds the time spent re-establishing communications to the exam.

Reschedule or exemption of exam due to technical issuesWhat happens?The exam is stopped and rescheduled for as soon as possible, if the examiners cannot soundly asses your performance e.g. due to broken, weak or unstable equipment or internet connection. The examiners decide if an exam should be rescheduled, but you can off course voice an opinion. The general recommendation is that an exam is rescheduled If it happens within the first 2/3 of the exam If the exam cannot be rectified within a duration corresponding to 1/5 of the exam duration. Group exams?What happens if one student in a group exam is disconnected and cannot reconnect to the meeting within a duration corresponding to 1/5 of the exam duration? The exam is completed for the remaining students. The exam is rescheduled for the student not able to connect If the exam is stopped, the examiner arranges a new time to resume the exam, preferably on the same day.Does it count as an exam attempt?A rescheduled exam due to technical issues does not count as an exam attempt. However, if the examiners assess that you deliberately tried to avoid attending the exam, the exam will be registered as an exam attempt. If - despite the interruption due to technical issues - the examiners are able to soundly assess your performance within the first 2/3 of the exam, the exam is concluded and counts as an exam attempt. This means that the exam and the grade may stand.Extension of examIf the duration of the interruption caused by technical problems corresponds to less than 1/5 of the exam, the examiner adds the time spent re-establishing communications to the exam.
Reschedule or exemption of exam due to technical issues
The exam is stopped and rescheduled for as soon as possible, if the examiners cannot soundly asses your performance e.g. due to broken, weak or unstable equipment or internet connection.
The examiners decide if an exam should be rescheduled, but you can off course voice an opinion.
The general recommendation is that an exam is rescheduled
What happens if one student in a group exam is disconnected and cannot reconnect to the meeting within a duration corresponding to 1/5 of the exam duration?
If the exam is stopped, the examiner arranges a new time to resume the exam, preferably on the same day.
Does it count as an exam attempt?
This page was last updated January 11 2023
