There are the following collegiate bodies at the IT University.
Read more about the collegiate bodies here.
Below you can find the rules for the election:
Election circular 2025
Articles of Association of the ITU

Every year representatives among students and staff are elected for the collegiate bodies at the IT University such as the Board of Directors, the Board of Studies ITU and the Subject Area Teams. Bodies, which make sure that everyone at the university is heard – both students and staff.
This year's election will be called for these collegiate bodies:
For students, the term of office is one year starting from January 1, 2025. For students elected to the Board of Directors, however, the term of office is two years.
Please read how ITU process your personal data in relation to the election here.In case you have any questions regarding the election, please e-mail the Election Committee on electioncommittee@itu.dk
The Election Committee

title: Study Abroad
paragraphs: The IT University hosts an ExploreIT event every fall semester in November, and Open office sessions in the end of every semester and close to the fall semester start.
Exchange Student (at partner universities)

Studying can be expensive, but it does not need to be. If you apply for one of our partner universities, no tuition fee is required (unless otherwise stated). This is often not the case if you choose to study abroad without an agreement. In either case, you will have to cover travel expenses, housing, visa, insurance and living expenses yourself.
Fortunately, there are several possibilities for financial support
Lemvigh Müeller Foundation
After returning from your stay abroad, you need to fill out a travel report and send it to sap@itu.dk. Find the templates under: Practicalities - after
We use the Travel reports as evaluation and inspiration for other students. It is mandatory to fill out the Travel report.
Find the Travel reports for Exchange students, Freemovers, Summer school and other activities here.

title: Exams and re-exams
paragraphs: The exam-plan for Summer University is as follows: 1. attempt: Week 32 2. attempt: Week 34 3. attempt: When the course is offered again. Be aware that you need to sign up for the course again.

title: Specialisations
paragraphs: During the course of your programme, you have to choose and pass a specialisation. This gives you a more distinctive profile and it is an opportunity to point your academic profile in the direction you wish to go after graduation.

Putting a specialisation together You can choose one of the specialisation packages in the drop down below, or you can put together your own specialisation package by mixing from the pool of DIM specialisation courses.
See for general information about Specialisations and how to register.
A specialisation must amount to a total of 22,5 ECTS and consist of different specalisation modules placed on your 2nd and 3rd semester.
Spring Big Data Processes (7,5 ECTS) New course title for Spring 2026: AI processes Autumn Managing Business Analytics and Data-Driven Decision-Making (15 ECTS)
This specialisation presupposes that you are learning or have previously learned basic programming.
About the specialisation Read about the specialisation here
Spring Introduction to Service Design and Management* (7,5 ECTS) New course title for Spring 2026: Making Sense of Service Systems
Autumn Service Design - Management and Implementation (15 ECTS) New course title for Spring 2026: Managing Service Strategy and Innovation
About the specialisation Read about the specialisation here
Spring The Digital State (7,5 ECTS)
Autumn The Digital State in Practice (15 ECTS)
About the specialisation Read about the specialisation here
See the courses listed here
Spring Big Data Processes* (7,5 ECTS) Introduction to Service Design and Management* (7,5 ECTS) The Digital State (7,5 ECTS)
Autumn Managing Business Analytics and Data-Driven Decision-Making (15 ECTS) Service Design - Management and Implementation (15 ECTS) The Digital State in Practice (15 ECTS)
*New course title for Spring 2026
If you are set on other courses that are not offered in the pool of DIM specialisation courses you can apply for an individual specialisation.

An individual specialisation must meet the same official requirements as the specialisation packages. As the specialisation normally leads up to the thesis, you need to ensure a progression within the individual specialisation.
See here for how to apply for an individual specialisation.

title: When should I use Generative AI?

headings.text: When should I use Generative AI?

paragraphs: Generative AI can be a great tool for many study-related activities. But before you start using generative AI for a specific task, you should always consider if it is appropriate. We have compiled a few points that you might consider before using generative AI:

Am I allowed to use generative AI for this activity as per the ITU guidelines on generative AI? Am I allowed to use generative AI for this particular course as stated in the course description? Does the use of generative AI serve a purpose in relation to my own learning, or will it prevent me from learning valuable new skills? Is generative AI the best tool available for this task? Does the data I am working with contain personal, sensitive, or ed information?
If you are unsure of whether to use generative AI or not, you should always consult your teacher or your supervisor.

The environmental impact An important point to keep in mind is the environmental impact of generative AI, which is significantly higher than many alternative technologies. Some studies suggest that a single prompt might be equivalent to charging your phone from 0% to 100% as much as 40 times. Therefore, you should carefully consider each prompt. Maybe you could use another tool? Or maybe this is a chance for you to be creative on your own? Depending on your needs, a regular  engine might be better. For example, if you are looking up the meaning of a word, ITU provides free access to Ordbogen.com, where you can find reliable dictionary definitions.

links.text: What can I use generative AI for?
Ensure academic integrity when using generative AI

Some studies suggest that a single prompt might be equivalent to charging your phone from 0% to 100% as much as 40 times. Therefore, you should carefully consider each prompt. title: Special Circumstances
paragraphs: If you find yourself in a situation where you cannot study as a full-time student you can apply for an exemption from the rules you are subject to when studying a higher education programme at ITU. This can also be relevant if due to special circumstances you need a fourth exam attempt, you cannot meet the requirements for progression etc. Read more about Exemptions
Read more about How to apply
Special pedagogical support (SPS) is a support offered for students with a physical or mental disability, to help them in their university studies.

title: Especially about the Bachelor Project

headings.text: When to write the bachelor project

paragraphs: The bachelor project is a 15 ECTS project that concludes your BSc programme. It is an independent project defined by you in collaboration with your supervisor.

Need inspiration or support?You can always check out the pages under The Study and Career Guidance for tips and advice. Follow this link for guidance on starting up a Project / ThesisThe bachelor project is a written submission with an oral exam (40 minutes per student incl. voting and feedback). The bachelor project is legally founded in the programme Curriculum (‘Studieordning’). Find your Curriculum under Your Programme. Otherwise, the bachelor project follows the general rules that apply when writing a project. For information on this, please read about Project work here. Below, you can find more information about what is specific to the bachelor project.
Need inspiration or support?
You can always check out the pages under The Study and Career Guidance for tips and advice.
Follow this link for guidance on starting up a Project / Thesis
Normally, you write your bachelor project on your 6th semester, as you can see in the contents of your programme overview.

Working in a groupYou can write the bachelor project alone or in group of up to 5 students. Learn more about working in groups.In certain cases - e.g. if you have not been able to pass 30 ECTS each semester - you might have to consider writing the project in another semester. However, you must have passed 120 ECTS before you can register for the bachelor project.
You can write the bachelor project alone or in group of up to 5 students.
Learn more about working in groups.

Keep an eye out for workshops to help you get started on the bachelor project run by the Study and Career Guidance or your study programme. They often take place early in the semester before you write the bachelor project. Check also your study programme specific pages.
See the Submission deadlines for a Bachelor project by following this link.

title: The oral exam

headings.text: Structure, length and content of the oral exam

paragraphs: Online oral examIf necessary and agreed upon with your Course manager/examiner you can attend your oral exam online via zoom. Please see here for detailsOn the day of the exam, make sure that you arrive in due time before the exam.
If necessary and agreed upon with your Course manager/examiner you can attend your oral exam online via zoom.
Please see here for details
It is also your responsibility to check which aids are provided and allowed at the exam and in the exam preparation room.

You can see in the course catalogue how the oral exam for your course is conducted. If you have questions about the exam, you should  the course manager, so that you know which elements the exam will consist of, and what is expected of you.

No recordingStudents are not allowed to do any kind of auditory or visual recording during the exam.If you are attending a group exam, the specific option used for that particular exam will be described in the course catalogue.
You can find a description of the five different exam forms here. See also the time and date of your exams in TimeEdit.

Oral exams are publicOral examinations are public, but the Board of Studies at ITU have decided that examinations will take place behind closed doors on the examinee’s request. Moreover, the Board of Studies may decide in particular cases that an examination is not public, and specify who may be present during the examination. Only the internal and external examiners may be present during the voting. The Board of Studies may, however, decide that future examiners may be present at the voting as well.

title: Exam Complaints

headings.text: What are the possible outcomes of a complaint?

paragraphs: Exam complaints do not include teaching, supervision, or other factors that are not part of the actual exam.
If you wish to complain about these matters, you should submit a separate complaint. Read more about complaining about teaching or supervision.
Examination complaints can be about the following issues:
If we decide in favour of you, we can either offer a new assessment of the exam that you have done or we can offer you a new examination.
If the exam was an oral exam, we will always offer you a new examination.

Read more about what happens after you have complained. How to applyIf you do not agree with the assessment at an exam, we recommend that you start by ing your examiner and discuss the reasons for your grade or assessment before making an official complaint. Many students understand the assessment better once they have spoken with the examiner. However, you do not have a statutory right to a statement from your examiner. Please note, that you need to file your complaint within the deadline (see below) no matter whether you have received feedback from the examiner or not. If you still wish to file an official complaint, you should use this form and structure your complaint as follows: Begin by specifying what you wish to achieve through the complaint. Substantiate your complaint - it may be a good idea to describe how your exam answer met the requirements stated in the goal description for the course or project. If the course language is English, the complaint must be written in English. If the course language is Danish, you can write your complaint in either Danish or English. Send it to sap@itu.dk.
If you do not agree with the assessment at an exam, we recommend that you start by ing your examiner and discuss the reasons for your grade or assessment before making an official complaint.
Many students understand the assessment better once they have spoken with the examiner. However, you do not have a statutory right to a statement from your examiner.
If you still wish to file an official complaint, you should use this form and structure your complaint as follows:
If the course language is English, the complaint must be written in English. If the course language is Danish, you can write your complaint in either Danish or English. Send it to sap@itu.dk.

The deadline is two weeks after the grade is announced. This applies even if you have ed your examiner and are awaiting an eventual reply. You need to file your complaint within the deadline even if you haven't heard from your examiner.
Read about when grades are announced.

title: SU
paragraphs: Phone opening hours for the SU team
Tuesdays from 10-11. Call: 7218 5488
The team strives to answer e-mails within 2-3 working days. Write sap@itu.dk

New rules have been adopted for the state educational grant system (SU) for higher and private education. The rules come into effect on January, 1. 2027 and will apply for students who start a new higher education program on July 1, 2025 or later. A "new higher education" also refers to a master’s program after completing a bachelor’s degree.

Here you will find the most basic information regarding the State Educational Grant and Loan Scheme (SU). To get the full overview and for more detailed information we advise all students to go to www.su.dk. This page here will only serve you as a second-hand guide to the official SU-website.
You must be an active student when receiving SU.
In terms of SU, your delay is the difference between the number of months you have received SU and the number of ECTS that you have earned.
One month of SU corresponds to 5 ECTS.
If you are receiving SU this will continue while on exchange.
Besides the standard SU, students who have to pay a tuition fee for their courses abroad can apply for the SU udlandsstipendium as well.
If you are not a Danish citizen and if you do not know whether you are entitled to SU, please look at SU's own webpage about equal status according to Danish rules.

The rules come into effect on January, 1. 2027 and will apply for students who start a new higher education program on July 1, 2025 or later. A "new higher education" also refers to a master’s program after completing a bachelor’s degree. You must be an active student when receiving SU. In terms of SU, your delay is the difference between the number of months you have received SU and the number of ECTS that you have earned. One month of SU corresponds to 5 ECTS. If you are receiving SU this will continue while on exchange. Besides the standard SU, students who have to pay a tuition fee for their courses abroad can apply for the SU udlandsstipendium as well. If you are not a Danish citizen and if you do not know whether you are entitled to SU, please look at SU's own webpage about equal status according to Danish rules.

title: Writing a project across study programmes

headings.text: Writing a project across study programmes

paragraphs: When writing an elective project at ITU, you can choose to do it either by yourself, or in a group. The groups can be formed across Study programmes here at ITU, without any special approval from SAP.
Of course the supervisor needs to be aware of the constellation, but the project goals are the same across the different study programmes.
ITU students are allowed to write their Bachelor project or Master´s thesis with students from other ITU study programmes, but only if the following rules apply:

title: Workload and Project Size

headings.text: Syllabus - How much should I read?
Project size - How much should I write?

paragraphs: When writing a project, always agree with your supervisor on how much you should read and write. Your supervisor has the final word on the workload, page limit and syllabus for your project, depending on the scope and distribution between re, production and writing in your work. On this page, you can find guidelines that can form the basis of your alignment of expectations with your supervisor.
The rule of thumb for minimum syllabus in projects is 500 pages + 300 additional pages per 7.5 ECTS. Examples:

This guideline is extremely flexible depending on the subject area and educational level. If your syllabus contains difficult literature (for example of a highly technical, philosophical or mathematical nature) which requires time to understand, your syllabus for a project can be reduced. If you develop a product as part of your project, the teacher can reduce the syllabus as appropriate.

Especially for these programmesEspecially for GAMESThe general syllabus guidelines are not suitable for the GAMES study programme. Because of the inherent interdisciplinarity of the programme, the syllabus is often a mix of technical papers, other academic articles and books. A suitable guideline is that all reports should cite at least as many sources as they have pages. If students develop a product as part of a project or exam assignment, the supervisor can reduce the syllabus as appropriate. Especially for SWU, DS, SD and CSThe general syllabus guidelines are not suitable for SWU, DS, SD & CS study programmes. This is because syllabus on these programmes often contains a lot of coding and very little text. Coding has a very compressed nature compared to text. This applies for both courses, exam assignments and projects. Supervisor/course manager decide the syllabus for these study programmes.
Especially for these programmes

The general syllabus guidelines are not suitable for the GAMES study programme. Because of the inherent interdisciplinarity of the programme, the syllabus is often a mix of technical papers, other academic articles and books. A suitable guideline is that all reports should cite at least as many sources as they have pages.
Especially for SWU, DS, SD and CS

General rules How much you need to write depends on the subject area and on the balance between text and the development of a product or other practical work. Therefore, you agree upon how much you need to write with the supervisor based on what is appropriate in your specific case.

Standard page and body sizeA standard page is 2,400 units per page, including spaces and notes. The standard page range indicated on this page refers to the body of the written work. The body includes the preface and all original text that is part of the original argumentation and message plus citations. The body does not include: front page, colophon, table of contents, abstract, bibliography, appendices and illustrations and charts There is no upper or lower limit to the page span of the elements not included in the body. Body versus appendices The exact division can be tricky at times, but a general rule of thumb is that the body is the line of argumentation, while the appendix material serves to substantiate the argument(s).
A standard page is 2,400 units per page, including spaces and notes.
The standard page range indicated on this page refers to the body of the written work.

The body includes the preface and all original text that is part of the original argumentation and message plus citations. The body does not include: front page, colophon, table of contents, abstract, bibliography, appendices and illustrations and charts There is no upper or lower limit to the page span of the elements not included in the body. Body versus appendices The exact division can be tricky at times, but a general rule of thumb is that the body is the line of argumentation, while the appendix material serves to substantiate the argument(s).
Below are the recommended standard page spans for written work at ITU. Please note that there are different page spans, if you are a GAMES student.

Especially for GAMES individual projectsGAMES individual projects Number of students 7.5 ECTS project 15 ECTS project 1 7.5-15 pages 15-30 pages 2 10-20 pages 20-40 pages 3 13-26 pages 26-52 pages 4 17-34 pages 34-68 pages
Especially for GAMES individual projects
GAMES individual projects

When you write a bachelor or a thesis, there are other guidelines. How much you should write depends on the subject area and on the balance between text and the development of a product. Therefore, you agree upon how much you should write with your supervisor based on what is appropriate in your bachelor project/thesis. This becomes even more important if you develop a product as part of your bachelor project/thesis. In such cases, it is important that you have a dialogue with your supervisor about how much you should write. It is important that your supervisor approves any deviations from the guidelines below.

Guidelines for bachelor projectsData Science bachelor projectThe general project size guidelines are not suitable for Data Science bachelor projects, because Data Science bachelor projects often contain a lot of coding and very little text. Coding has a very compressed nature compared to text. Therefore, Data Science students agree upon the size of the project with the supervisor during the initial alignment of expectations in the supervision agreement.BDDIT bachelor project1 student: 24-30 standard pages 2 students: 30-38 standard pages 3 students: 36-45 standard pages 4 students: 42-53 standard pages Practical work If the project includes practical work, up to 20 per cent may be deducted of the size that the project would otherwise have. The reduction in the number of pages submitted is agreed between the supervisor and the student(s).GBI bachelor project1 student: 21-26 standard pages 2 students: 25-31 standard pages 3 students: 29-35 standard pages 4 students: 32-40 standard pages SWU bachelor projectThe general project size guidelines are not suitable for SWU bachelor projects, because SWU bachelor projects often contain a lot of coding and very little text. Coding has a very compressed nature compared to text. Therefore, SWU students agree upon the size of the project with the supervisor during the initial alignment of expectations in the supervision agreement. Guidelines for the master thesisComputer Science thesisThe general project size guidelines are not suitable for the Computer Science thesis, because they often contain a lot of coding and very little text. Coding has a very compressed nature compared to text. Therefore, students agree upon the size of the project with the supervisor during the initial alignment of expectations in the supervision agreement.Data ScienceThe general project size guidelines are not suitable for the Computer Science thesis, because they often contain a lot of coding and very little text. Coding has a very compressed nature compared to text. Therefore, students agree upon the size of the project with the supervisor during the initial alignment of expectations in the supervision agreement.KDDIT thesis1 student: 50-75 standard pages 2 students: 63-94 standard pages 3 students: 75-113 standard pages 4 students: 88-131 standard pages Practical work If the project includes practical work, up to 20 per cent may be deducted of the size that the project would otherwise have. The reduction in the number of pages submitted is agreed between the supervisor and the student(s).DIM thesis1 student: 54-66 standard pages 2 students: 72-88 standard pages 3 students: 90-110 standard pages 4 students: 108-132 standard pagesGAMES thesis1 student: 50-75 standard pages 2 students: 75-100 standard pages 3 students: 100-125 standard pages 4 students: 125-150 standard pages Practical work If the project includes practical work, up to 20 per cent may be deducted of the size that the project would otherwise have. The reduction in the number of pages submitted is agreed between the supervisor and the student(s).Software Design thesisThe general project size guidelines are not suitable for the Software Design Thesis, because they often contain a lot of coding and very little text. Coding has a very compressed nature compared to text. Therefore, Software Design students agree upon the size of the project with the supervisor during the initial alignment of expectations in the supervision agreement.

Therefore, students agree upon the size of the project with the supervisor during the initial alignment of expectations in the supervision agreement. 1 student: 50-75 standard pages 2 students: 63-94 standard pages 3 students: 75-113 standard pages 4 students: 88-131 standard pages Practical work If the project includes practical work, up to 20 per cent may be deducted of the size that the project would otherwise have. The reduction in the number of pages submitted is agreed between the supervisor and the student(s). 1 student: 54-66 standard pages 2 students: 72-88 standard pages 3 students: 90-110 standard pages 4 students: 108-132 standard pages 1 student: 50-75 standard pages 2 students: 75-100 standard pages 3 students: 100-125 standard pages 4 students: 125-150 standard pages Practical work If the project includes practical work, up to 20 per cent may be deducted of the size that the project would otherwise have. The reduction in the number of pages submitted is agreed between the supervisor and the student(s). Software Design thesis The general project size guidelines are not suitable for the Software Design Thesis, because they often contain a lot of coding and very little text. Coding has a very compressed nature compared to text. Therefore, Software Design students agree upon the size of the project with the supervisor during the initial alignment of expectations in the supervision agreement.

title: New SU reform
paragraphs: What does the reform mean for me?Please go to Scenarios and Examples to check out how the new SU reform might affect you. We encourage you, as a first step, to visit SU.dk, where you will find help and guidance for understanding the new SU rules. For information in English, please go to: SU reform - English
What does the reform mean for me?
What is new? From January 2027, the maximum SU grant portions in total will be reduced from 70 to 58.

When the new rules for SU come into effect from January 2027 onwards, the 70 SU grant portions you can receive will be reduced to 58 if you have started a new education after July 1, 2025. Therefore, you may have SU grant portions that will lapse when the limit is reduced from 70 to 58. On the SU grant portion calculator page (in Danish), you can calculate how many SU grant portions you will have left when the new rules come into effect.

Get an overviewWatch a short VIDEO (in Danish only) if you want an overview of the new SU reform. (Scroll down midways) When do the new rules take effect, and who do they apply to? The new rules apply to SU (student grant) from January 2027 onward for students who begin a new higher education programme on July 1, 2025, or later.
Until January 2027, the current rules will apply to all students, regardless of when they started their studies. Therefore, you will receive SU under the same rules as today until then.

your SU team If the information on su.dk raises further questions, you are, of course, always welcome to  SAP by email or by phone. The SU office has phone hours every Tuesday from 10-11. Find our  information here.
This page was last updated March 2025

title: Specialisations
paragraphs: How it worksStudents choose 37,5 ECTS of courses in all. Of these, a minimum of 22,5 ECTS need to be from the list of specialisation courses. Either you choose a combination that matches a recomended specialisation or you mix the courses yourself. The remaining 15 ECTS can be used for specialisation courses or elective courses. Find the list of electives for your programme herePlease note - this page is for the intake 2025 or later. If enrolled before 2025, please see here
Students choose 37,5 ECTS of courses in all.
Of these, a minimum of 22,5 ECTS need to be from the list of specialisation courses.
Either you choose a combination that matches a recomended specialisation or you mix the courses yourself.
The remaining 15 ECTS can be used for specialisation courses or elective courses.
Find the list of electives for your programme here

During your programme, you have to specialize by choosing an area of interest. This gives you a more distinctive profile and is an opportunity to point your academic profile in the direction you wish to go after graduation.

You can choose to follow one of the recommended combinations of courses, or you can make your own mix by combining courses from the list of specialisation courses below – you just need to choose a minimum of 22,5 ECTS from the list of specialisation courses.
For how to register, go to Study Administration / Registration
You register for the courses - not the specialisation You cannot register for a specialisation. Instead, you must sign up for and pass the courses on the specialisation.

Individual specialisations Students choose 37,5 ECTS of courses in all. Since the specialisation courses are designed for the KSD students to follow, it is therefore strongly recommended to choose at least 22,5 ECTS from the list of specialisation courses, and a maximum of 15 ECTS from the larger list of possible electives from other programmes.

If you want to take more than 15 ECTS from another programme, you need to apply for an individual specialisation of 22,5 ECTS. The specialisation need to be coherent within a given field, and fulfill the core curriculum of the KSD programme.

Before applying please do consult a lecturer/supervisor within the relevant academic area to get an indication of whether your plan for the individual specialisation looks reasonable. Please follow this link for information on how to apply.

title: Free Services
paragraphs: To use the services outside the university  by using WAYF. Just click on the WAYF logo at the  page and enter your ITU initials and password. The IT University of Copenhagen subscribes to the following services which means they are either free of use or provided with discounts for students. Some services may offer expansions available for purchase at your own cost. Read more below.
To use the services outside the university  by using WAYF. Just click on the WAYF logo at the  page and enter your ITU initials and password.

Free servicesOne.comAs an ITU-student you get: - Free domain registration for 12 months - Free ’Explorer’ hosting for 12 months - Unlimited email accounts - Free access to WordPress / Webshop Builder - Free SSL-certificate - Web statistics - Access to one.com Academia Support at: support.academiaprogram@one.com Please  the helpdesk at ITU to receive the discount code which you will need in order to claims the discount when you register at one.com Please note that if you choose a different subscription, the discount will not be added to your order. Make sure to follow the steps in the ”Voucher Coupon Guide” to ensure you receive the first year for free. We urge you to use your own email address for registration in order to get the future invoice and information from One.com. Please be aware that if you wish to terminate the domain and hosting service, you must do so in accordance with the Terms and conditions for one.com. Read more here. OrdbogenOrdbogen.com Ordbogen.com enables you to look up and translate words from English to Danish and Danish to English. Access ordbogen.com here. ColourboxColourbox is a collection of stock photos for non-commercial use. Students from ITU can download 30 photos per month. Staff and students at the IT University have free access to photos in Colourbox. Visit Colourbox here. How to get access Go to www.colourbox.com/education Enter the educational key in the box in the right column: Get the key here Fill in the form How to renew license Log in to your account Click on "Education License" Choose "Renew key" in the drop-down- NOTICE You are NOT allowed to use Colourbox pictures for commercial exploitation. If you need pictures for commercial use please  Martin Nedergaard Møller at mnmo@itu.dk Upload to Colourbox It is also possible to upload your own photos to Colourbox. However this is not allowed when using this license because it will transfer data to a third party data handler who does not live up to GDPR. Microsoft OfficeThe IT Department offer free Microsoft Office for all staff and students. The software includes Word, PowerPoint, Excel, Outlook and One Note, as well as Teams and OneDrive. You can freely use the license on up to five devices. Be aware! When installing Microsoft Office on your personal PC, "Allow my organization to manage my device" will automatically be checked off. Make sure to uncheck the box. If you already installed MS Office and checked the box, find the guide to undo it here. DO NOT use your ITU account to log into your private computer. This will cause you to be locked out after graduation. Read more here.MentimeterMentimeter is a tool for creating engaging presentations including polls, quizzes, and questions. Start using Mentimeter by going to mentimeter.itu.dk and log in using your ITU credentials. Try it out! You only need to register for an account using your ITU credentials, then you will automatically be given the premium perks of Overleaf. Overleaf is an online LaTeX editor that's easy to use. No installation, real-time collaboration, version control, hundreds of LaTeX templates, manage group projects, and more. InLearningInLearning is an online learning platform that helps with anything from business, software, and design. The IT University now provides free access to all the content, you just need to sign up with your ITU log-in. NVivoNVivo is a software tool for qualitative re to analyze large data sets. To receive your activation key for NVivo, please  it@itu.dk Note that you have to provide a valid student proof. Therefore, you must send a mail to it@itu.dk, from your ITU mail account. Read more about NVivo here. Once having received the activation key you will need to  with your ITU account. (If the page doesn't load, try closing the page and clicking the link again)

title: New progression requirement
paragraphs: The progression requirement is a rule stating how much you have to pass each year in order to be considered an active student and continue your programme at ITU.

From 1 September 2025, the progression requirement is changed. Consequently, you must pass one exam within a continuous period of one year, corresponding to two consecutive semesters, including re-exams. If you do not do this, you will not be allowed to continue your programme and your enrolment will be terminated.

If you due to special circumstances cannot fulfil the progression requirement, you can apply for an exemption from this rule. Please go to Exemptions for further information about the requirement and exemptions. Transitional period If you apply for an exemption from the progression requirement concerning a period from 1 September 2025 and onwards, the new progression requirement will apply. If you apply for an exemption from the progression requirement concerning a period before 1 September 2025, the old requirement will apply.
Please see here for the old requirement.

Transitional period If you apply for an exemption from the progression requirement concerning a period from 1 September 2025 and onwards, the new progression requirement will apply. If you apply for an exemption from the progression requirement concerning a period before 1 September 2025, the old requirement will apply. Please see here for the old requirement.

title: Committee for Diversity, Equity and Inclusion

headings.text: Committee for Diversity, Equity and Inclusion

paragraphs: ITU believes that a diverse, equitable and inclusive work and study environment is a prerequisite for attracting and retaining talented staff and students.

To promote a diverse, equitable and inclusive work and study environment at ITU the Executive Management has established a Committee for Diversity, Equity and Inclusion. The committee is responsible for ensuring actions (action plans) on initiatives that promote a diverse, equitable and inclusive work and study environment at ITU in alignment with ITU’s mission, vision, and strategy.

The goal (goals for 2022-2025) is to ensure noticeable progress in areas where there is a defined goal due to an inequality. The committee must especially focus on areas where there is limited progress and/or areas where special attention is needed to achieve the goal of a diverse, equitable and inclusive work environment that attract and retain talented staff and students. Members of the Committee:
Find the Rules of Procedure for Committee for Diversity, Equity and Inclusion here.

If you have input/inquiries for the Committee for Diversity, Equity and Inclusion to discuss or consider in their work with Diversity, Equity and Inclusion feel free to reach out at diversity-inclusion@itu.dk. Your email will be handled by HR with complete confidentiality by HR Partners Kristina Køj-Udsen and Nina Sølvberg Nelby who will handle all inquiries on behalf of the committee.
Data on Gender Equality
Gender Equality Plan Gender Equality Plan
Target figure Target figure for gender composition for ITU's board and management
Maintained by HR. Updated April 10, 2025.

title: Online oral exam

headings.text: At the day of the exam

paragraphs: Even though it is standard procedure to have all oral examinations at ITU, you can if necessary arrange with your course manager and the examiner to have the oral exam online.
When deciding on this you need to be aware of the online format, how it might affect you in the exam situation and how to prepare for it.
For a full overview of how to prepare, please also have a look at the guidelines for normal oral exams, since a lot of the tips for how to prepare will be the same.
For information about the formalities about an online exam, please see here for course exams and here for thesis/projects exams
* Be sure that you have tested all the technique. Find more information here
* Make sure that you sit in your best spot – where you will feel comfortable, and that you have everything you need within your reach.
* Set up a nice background, if you are not comfortable with showing your dirty laundry laying on bed.
* Don’t be afraid to take short breaks under your examination – it makes sense to use time to think, when you are asked questions.

links.text: The exam situation can feel different

full_text: Online oral exam Exam Hacks Online oral exam A different experience At the day of the exam Even though it is standard procedure to have all oral examinations at ITU, you can if necessary arrange with your course manager and the examiner to have the oral exam online. When deciding on this you need to be aware of the online format, how it might affect you in the exam situation and how to prepare for it. For a full overview of how to prepare, please also have a look at the guidelines for normal oral exams, since a lot of the tips for how to prepare will be the same. For information about the formalities about an online exam, please see here for course exams and here for thesis/projects exams * Be sure that you have tested all the technique. Find more information here * Make sure that you sit in your best spot – where you will feel comfortable, and that you have everything you need within your reach. * Set up a nice background, if you are not comfortable with showing your dirty laundry laying on bed. * Don’t be afraid to take short breaks under your examination – it makes sense to use time to think, when you are asked questions.

title: Course Exams

headings.text: Time and date of the exam

paragraphs: Some courses have mandatory activities. You need to pass the mandatory activities in order to be eligible for the exam. In the course catalogue, you can see if your courses have mandatory activities.

If you do not pass the mandatory activities You will receive the grade NA (not approved) at the ordinary exam, if the mandatory activities are not approved before the deadline set by the course manager. You will use an exam attempt.
Re-exam Before the re-exam you again need to have the mandatory activities approved. Therefore  your course manager asap for a new agreement on when to submit the mandatory activities.
Courses typically have three different exam forms. In the course catalogue you can find information about the exam form used for the different courses.
Follow the links below and read more about the different exam forms.
Follow this link for the exam forms and variations explained in details.
Written exams on premises
Talk to your course manager about whether or not you need to make amendments to the exam assignment. See here for details about re-submitting.
Oral exams and written exams on premises
See TimeEdit for all the above dates. Please note that if the form for the exam change for the re-exam, the date for your re-exam might change as well, so remember to check up on the date!
The Study and Career Guidance offers a lot of useful tips and tricks, that can be relevant for you when it comes to exams and preparation.
Explore the the topics they cover, by having a look at the drop down  for The Study and Career Guidance.

title: Transitional provisions
paragraphs: Bacheloruddannelsen i Digitalt design og interaktive teknologier (BDDIT) har sidste optag af studerende på 2020 studieordningen i efterårssemestret 2023.

Der vil blive udbudt undervisning for studerende indskrevet op til september 2023 ift. normeret studietid således at studerende har mulighed for at færdiggøre deres uddannelse inden for normeret studietid som planlagt til og med sommereksamen 2026.

Følgende overgangsbestemmelser er udarbejdet med det formål at sikre, at alle studerende indskrevet på BDDIT kan færdiggøre deres uddannelser inden for alle tidligere studieordninger, når den reviderede BDDIT studieordning af 2024 træder i kraft med virkning fra BDDIT Optag 2024.
Overgangsordning (transitional provisions) gældende for alle BDDIT studerende optaget til og med 2023 kan findes her (opdateret 18 september 2025).
full_text: Transitional provisions Transitional provisions Bacheloruddannelsen i Digitalt design og interaktive teknologier (BDDIT) har sidste optag af studerende på 2020 studieordningen i efterårssemestret 2023. Der vil blive udbudt undervisning for studerende indskrevet op til september 2023 ift. normeret studietid således at studerende har mulighed for at færdiggøre deres uddannelse inden for normeret studietid som planlagt til og med sommereksamen 2026. Følgende overgangsbestemmelser er udarbejdet med det formål at sikre, at alle studerende indskrevet på BDDIT kan færdiggøre deres uddannelser inden for alle tidligere studieordninger, når den reviderede BDDIT studieordning af 2024 træder i kraft med virkning fra BDDIT Optag 2024. Overgangsordning (transitional provisions) gældende for alle BDDIT studerende optaget til og med 2023 kan findes her (opdateret 18 september 2025).

title: You register for all your study activities yourself

headings.text: You register for all your study activities yourself
When can we see our confirmed registrations?
What courses can you sign up for?
Summer University or Summer Courses outside of ITU

paragraphs: Registration periodsSpring semester You can register from December 1 (midnight) - December 10 (23:59). Autumn semester You can register from June 1 (midnight) - June 10 (23:59). Summer University You can register from December 1 (midnight) - December 10. (23:59) If there are seats available, you are be able to register June 1 (midnight) - June 10. (23:59) Read more about Summer University at ITU.
Spring semester You can register from December 1 (midnight) - December 10 (23:59).
Autumn semester You can register from June 1 (midnight) - June 10 (23:59).
Summer University You can register from December 1 (midnight) - December 10. (23:59)
If there are seats available, you are be able to register June 1 (midnight) - June 10. (23:59)
Read more about Summer University at ITU.
You must register for all your study activities yourself: (all new BSc and MSc students are administratively registered for their first semester)

A limit to your registrations You cannot exceed the registration limit of 37,5 ECTS pr. semester. The only exception is, if for the Spring semester you want to register for 37, 5 ECTS + a Summer University course, then you write sap@itu.dk.
In general, if you have issues making a registration send an e-mail to sap@itu.dk in the registration period, and we will look into it.
Mandatory courses Your registration for a mandatory course on your programme will secure you a seat on the course.

Electives Your registration for elective courses is only a wish. Getting a seat has to do with how many who registered for it and how the seats are allocated. For this reason you should always register a second priority for your electives. Are you pushing courses?If you are considering to push courses and not register for the standard 30 ECTS, please SEE HERE for what to be aware of.
Are you pushing courses?
Specialisation courses Your registration for a specialisation course that is standard to your programme will secure you a seat on the course. This goes for the 2nd (and 3rd) part as well.
A registration for a course that is part of an approved individual specialisation is only a wish. Getting a seat has to do with how many who registered for it and how the seats are allocated.
You can find the principles for the allocation of course seats here.

How to registerYou register in My Study Activities. First and second priorities (Electives only*) The number of courses that you give first priority indicates the number of courses you want to register for, therefore if you need to register for two courses, you should give both courses first priority. Your choice of second priority course will only be taken into consideration, if you are not awarded a seat in the course(s) that you have given first priority. During the period for changing registrations in the beginning of the semester, you cannot prioritise registrations. * For mandatory courses or specialisation courses you do not need to have a second priority.
You register in My Study Activities.

First and second priorities (Electives only*) The number of courses that you give first priority indicates the number of courses you want to register for, therefore if you need to register for two courses, you should give both courses first priority.
Your choice of second priority course will only be taken into consideration, if you are not awarded a seat in the course(s) that you have given first priority.
During the period for changing registrations in the beginning of the semester, you cannot prioritise registrations.
* For mandatory courses or specialisation courses you do not need to have a second priority.

Please be aware If your registration is rejected by the system (afvist, ingen plads, osv.), the registration team will look into it and send you an email if any action is necessary on your part. Often the team will be able to simply fix the registration, but remember to keep an eye on your email during the registration period.
You do not need to notify SAP!
In each registration period, you can see a list of the courses available for your registration on the registration form in My Study Activities.

Approved electivesFind the list in LearnIT. Set the filters to The relevant semester and Elective to and then choose your own study programme.Remember to check if the courses you sign up for are scheduled to run at the same time. In the weeks up until the registration opens, a list of approved courses will be shared for each programme with the courses available to choose from.
Find the list in LearnIT. Set the filters to The relevant semester and Elective to and then choose your own study programme.
Please be aware If you are choosing electives approved for you, but from a different study programme, the course can require specific knowledge you might not have.

The courses facilitated by your own Study Programme should fit in with your acquired knowledge and skills, but do remember to check up on the prerequisites.Special academic prerequisites?For some students their educational background might qualify them for courses outside the course list. Please read more here
Special academic prerequisites?
For some students their educational background might qualify them for courses outside the course list.
Please read more here
You are responsible for ensuring that you meet the prerequisites for a course.

Remember that you have the possibility to take courses during the summer either through Summer University at ITU or Summer courses outside ITU. For courses outside of ITU instead of registering you need to apply for a pre-approval in advance.
You register for a project in My Study Activities similar to registering for courses. This includes bachelor projects and master theses.
Please note, when you register for the project, you will be asked to provide,

Do you have a supervisor? You are responsible for finding a supervisor, however, some programmes have processes to help you find supervisors for bachelor projects and master theses. See for information on finding a supervisor.
If you don’t have a supervisor upon registration, please email sap@itu.dk with the name as soon as you have found one.
For more information about the process and requirements for writing a project or thesis, please see Process for writing projects and theses

How to registerProject codes When you register you choose between different project codes. Each code represents a different project. If you have not registered for a project before you just choose number 1. If writing a second project, you then choose another project code. If you need more attempts concerning a project you have already registered for once, Student Affairs & Programmes will need to handle the registration for you. You then write to sap@itu.dk about the registration. Group projects If you are registering for a group project, only one member of the group has to make the registration and then add the other group member(s) before finalising the registration. The added group members will receive an invitation for the project and it is important that they remember to accept this invitation.

Project codes When you register you choose between different project codes. Each code represents a different project. If you have not registered for a project before you just choose number 1. If writing a second project, you then choose another project code. If you need more attempts concerning a project you have already registered for once, Student Affairs & Programmes will need to handle the registration for you. You then write to sap@itu.dk about the registration. Group projects If you are registering for a group project, only one member of the group has to make the registration and then add the other group member(s) before finalising the registration. The added group members will receive an invitation for the project and it is important that they remember to accept this invitation.

Project page and problem statement Your registration for a project generates a project page in LearnIT. This is where you submit your problem statement and where your supervisor will be added. The project page is also where you later submit the final project.
Read more about the preliminary problem statement here Learn more about getting started with a project here.

FAQI have attended the course before. Can I sign up for the exam only?No. Registration for an exam requires that you register for the course in the registration period. This also means that have to submit mandatory assignments again, and that your exam will be based on the newest curriculum for the course, if the course has changed.  the course manager for the possibility of re-submitting the mandatory assignments from when you attended the course the first time. If the course hasn't changed this could be a possibility.Registering for a 2nd or 3rd exam attempt (courses)1. If, due to cancelled attempts, your "first" exam attempt was in the re-exam period, you must register for the course again in the registration period 2. If your second exam attempt was in the re-exam period, you must register for the course again in the registration period. 3. If your second exam attempt was at the ordinary exam in December/January or May/June, you must register for your third attempt in the re-exam period by sending an email to sap@itu.dk no later than on the 2nd Wednesday of respectively February or July.* *If your grades are released after the above deadline and you discover that you need to register for your third attempt in the re-exam period, please  sap@itu.dk within 3 days of the grade announcement.What if the course is no longer offered?When a course is no longer offered Then in most cases a replacement course is chosen and you must take this instead. You will be able to register for this course by yourself. In very rare cases, no replacement course exists As a rule, you will then get the opportunity to complete the course in the first-coming exam period after the course has been cancelled. However, this may vary from course to course and under certain circumstances, other timeframes may also apply. SAP will  you and inform you about the practicalities. Can I do courses or projects at other Universities?Yes, you can. For this you need a pre-approval of credit transfer from the IT University. Apart from this, you have to follow the admission guidelines for guest students at the specific university.
I have attended the course before. Can I sign up for the exam only?

No. Registration for an exam requires that you register for the course in the registration period. This also means that have to submit mandatory assignments again, and that your exam will be based on the newest curriculum for the course, if the course has changed.
the course manager for the possibility of re-submitting the mandatory assignments from when you attended the course the first time. If the course hasn't changed this could be a possibility.
Registering for a 2nd or 3rd exam attempt (courses)
1. If, due to cancelled attempts, your "first" exam attempt was in the re-exam period, you must register for the course again in the registration period
2. If your second exam attempt was in the re-exam period, you must register for the course again in the registration period.

3. If your second exam attempt was at the ordinary exam in December/January or May/June, you must register for your third attempt in the re-exam period by sending an email to sap@itu.dk no later than on the 2nd Wednesday of respectively February or July.*

*If your grades are released after the above deadline and you discover that you need to register for your third attempt in the re-exam period, please  sap@itu.dk within 3 days of the grade announcement.
What if the course is no longer offered?
Can I do courses or projects at other Universities?

title: Courses outside ITU

headings.text: Courses at other universities in Denmark
Courses passed before enrolling at ITU

paragraphs: You can take courses outside ITU as part of you programme. Courses at other universities in Denmark If you want to do courses at other universities in Denmark, you need to have the courses pre-approved. Be aware that besides applying for pre-approval from ITU you also need to follow the guidelines for admission at the University where you want to take your electives. Look for admission rules for guest students on their website. Courses passed before enrolling at ITUIf you have passed courses that are relevant for your studies at ITU before you enrolled at ITU, you can apply for a Credit Transfer. Studying abroad If you want to take courses at Universities outside Denmark, you can apply to go on Exchange. This involves getting a pre-approval well. Read about how to Study Abroad.
You can take courses outside ITU as part of you programme.
If you want to do courses at other universities in Denmark, you need to have the courses pre-approved.
Be aware that besides applying for pre-approval from ITU you also need to follow the guidelines for admission at the University where you want to take your electives.
Look for admission rules for guest students on their website.
Courses passed before enrolling at ITUIf you have passed courses that are relevant for your studies at ITU before you enrolled at ITU, you can apply for a Credit Transfer.

If you want to take courses at Universities outside Denmark, you can apply to go on Exchange. This involves getting a pre-approval well. Read about how to Study Abroad.

title: Student Organisations
paragraphs: Student Council is the political organisation at the IT University of Copenhagen. It consists of students from every field of study at the university, and is run by students. The Student Council works to promote students’ interests and improve their political, professional, and social conditions at the ITU.

Furthermore, they run Student Activity Fund, which supports both professional and social activities improving the study environment. Read more about Student Council and how you can join in. Follow Student Council on

Analog is the IT University’s student café where you can have a nice cup of coffee and chat with your fellow students. Analog is also a good place to do group work if you are looking for a relaxed atmosphere. The café is run by student volunteers, so this is another place to get involved and be a part of creating a positive study environment at ITU. You will find Analog next to the Information desk.
Follow Analog on  and see Download Analog's App (Google Play/App Store) and get your ticket coupons for coffee digitally.

The university’s party committee and Friday bar is named ScrollBar. The bar opens every Friday at 15.00 and stays open till 2.00, offering a wide range of special brew and drinks. All bartenders are volunteers and they also arrange theme parties in the course of the semester as well. You will find ScrollBar directly across the Canteen.

Modem is the IT University’s own online student radio run by students themselves. Their mission is to produce entertaining and informative radio programmes to students at ITU. The programmes are released as podcasts as well. Modem is run by a committee, and they are always looking for new members sharing their passion for radio. Read more and listen to Radio Modem

Node is the student and alumni choir at ITU. Each week we meet for two hours to sing rhythmic songs conducted by a professional conductor. In between there is a small coffee break to socialise. We are always looking for new members, experienced or not. If you enjoy singing you can join our meet n’ greet at the beginning of each semester or feel welcome to stop by for any practice session.
Reach us here: node_choir@itu.dk.
CampusCup aims to bring students from the IT University and Søndre Campus (University of Copenhagen) together through a joyful competition combining Regatta and beerrace in Emil Holm’s canal.

The event takes place every year in September, and everyone can look forward to a fantastic afternoon with entertainment, music and party – no matter if they feel like jumping in the kayak or not. Read more about Campus Cup Follow Campus Cup on
Connect is a student-run organization with the purpose of hosting events based around socializing, games and movies for the students at the IT University of Copenhagen.

ITU LAN is organising a gaming event at the IT University every Spring and Autumn. Here, both ITU students and people from outside ITU can participate in larger and smaller tournaments in selected games. ITU LAN is run by volunteers.
Read more about how you can join an event and how you can get involved as a volunteer.
Read more about ITU LAN
Blockchain Student Group is a student-driven community interred in blockchain. We have presentation by experts, discuss the latest blockchain news and develop student blockchain projects.

All students are welcome to join and there is no prior blockchain knowledge required. Think decentralized and be part of the community by joining our Teams group 'Blockchain Student Group’ or our public  group ‘Blockchain Student Group - ITU'.

title: Oral Exam

headings.text: Structure and content of oral exams for group projects
Structure and content of oral exams in an individual project

paragraphs: Oral exam - online or at ITUYou have to decide and agree with your supervisor if you want your oral exam to be conducted online or physically at ITU. Have the talk with your supervisor in the start-up fase of your project. Please see here for details about the online oral examThe oral exam will be held no later than 4 weeks after the submission deadline. LearnIT will be updated with the exact time and place of the oral exam.
Oral exam - online or at ITU
You have to decide and agree with your supervisor if you want your oral exam to be conducted online or physically at ITU.
Have the talk with your supervisor in the start-up fase of your project.
Please see here for details about the online oral exam
On the day of the exam, make sure that you arrive in due time before the exam.
Projects Oral exams following ordinary projects last around 40 minutes per student, including the examiners’ voting and feedback to you. This also applies to the bachelor project.
The Master thesis The oral exam for the master thesis last around 50 minutes per student, including the examiners’ voting and feedback.

RememberIt is your responsibility to check which aids are provided and allowed at the exam and in the exam preparation room.Your graduation date is the day your examiners date the exam protocol, which is often on the same day as the oral exam. Read more about graduation and the diploma.

Formal requirements Apart from the length of the exam, there are no formal requirements to the structure and content of the oral exam. You should always turn to your supervisor / the examiner, to find out which elements the exam will consist of and what will be expected of you.

Structure and content of oral exams for group projectsThe oral group exam in a group project must be conducted in one the five ways described in this document. This is to ensure that it is possible to give each student an individual assessment. The group must choose between one of the five possibilities and let the supervisor know. The group shares the responsibility for the exam assignment.

The oral group exam in a group project must be conducted in one the five ways described in this document. This is to ensure that it is possible to give each student an individual assessment. The group must choose between one of the five possibilities and let the supervisor know.
The group shares the responsibility for the exam assignment.

Structure and content of oral exams in an individual projectApart from the length of the exam, there are no formal requirements to the structure and content of oral exams for individual projects. You should always talk to the examiner, so that you know which elements the exam will consist of and what will be expected of you. See also the time and date of your exams in TimeEdit.

Apart from the length of the exam, there are no formal requirements to the structure and content of oral exams for individual projects. You should always talk to the examiner, so that you know which elements the exam will consist of and what will be expected of you.
See also the time and date of your exams in TimeEdit.

Oral examinations are public, but the Board of Studies at ITU has decided that examinations will take place behind closed doors on the examinee’s request. Moreover, the Board of Studies may in particular cases decide that an examination is not public, and specify who may be present during the examination. Only the internal and external examiners may be present during the evaluation. The Board of Studies may, however, decide that future examiners may be present at the evaluation as well. Students are not allowed to do any kind of auditory or visual recording during the exam.

title: The project page
paragraphs: Please Note: If your project is cancelled or pushed the project page will be shut down. If you need your work for later, you need to save and store it yourself.

The preliminary problem statement is where you zoom in on the scope of your project, giving a more precise description of your subject area, topic, hypothesis etc. Your supervisor must approve your problem statement and thereby also agree to supervise your project. After your supervisor approve your preliminary problem statement, it cannot be edited on the project page. However, you can still elaborate on it in the actual project. The preliminary problem statement will not be part of the assessment of your project. Therefore, your preliminary problem statement needs to be generic enough to allow for your scope to change as the project progresses, while at the same time be specific enough for your supervisor to be able to assess and approve of the scope of the project. This description is also used in the process of allocating an external examiner for your oral exam (where applicable). Therefore, we recommend that you spend some time to work on the preliminary problem statement before submitting.

Elective projects, Bachelor projects and Thesis: Friday in week 5 (for Spring) / 35 (for Autumn) Re project (CS, DS & SD): Friday in week 8 (for Spring) / 39 (for Autumn) Summer project: Friday week 26 Project agreements have a deadline running until 14:00 on the date given above.
Elective projects, Bachelor projects and Thesis: Friday in week 5 (for Spring) / 35 (for Autumn)
Re project (CS, DS & SD): Friday in week 8 (for Spring) / 39 (for Autumn)
Summer project: Friday week 26

Late registration If you register for a project, bachelor project or thesis in the registration change period, the deadline for the preliminary problem statement is moved to Friday in week 8 / week 39.

The title you registered in My Study Activities is the name of the project page and the default project title which will go on your diploma. To change the title of your project, you must write to sap@itu.dk and they will be happy to change the title for you. SAP will not be able to change the title of your project page, but only change the project title as it will appear on your diploma.
Please note, the title should be changed before you submit your project.

Projects are submitted on the project page, similar to course exams. See how to submit written work. Submission deadlines can be found here. When set, you can find the time and date for the oral exam in the calendar function on the project page. For more details on formal requirements for projects, see this overview Project work

title: Study Skills
paragraphs: As a students it is important to establish a normal workday, where you study from morning to afternoon - even if you do not have classes.
Aside from your lectures and tutorials, you will need to read a lot of texts and prepare hand-ins or oral presentations.
Planning as a tool can be extremely helpful, since it will help you feel in charge of both study time and free time.
Exams can for some feel overwhelming. With the right preparation though and the tools to successfully study for exams it can end up being a great experience.
We have gathered some tips and tricks to help you in preparing for your exams.

We acknowlegde that navigating your studies: going to lectures, participating in exercises, studying and working in groups or by yourself is a lot. Then on top comes navigating all the study rules and requirements.
To give you a quick overview we have put together a small video highlighting all the important study rules you need to be aware of.

Aside from your lectures and tutorials, you will need to read a lot of texts and prepare hand-ins or oral presentations. Planning as a tool can be extremely helpful, since it will help you feel in charge of both study time and free time. Exams can for some feel overwhelming. With the right preparation though and the tools to successfully study for exams it can end up being a great experience. We have gathered some tips and tricks to help you in preparing for your exams. We acknowlegde that navigating your studies: going to lectures, participating in exercises, studying and working in groups or by yourself is a lot. Then on top comes navigating all the study rules and requirements. To give you a quick overview we have put together a small video highlighting all the important study rules you need to be aware of.

title: First-year exam
paragraphs: All bachelor students at the IT University must meet the requirements of the first-year exam which are stipulated in the Examination Order.

Students enrolled 2015 or laterHow do I pass the first-year exam? In order to pass the first-year exam, you must pass exams corresponding to 45 ECTS before the end of your first year of studies. This applies regardless of whether you have only used 2 exam attempts on the courses that constitutes the 1. year. Consequences of not passing the first-year exam If you do not pass the first-year exam, you will not be allowed to continue your studies at the IT University. Can I get an exemption? You can apply for an exemption from the first-year exam, if there are special circumstances in your situation. Learn more about exemptions and How to apply for an exemption.

How do I pass the first-year exam? In order to pass the first-year exam, you must pass exams corresponding to 45 ECTS before the end of your first year of studies. This applies regardless of whether you have only used 2 exam attempts on the courses that constitutes the 1. year.
Consequences of not passing the first-year exam If you do not pass the first-year exam, you will not be allowed to continue your studies at the IT University.
Can I get an exemption? You can apply for an exemption from the first-year exam, if there are special circumstances in your situation. Learn more about exemptions and How to apply for an exemption.

title: Becoming a parent

headings.text: Take leave of absence or apply for parental exemption?

paragraphs: information The Study and Career Guidance if you have any questions regarding your options when you become a parent. We recommend that you talk to a student advisor, if you become a parent (by birth or adoption) while studying at ITU.
The Study and Career Guidance if you have any questions regarding your options when you become a parent.

Did you know that there is a difference between taking a leave of absence or applying for a parental exemption? Depending on what you choose, your rights will vary both in terms of your studies and your financial situation.

Processing timeYou can expect a processing time of up to 8 weeks. If you apply for an exemption from several rules, your application is a continuation of a previous exemption or lacks documentation the processing time can be extended. During the exam period, the processing time for an application will, in general, still be up to 8 weeks. July is not included in the processing time due to the summer holiday.If you apply for a leave of absence, please be aware that you cannot be study active in the period of your leave (you cannot attend classes or go to exams). In addition, you will not be eligible to receive SU grants. For more information, go to Leave of absence. If you do not want to take a leave of absence, you can apply for a parental exemption. Please read below for more information. Parental exemption You can be granted a parental exemption when becoming a parent through childbirth or adoption. A parental exemption enables you to take a break from your studies for some time but also gives you the possibility of combining parental leave (“barsel”) with being an active student and receiving SU or students birth grant (fødsels-støtte). In practice, this means that you can study between 0-30 ECTS per semester and attend exams during your parental leave. You will typically need exemptions from various study rules, which depend on where you are in your studies. You may need an exemption to:
You can expect a processing time of up to 8 weeks.

If you apply for an exemption from several rules, your application is a continuation of a previous exemption or lacks documentation the processing time can be extended. During the exam period, the processing time for an application will, in general, still be up to 8 weeks.
July is not included in the processing time due to the summer holiday.

• Deregister from course(s) you have registered for (“the binding course registration”) • Postpone the deadline for completing your first-year exam (“the first-year exam”) • Postpone the deadline for completion of your programme (“the maximum programme duration”) • Not pass an exam for a continous period of one year (The progression requirement) • Postpone the deadline for a project or your thesis (“project or thesis deadline”)

See for details about your possibilitiesThe motherAs the mother you are entitled to two semesters of parental leave starting either from the semester in which the birth takes place or from the first coming semester after the birth has taken place. Example: You are due on 4 June 2025 (i.e. Spring semester 2025), hence you have the following options: • Apply for parental leave in the Spring and Autumn semesters 2025 • Apply for parental leave in the Autumn semester 2025 and the Spring semester 2026 Please note that when you apply for a parental exemption you will automatically have your maximum programme duration postponed corresponding to the length of your parental leave.The fatherAs the father / co-parent you are entitled to one semester of parental leave either in the semester in which the birth takes place or in one of the following two semesters. Example: Your partner is due on 4 June 2025 (i.e. Spring semester 2025), hence you have the following options: • Apply for parental leave in the Spring semester 2025 • Apply for parental leave in the Autumn semester 2025 • Apply for parental leave in the Spring semester 2026 Please note that when you apply for a parental exemption you will automatically have your maximum programme duration postponed corresponding to the length of your parental leave. Unforeseen circumstancesWhen your parental exemption is granted, it cannot be altered. However, you can apply for an exemption to alter the semester(s) of your parental leave if unforeseen circumstances occur in relation to your or your partner’s pregnancy, the birth of your child, or your parental leave. Examples of unforeseen circumstances: • You fall ill due to your pregnancy • Your child is born prematurelyHow to applyYou apply for a parental exemption by filling out this form: Parental exemption. To your application you must submit documentation of your parenthood in the form of either a birth certificate, paternity certificate, the medical record (vandrejournal) or other medical documentation or adoption papers. The documentation must contain information about the due date, name and civil registration number. You are welcome to blur out the remaining information. You must also submit a provisional study plan which shows how you plan to complete your studies. Please state which semester(s) you plan to be on parental leave including which semester you plan to start the parental leave and when you plan to resume your studies. Send the application to sap@itu.dk.
See for details about your possibilities
Unforeseen circumstances

SU when becoming a parent You can apply for additional SU clips if you become a parent while studying. Read more about additional SU clips here. Your responsibilities We expect you to check your ITU-mail regularly while you are on parental leave. You must also remember to register for study activities (courses and projects) in accordance with your study plan during and after your parental leave. We do not do this for you. Please be aware of the registration periods.

You must also remember to register for study activities (courses and projects) in accordance with your study plan during and after your parental leave. We do not do this for you. Please be aware of the registration periods.

title: Activating account without MitID
paragraphs: Please be awareThis guide applies to all international students, who applied to ITU without a cpr-number. Even if you now have MitID, you still need to activate your account as described on this page.Since you are an International student you will most likely not have a Danish social security number yet (called cpr-number), and therefore you will not have MitID.
This guide applies to all international students, who applied to ITU without a cpr-number.
Even if you now have MitID, you still need to activate your account as described on this page.
And even if you have acquired a cpr-number and you have MitID, you need to follow these instructions.
You activate your account as described below, by logging in and changing your password.
First step - locate your  information
Second step - log in to change your temporary password Multi-Factor AuthenticationBefore you can use your ITU-, you need to set up the Multi Factor Authentication. Read about it here
Multi-Factor Authentication
Before you can use your ITU-, you need to set up the Multi Factor Authentication.
Once you have done that and activated the Multi-factor authentication, you can access your ITU email and you will have access to all ITU systems.
