title: Collaborating with companies
paragraphs: Intellectual property rights and confidentialityIntellectual property (IP) is a category of property that includes intangible creations of the human intellect. The well-known types are s, patents, trademarks, designs and trade secrets that often hold a significant value to companies. Students, who are not employees at ITU own the intellectual property rights (IPR) in the works they produce.It is also possible to collaborate with a company on a project. Collaborating with a company while you are studying gives you the opportunity to:
Intellectual property rights and confidentiality

Intellectual property (IP) is a category of property that includes intangible creations of the human intellect. The well-known types are s, patents, trademarks, designs and trade secrets that often hold a significant value to companies. Students, who are not employees at ITU own the intellectual property rights (IPR) in the works they produce.

ITU recommends that aspects of confidentiality and intellectual property rights are discussed before starting such projects. This is among other things to ensure that you do not enter into a contract with a company on unfair terms, such as to waive all the rights to your IP without any remuneration. Agreements Here you can find an example of a Confidentiality Agreement Here you can find an example of a Confidentiality and Rights Agreement PLEASE NOTE You need to email the Confidentiality and Rights agreement to legal@itu.dk for a signature, before it can be of any use. Before sending it both the student and the company needs to have signed the agreement. ITU has prepared an example of a so-called Confidentiality Agreement and a Confidentiality and Rights Agreement for a student project that you and the company can use. This is not a requirement; However, ITU will only co-sign an agreement for a student project, if the agreement is based on our template, see section on the Confidentiality and Rights Agreement below.
Here you can find an example of a Confidentiality Agreement Here you can find an example of a Confidentiality and Rights Agreement
You need to email the Confidentiality and Rights agreement to legal@itu.dk for a signature, before it can be of any use.
Before sending it both the student and the company needs to have signed the agreement.
Many companies prefer to use their own agreement, but ITU will not sign these, and you can only commit yourself – and not ITU – to the content with your signature.

Confidentiality agreementA Confidentiality Agreement is between you and the company, and ITU is not a part of the agreement. Both supervisor and examiner are obliged to follow the duty of confidentiality in general. Therefore, you do not need a signature from your supervisor or any other ITU representative. For this reason as well, you must be extra careful what you agree to, as the agreement is your responsibility.Confidentiality and Rights agreementA Confidentiality and Rights Agreement is between you, ITU and the Company. Please be aware that certain provisions regarding e.g. confidentiality, examination and rights to ITU’s intellectual property cannot be changed as ITU are bound by the rules in the University Act, the Examination Act, the Re Patent Act and the state aid rules. The non-negotiable provisions are marked as such in the agreement. If these provisions are changed in any way, ITU consider the agreement invalid. You can always change the provisions concerning your own rights to intellectual property. Have it signed by ITU It is a requirement that ITU’s pro-rector sign this type of agreement. Therefore, please  legal@itu.dk for such. Involving ITU Legal?You are not entitled to use ITU Legal, as this is a service to the University staff that can be used as part of their work. Legal will often get involved in your project through the supervisor, but please be aware that it is the supervisor's interests that Legal are protecting and not yours. However, Legal has tried to consider the interests of students in preparing the standard contract Confidentiality and Rights agreement.Mark as confidentialIf necessary, you can mark in LearnIT that the assignment is confidential, when you submit it. In addition, the oral exam will be held behind closed doors, i.e. without an audience, on your request.RecommendationsWe recommend that you show any agreement to your supervisor before you sign it, so you and your supervisor can ensure that the agreement does not contain elements, which are in violation with ITU regulations for projects and exams. Things to consider1. Remember, it is not a requirement in general to enter into a Confidentiality Agreement or an Agreement on Confidentiality and Rights with companies. 2. Make sure you understand the content and consequences of the agreement. 3. Remember that you own the intellectual property rights (IPR) in the works you produce. 4. Remember that you and the company often have conflicting interests. 5. Make sure that you are given a fair remuneration for your project results. You should rather not be the new student who develops a new , without getting a piece of the cake! 6. Remember to be credited for your work 7. Remember that the goal is for you to pass your exam! How to set up a projectA project executed in collaboration with a company must be set up as any other project at ITU; you must register the project in the same way, observe the same deadlines, find a supervisor from ITU who will accept your project and supervise you, etc. The project must also meet the same academic standard as other projects at ITU. This means, that you must discuss the problem statement with the ITU supervisor, and find out how the company can be used as a case in the final assignment. Finding a CompanyThere are several ways to get in touch with a company: Many companies have uploaded project proposals in the Job- and Project Bank (you might also check the Project Banks of other Universities). Take a look at companies that have posted internships as well; often these will be interested in project collaboration. Twice a year The Study and Career Guidance hosts an event, where the companies/organizations who are interested in collaborating with students visit ITU. See the calendar for The Study and Career Guidance here. If you are looking at potential companies that you think would be interesting to work with, do not hesitate to  them. Many companies are interested in working with students. Some teachers are in  with companies on their own – you can then ask the person you have in mind to supervise your project. Discuss mutual expectations with the companyIt is a good idea to discuss your individual expectations, before you start the project collaboration. You can ask yourself questions like: Why does the company wish to collaborate with students and what are their expectations in terms of the outcome of this collaboration? What are their expectations in regards to how the project collaboration will go about? Does the company have any preferences in terms of method, theoretical approach, the design of the study etc.? Access to important data at the companyBefore you make an agreement with a company or organization, you should make sure that it is possible for you to gain access to relevant data, which is important for your project. This means that you should: Make sure you have a  person at the company who has time to meet up with you or your group. If you need to conduct interviews etc., you should make sure that the company is prepared for that. Ensure that you have the opportunity to gain access to relevant material, such as: Meeting summaries, reports, software, documentation etc. GDPRWill you be working with personal data with a company or organization? Please read about your responsibility as a student working with personal data here.
Confidentiality agreement
A Confidentiality Agreement is between you and the company, and ITU is not a part of the agreement.

Both supervisor and examiner are obliged to follow the duty of confidentiality in general. Therefore, you do not need a signature from your supervisor or any other ITU representative. For this reason as well, you must be extra careful what you agree to, as the agreement is your responsibility.
Confidentiality and Rights agreement
You are not entitled to use ITU Legal, as this is a service to the University staff that can be used as part of their work.
Legal will often get involved in your project through the supervisor, but please be aware that it is the supervisor's interests that Legal are protecting and not yours.
However, Legal has tried to consider the interests of students in preparing the standard contract Confidentiality and Rights agreement.
How to set up a project

A project executed in collaboration with a company must be set up as any other project at ITU; you must register the project in the same way, observe the same deadlines, find a supervisor from ITU who will accept your project and supervise you, etc.

The project must also meet the same academic standard as other projects at ITU. This means, that you must discuss the problem statement with the ITU supervisor, and find out how the company can be used as a case in the final assignment.
Discuss mutual expectations with the company
It is a good idea to discuss your individual expectations, before you start the project collaboration. You can ask yourself questions like:
Access to important data at the company

Before you make an agreement with a company or organization, you should make sure that it is possible for you to gain access to relevant data, which is important for your project. This means that you should:

title: Exemptions
paragraphs: Expected processing time You can expect a processing time of up to 8 weeks. If you apply for an exemption from several rules, your application is a continuation of a previous exemption or lacks documentation the processing time can be extended. During the exam period, the processing time for an application will, in general, still be up to 8 weeks. July is not included in the processing time due to the summer holiday.If you are in a situation where you cannot follow the rules and regulations, that apply for your education, you can apply for an exemption. Exemptions are approved deviations from rules stipulated in ministerial legislation, IT University rules or rules in the curriculum.
Expected processing time You can expect a processing time of up to 8 weeks.

If you apply for an exemption from several rules, your application is a continuation of a previous exemption or lacks documentation the processing time can be extended. During the exam period, the processing time for an application will, in general, still be up to 8 weeks.
July is not included in the processing time due to the summer holiday.
Below you can find examples of the rules that students are most likely to apply for an exemption from. The list is not exhaustive, and each application is handled based on its specific situation.

Binding course registrationFrom Monday of the third week in a semester, registrations for study activities are binding and you must complete the course or project and sit for the examination. If you due to special circumstances cannot complete a course, and you want to deregister from the course, you will need to apply for an exemption.Project or thesis deadlineIf you due to special circumstances are not able to meet a project or thesis deadline, you can apply for an exemption to postpone the deadline.Additional exam attemptsYou have three attempts to pass your exam. If you do not pass your exam using the three attempts, you can apply for a fourth exam attempt, if special circumstances has led to the situation.The first-year examAs a bachelor student you must pass a minimum of 45 ECTS of your first-year courses by the end of your first year of study. If you do not meet this requirement, you will not be allowed to continue your studies at ITU without an exemption. ITU can grant you an exemption from the above-mentioned deadline if there are special circumstances. Therefore, if you have been prevented from following courses and/or taking exams due to special circumstances, you can apply for an exemption. If you are granted an exemption, the deadline for when you must have passed a minimum 45 ECTS of your first-year courses will be by the end of your second year of study. If you have credits transferred from previous studies to your ITU programme, these credits will not count as part of the fulfilment of the first-year exam. More information about the first-year exam.The maximum programme durationThe Bachelor of Science (BSc) programme must be completed within four years for students enrolled autumn 2015 or later. The Master of Science (MSc) programme must be completed within three years for students enrolled in autumn 2015 or later. If you due to special circumstances cannot complete your education within the maximum programme duration, you will need to apply for an exemption to postpone the deadline for when you must have completed your education.The progression requirementThe progression requirement states how much you have to pass each year in order to be considered an active student. From 1 September 2025, you must pass one exam within a continuous period of one year, corresponding to two consecutive semesters, including re-exams. If you do not do this, you will not be allowed to continue your programme and your enrolment will be terminated. In this context, it is irrelevant how many exam attempts you have used. If you due to special circumstances cannot fulfil the progression requirement, you can apply for an exemption from this rule. Calculating the one-year period In case you have been granted leave of absence, this period is excluded when calculating the one-year period. Any credit transfer from courses taken prior to admission is excluded from the one-year period. If you have passed an exam at another university as part of your ITU study programme, this exam will be included in the one-year period.
Binding course registration

From Monday of the third week in a semester, registrations for study activities are binding and you must complete the course or project and sit for the examination. If you due to special circumstances cannot complete a course, and you want to deregister from the course, you will need to apply for an exemption.
Project or thesis deadline
Additional exam attempts
You have three attempts to pass your exam. If you do not pass your exam using the three attempts, you can apply for a fourth exam attempt, if special circumstances has led to the situation.

As a bachelor student you must pass a minimum of 45 ECTS of your first-year courses by the end of your first year of study. If you do not meet this requirement, you will not be allowed to continue your studies at ITU without an exemption.

ITU can grant you an exemption from the above-mentioned deadline if there are special circumstances. Therefore, if you have been prevented from following courses and/or taking exams due to special circumstances, you can apply for an exemption. If you are granted an exemption, the deadline for when you must have passed a minimum 45 ECTS of your first-year courses will be by the end of your second year of study.
If you have credits transferred from previous studies to your ITU programme, these credits will not count as part of the fulfilment of the first-year exam.
More information about the first-year exam.
The maximum programme duration
The Bachelor of Science (BSc) programme must be completed within four years for students enrolled autumn 2015 or later.
The Master of Science (MSc) programme must be completed within three years for students enrolled in autumn 2015 or later.

If you due to special circumstances cannot complete your education within the maximum programme duration, you will need to apply for an exemption to postpone the deadline for when you must have completed your education.
The progression requirement

The progression requirement states how much you have to pass each year in order to be considered an active student. From 1 September 2025, you must pass one exam within a continuous period of one year, corresponding to two consecutive semesters, including re-exams. If you do not do this, you will not be allowed to continue your programme and your enrolment will be terminated. In this context, it is irrelevant how many exam attempts you have used. If you due to special circumstances cannot fulfil the progression requirement, you can apply for an exemption from this rule. Calculating the one-year period In case you have been granted leave of absence, this period is excluded when calculating the one-year period.

Any credit transfer from courses taken prior to admission is excluded from the one-year period. If you have passed an exam at another university as part of your ITU study programme, this exam will be included in the one-year period.
When is an exemption a possibility? The university can grant you an exemption if you can document that special circumstances apply to your situation.

The special circumstances must relate to you as a student and must be externally imposed and something that you could not anticipate or plan for. This could for instance be illness affecting yourself or illness in your immediate family - or other personal special circumstances.
Look here more information about How to apply for an exemption.
What is special circumstances?

Examples of what can qualify as special circumstances:Examples of what can qualify as special circumstances: Documented illness or an accident affecting yourself Documented illness in your immediate family (a spouse/partner, a sibling, a parent or a child) Death in your immediate family (see below) Childbirth Pregnancy-related complications A worsening of a chronic illness Or other special circumstances related to you individually which you could not anticipate or plan for Examples of what cannot qualify as special circumstances:Examples of what cannot qualify as special circumstances: Vacation Challenges or problems with attending classes and/or exams because of work Exams or courses scheduled at the same time or close to each other Academic challenges Lack of knowledge of rules and deadlines The fact that you will be delayed in completing your studies is not in itself a special circumstance The fact that you plan to start a master’s programme as a direct extension of your bachelor programme is not a special circumstance. Other circumstances which are not special, but can provide a basis for an exemption:There can also be other circumstances, which are not special, but can provide a basis for an exemption: Civic duties as a lay judge or member of a jury Athlete of elite sports Entrepreneurship of a certain scale
Examples of what can qualify as special circumstances:
Examples of what can qualify as special circumstances:
Examples of what cannot qualify as special circumstances:
Examples of what cannot qualify as special circumstances:
Other circumstances which are not special, but can provide a basis for an exemption:
There can also be other circumstances, which are not special, but can provide a basis for an exemption:

Medical certificateSee the detailed requirements for the Medical certificate The requirements are aligned with executive order no. 908 of 18/08/2011 regarding "Executive Order on the issuance of medical certificates, etc." You must pay for the medical certificate yourself.Please note that the special circumstance, you describe in your application, must have taken place at a time and been of a duration that corresponds with the exemption you are applying for.
See the detailed requirements for the Medical certificate
The requirements are aligned with executive order no. 908 of 18/08/2011 regarding "Executive Order on the issuance of medical certificates, etc."
You must pay for the medical certificate yourself.

Death in the immediate family Death in the immediate family includes a spouse/partner, a parent, a sibling or a child. You can document this special circumstance with a copy of a death certificate. If you lose someone who is not your immediate family (see above) but someone you are very close to, you can apply for an exemption, if the death affects your ability to study. You must submit medical documentation which describes the close relationship with the person as well as how the death affects you and your ability to study.

Can I deregister a course after a used attempt? Deregistration after used attemptAccording to the Danish Education Order it is not possible to be deregistered a study activity after you have used one or more exam attempts. ITU can make an exemption from this rule if there are special circumstances and these circumstances: are directly linked to the study activity, over a longer period of time prevents you from completing the course or project. Please note that an exemption from this rule is rarely granted, since both of the above-mentioned criteria must apply to your situation.
Deregistration after used attempt

According to the Danish Education Order it is not possible to be deregistered a study activity after you have used one or more exam attempts. ITU can make an exemption from this rule if there are special circumstances and these circumstances:
Please note that an exemption from this rule is rarely granted, since both of the above-mentioned criteria must apply to your situation.
This page was last updated January 2025

If you do not do this, you will not be allowed to continue your programme and your enrolment will be terminated. In this context, it is irrelevant how many exam attempts you have used. If you due to special circumstances cannot fulfil the progression requirement, you can apply for an exemption from this rule. Calculating the one-year period In case you have been granted leave of absence, this period is excluded when calculating the one-year period. Any credit transfer from courses taken prior to admission is excluded from the one-year period. If you have passed an exam at another university as part of your ITU study programme, this exam will be included in the one-year period. Binding course registration From Monday of the third week in a semester, registrations for study activities are binding and you must complete the course or project and sit for the examination. If you due to special circumstances cannot complete a course, and you want to deregister from the course, you will need to apply for an exemption. Project or thesis deadline Additional exam attempts You have three attempts to pass your exam. If you do not pass your exam using the three attempts, you can apply for a fourth exam attempt, if special circumstances has led to the situation. As a bachelor student you must pass a minimum of 45 ECTS of your first-year courses by the end of your first year of study. If you do not meet this requirement, you will not be allowed to continue your studies at ITU without an exemption. ITU can grant you an exemption from the above-mentioned deadline if there are special circumstances. Therefore, if you have been prevented from following courses and/or taking exams due to special circumstances, you can apply for an exemption. If you are granted an exemption, the deadline for when you must have passed a minimum 45 ECTS of your first-year courses will be by the end of your second year of study. If you have credits transferred from previous studies to your ITU programme, these credits will not count as part of the fulfilment of the first-year exam. More information about the first-year exam. The maximum programme duration The Bachelor of Science (BSc) programme must be completed within four years for students enrolled autumn 2015 or later. The Master of Science (MSc) programme must be completed within three years for students enrolled in autumn 2015 or later. If you due to special circumstances cannot complete your education within the maximum programme duration, you will need to apply for an exemption to postpone the deadline for when you must have completed your education. The progression requirement The progression requirement states how much you have to pass each year in order to be considered an active student. From 1 September 2025, you must pass one exam within a continuous period of one year, corresponding to two consecutive semesters, including re-exams. If you do not do this, you will not be allowed to continue your programme and your enrolment will be terminated. In this context, it is irrelevant how many exam attempts you have used. If you due to special circumstances cannot fulfil the progression requirement, you can apply for an exemption from this rule. Calculating the one-year period In case you have been granted leave of absence, this period is excluded when calculating the one-year period. Any credit transfer from courses taken prior to admission is excluded from the one-year period. If you have passed an exam at another university as part of your ITU study programme, this exam will be included in the one-year period. When is an exemption a possibility? The university can grant you an exemption if you can document that special circumstances apply to your situation. The special circumstances must relate to you as a student and must be externally imposed and something that you could not anticipate or plan for. This could for instance be illness affecting yourself or illness in your immediate family - or other personal special circumstances. Look here more information about How to apply for an exemption. What is special circumstances? Examples of what can qualify as special circumstances:Examples of what can qualify as special circumstances: Documented illness or an accident affecting yourself Documented illness in your immediate family (a spouse/partner, a sibling, a parent or a child) Death in your immediate family (see below) Childbirth Pregnancy-related complications A worsening of a chronic illness Or other special circumstances related to you individually which you could not anticipate or plan for Examples of what cannot qualify as special circumstances:Examples of what cannot qualify as special circumstances: Vacation Challenges or problems with attending classes and/or exams because of work Exams or courses scheduled at the same time or close to each other Academic challenges Lack of knowledge of rules and deadlines The fact that you will be delayed in completing your studies is not in itself a special circumstance The fact that you plan to start a master’s programme as a direct extension of your bachelor programme is not a special circumstance. Other circumstances which are not special, but can provide a basis for an exemption:There can also be other circumstances, which are not special, but can provide a basis for an exemption: Civic duties as a lay judge or member of a jury Athlete of elite sports Entrepreneurship of a certain scale Examples of what can qualify as special circumstances: Examples of what can qualify as special circumstances: Examples of what cannot qualify as special circumstances: Examples of what cannot qualify as special circumstances: Other circumstances which are not special, but can provide a basis for an exemption: There can also be other circumstances, which are not special, but can provide a basis for an exemption: Medical certificateSee the detailed requirements for the Medical certificate The requirements are aligned with executive order no. 908 of 18/08/2011 regarding "Executive Order on the issuance of medical certificates, etc." You must pay for the medical certificate yourself.Please note that the special circumstance, you describe in your application, must have taken place at a time and been of a duration that corresponds with the exemption you are applying for. See the detailed requirements for the Medical certificate The requirements are aligned with executive order no. 908 of 18/08/2011 regarding "Executive Order on the issuance of medical certificates, etc." You must pay for the medical certificate yourself. Death in the immediate family Death in the immediate family includes a spouse/partner, a parent, a sibling or a child. You can document this special circumstance with a copy of a death certificate. If you lose someone who is not your immediate family (see above) but someone you are very close to, you can apply for an exemption, if the death affects your ability to study. You must submit medical documentation which describes the close relationship with the person as well as how the death affects you and your ability to study. Can I deregister a course after a used attempt? Deregistration after used attemptAccording to the Danish Education Order it is not possible to be deregistered a study activity after you have used one or more exam attempts. ITU can make an exemption from this rule if there are special circumstances and these circumstances: are directly linked to the study activity, over a longer period of time prevents you from completing the course or project. Please note that an exemption from this rule is rarely granted, since both of the above-mentioned criteria must apply to your situation. Deregistration after used attempt According to the Danish Education Order it is not possible to be deregistered a study activity after you have used one or more exam attempts. ITU can make an exemption from this rule if there are special circumstances and these circumstances: Please note that an exemption from this rule is rarely granted, since both of the above-mentioned criteria must apply to your situation. This page was last updated January 2025

title: Courses outside ITU

headings.text: Courses at other universities in Denmark
Courses passed before enrolling at ITU

paragraphs: You can take courses outside ITU as part of you programme. Courses at other universities in Denmark If you want to do courses at other universities in Denmark, you need to have the courses pre-approved. Be aware that besides applying for pre-approval from ITU you also need to follow the guidelines for admission at the University where you want to take your electives. Look for admission rules for guest students on their website. Courses passed before enrolling at ITUIf you have passed courses that are relevant for your studies at ITU before you enrolled at ITU, you can apply for a Credit Transfer. Studying abroad If you want to take courses at Universities outside Denmark, you can apply to go on Exchange. This involves getting a pre-approval well. Read about how to Study Abroad.

title: Special Circumstances
paragraphs: If you find yourself in a situation where you cannot study as a full-time student you can apply for an exemption from the rules you are subject to when studying a higher education programme at ITU. This can also be relevant if due to special circumstances you need a fourth exam attempt, you cannot meet the requirements for progression etc. Read more about Exemptions
Read more about How to apply
Special pedagogical support (SPS) is a support offered for students with a physical or mental disability, to help them in their university studies.

title: Especially about the Master Thesis

headings.text: When can you start your thesis?

paragraphs: The thesis is a 30 ECTS project, which must conclude your MSc programme.Working in a groupYou can write the thesis alone or in groups of up to 4 students. You are allowed to work with students from other study programmes as long as you can have your problem statement approved. Learn more about working in groups. It is an independent project, which should show that you are able to work with a topic of your own choosing at a high academic level. The thesis is a written submission (either individual or in group) with an oral exam (50 minutes per student incl. voting and feedback). The thesis is legally founded in the programme Curriculum (‘Studieordning’). Find your Curriculum under Your Programme. Otherwise, the thesis follows the general rules that apply when writing a project. For information on this, please read about Project work here Below, you can find more information about what is specific to the master thesis.
You can write the thesis alone or in groups of up to 4 students.
You are allowed to work with students from other study programmes as long as you can have your problem statement approved. Learn more about working in groups.

Need inspiration or support?You can always check out the pages under The Study and Career Guidance for tips and advice. Follow this link for guidance on starting up a Project / ThesisThe general requirement is that your thesis must be placed in the final year of your master programme. This means that you must have passed 60 ECTS before writing your thesis.
Need inspiration or support?
You can always check out the pages under The Study and Career Guidance for tips and advice.
Follow this link for guidance on starting up a Project / Thesis
The details The master thesis should conclude your study programme and show that you have the required academic skills in applying scientific theories and methods.

Therefore, your thesis ideally should be placed in your 4th and final semester, but sometimes it might be necessary to take any remaining ECTS in the following semester. If possible, you can also register for 7,5 ECTS in the same semester as you write your thesis.
Read more about exemptions here
You must include an abstract in your thesis. If the thesis is in Danish, the abstract must be in English. If the thesis is in English, you can write the abstract in either Danish or English.
You can see the deadlines for submission of the thesis under Submission deadlines.

title: How to apply for an Exemption

headings.text: How to apply for an Exemption

paragraphs: Ill at your exam?If you need to report illness at your exam, please follow this link for detailed information.If you wish to apply for an exemption to deviate from existing rules, you must send your application to Student Affairs & Programmes. Below you will find guidelines for how to apply and how to document your situation.
If you need to report illness at your exam, please follow this link for detailed information.

The recipient of your application for exemption generally does not know what you are applying for. To avoid doubt, it is very important that you clearly specify exactly what you want to be exempted from.
Please have a careful look at the Exemptions page before applying. If you have questions regarding exemptions, you are always welcome to  The Study and Career Guidance.
Fill out the following form:
Fill out a provisional study plan and attach to your application. The student advisors can help make a study plan that will work.
The details The application form must include an explanation of why the exemption is necessary. The explanation you provide matters, and your application must include information on:
Academic ability will not be taken into account when the university assesses if circumstances are special.
You submit the application by emailing it to sap@itu.dk
Along with your application for an exemption, you must send documentation of the special circumstances you describe in the application.
This could be a medical certificate, a birth certificate a death certificate or similar. Of course the circumstances that lead to an exemption can be documented in other ways as well.
In relation to illness a medical certificate is of the most importance. Please see the specific requirements for the medical certificate below.

Accesible formats Please attach the documentation in the following formats: PDF, Word, PNG or JPEG/JPG (we cannot open documents in HEIC format). Do not insert links to the documents directly in the e-mail. Documentation attached in other formats may prolong the processing time of your application.

The medical certificate must be in Danish - but in special cases we can accept one in English. The doctor must write the medical certificate in accordance with applicable rules and it must always contain the mandatory specifications listed below.
Please read all four points:

1. The patient Full name CPR-number Address 2. The doctor and clinic Full name and title (specialist title if possible) Practitioner’s ID number and authorization ID (ydernummer) Address 3. The certificate must: distinguish between information based on the doctors own examination of you, your information as a patient and third–party information from medical journals etc. inform whether you are a regular patient at the doctor or not be dated and provided with the doctors professional's signature or otherwise unambiguously attributable to the doctor address all issues relevant to fulfill the purpose of the certificate 4. The medical certificate should also include: a description of how the illness affects you and your ability to study or attend an exam the period for your illness (start date and how long it is expected to last) an indication - using percentages (%) of how much the illness affects your ability to study or attend exams
2. The doctor and clinic
3. The certificate must:
4. The medical certificate should also include:

The purpose of the medical certificate is to document how, to what extent and how long your disorder or illness affects your ability to study and to complete your programme on the terms that normally apply
The doctor is not obliged to inform which illness or disorder is involved, but it can help us understand the degree of influence on your ability to study or attend an exam.
Adequate information gives us the best opportunity to assess whether there is reason to give you exemption.
The requirements are aligned with executive order no. 908 of 18/08/2011 regarding "Executive Order on the issuance of medical certificates, etc."

title: Courses outside ITU

headings.text: Courses at other universities in Denmark
Courses passed before enrolling at ITU

paragraphs: You can take courses outside ITU as part of you programme. Courses at other universities in Denmark If you want to do courses at other universities in Denmark, you need to have the courses pre-approved. Be aware that besides applying for pre-approval from ITU you also need to follow the guidelines for admission at the University where you want to take your electives. Look for admission rules for guest students on their website. Courses passed before enrolling at ITUIf you have passed courses that are relevant for your studies at ITU before you enrolled at ITU, you can apply for a Credit Transfer. Studying abroad If you want to take courses at Universities outside Denmark, you can apply to go on Exchange. This involves getting a pre-approval well. Read about how to Study Abroad.

title: Learn Danish
paragraphs: Interested?Sign up now. UCplus will later inform you of the lesson schedule from which you can choose lessons in accordance with your calendar. Through a collaboration with the language school, UCplus, we offer Danish lessons at ITU for those interested.
UCplus will later inform you of the lesson schedule from which you can choose lessons in accordance with your calendar.

Learning Danish will make it easier to navigate the Danish society and to get a part-time job. You can take the mandatory language tests at a pace that suits you and your work / study schedule. You will receive your first certificate after a few months.

How much does it cost? It is free of charge to learn Danish with UCPlus, however you need to deposit DKK 2,000 which you will get refunded when you quit the study. We offer you up to 6 lessons per week. Should you have weeks where you are unable to attend the lessons, you can improve your skills using UCplus’ online training tool.

Should you have any questions, you are welcome to write UCplus at cph@ucplus.dk or call them at +45 44 87 01 66. You can sign up on the website www.ucplusdansk.dk. You can also get more information about the courses at the International Night.
UCplus look much forward to greeting you at their courses.

title: The project page
paragraphs: Please Note: If your project is cancelled or pushed the project page will be shut down. If you need your work for later, you need to save and store it yourself.

The preliminary problem statement is where you zoom in on the scope of your project, giving a more precise description of your subject area, topic, hypothesis etc. Your supervisor must approve your problem statement and thereby also agree to supervise your project. After your supervisor approve your preliminary problem statement, it cannot be edited on the project page. However, you can still elaborate on it in the actual project. The preliminary problem statement will not be part of the assessment of your project. Therefore, your preliminary problem statement needs to be generic enough to allow for your scope to change as the project progresses, while at the same time be specific enough for your supervisor to be able to assess and approve of the scope of the project. This description is also used in the process of allocating an external examiner for your oral exam (where applicable). Therefore, we recommend that you spend some time to work on the preliminary problem statement before submitting.

Elective projects, Bachelor projects and Thesis: Friday in week 5 (for Spring) / 35 (for Autumn) Re project (CS, DS & SD): Friday in week 8 (for Spring) / 39 (for Autumn) Summer project: Friday week 26 Project agreements have a deadline running until 14:00 on the date given above.
Elective projects, Bachelor projects and Thesis: Friday in week 5 (for Spring) / 35 (for Autumn)
Re project (CS, DS & SD): Friday in week 8 (for Spring) / 39 (for Autumn)
Summer project: Friday week 26

Late registration If you register for a project, bachelor project or thesis in the registration change period, the deadline for the preliminary problem statement is moved to Friday in week 8 / week 39.

The title you registered in My Study Activities is the name of the project page and the default project title which will go on your diploma. To change the title of your project, you must write to sap@itu.dk and they will be happy to change the title for you. SAP will not be able to change the title of your project page, but only change the project title as it will appear on your diploma.
Please note, the title should be changed before you submit your project.

Projects are submitted on the project page, similar to course exams. See how to submit written work. Submission deadlines can be found here. When set, you can find the time and date for the oral exam in the calendar function on the project page. For more details on formal requirements for projects, see this overview Project work

title: How to apply for an Exemption

headings.text: How to apply for an Exemption

paragraphs: Ill at your exam?If you need to report illness at your exam, please follow this link for detailed information.If you wish to apply for an exemption to deviate from existing rules, you must send your application to Student Affairs & Programmes. Below you will find guidelines for how to apply and how to document your situation.
If you need to report illness at your exam, please follow this link for detailed information.

The recipient of your application for exemption generally does not know what you are applying for. To avoid doubt, it is very important that you clearly specify exactly what you want to be exempted from.
Please have a careful look at the Exemptions page before applying. If you have questions regarding exemptions, you are always welcome to  The Study and Career Guidance.
Fill out the following form:
Fill out a provisional study plan and attach to your application. The student advisors can help make a study plan that will work.
The details The application form must include an explanation of why the exemption is necessary. The explanation you provide matters, and your application must include information on:
Academic ability will not be taken into account when the university assesses if circumstances are special.
You submit the application by emailing it to sap@itu.dk
Along with your application for an exemption, you must send documentation of the special circumstances you describe in the application.
This could be a medical certificate, a birth certificate a death certificate or similar. Of course the circumstances that lead to an exemption can be documented in other ways as well.
In relation to illness a medical certificate is of the most importance. Please see the specific requirements for the medical certificate below.

Accesible formats Please attach the documentation in the following formats: PDF, Word, PNG or JPEG/JPG (we cannot open documents in HEIC format). Do not insert links to the documents directly in the e-mail. Documentation attached in other formats may prolong the processing time of your application.

The medical certificate must be in Danish - but in special cases we can accept one in English. The doctor must write the medical certificate in accordance with applicable rules and it must always contain the mandatory specifications listed below.
Please read all four points:

1. The patient Full name CPR-number Address 2. The doctor and clinic Full name and title (specialist title if possible) Practitioner’s ID number and authorization ID (ydernummer) Address 3. The certificate must: distinguish between information based on the doctors own examination of you, your information as a patient and third–party information from medical journals etc. inform whether you are a regular patient at the doctor or not be dated and provided with the doctors professional's signature or otherwise unambiguously attributable to the doctor address all issues relevant to fulfill the purpose of the certificate 4. The medical certificate should also include: a description of how the illness affects you and your ability to study or attend an exam the period for your illness (start date and how long it is expected to last) an indication - using percentages (%) of how much the illness affects your ability to study or attend exams
2. The doctor and clinic
3. The certificate must:
4. The medical certificate should also include:

The purpose of the medical certificate is to document how, to what extent and how long your disorder or illness affects your ability to study and to complete your programme on the terms that normally apply
The doctor is not obliged to inform which illness or disorder is involved, but it can help us understand the degree of influence on your ability to study or attend an exam.
Adequate information gives us the best opportunity to assess whether there is reason to give you exemption.
The requirements are aligned with executive order no. 908 of 18/08/2011 regarding "Executive Order on the issuance of medical certificates, etc."

title: Bachelor Project

headings.text: When can I write the bachelor project?

paragraphs: The bachelor project is a 15 ECTS project that concludes your BSc programme. It is an independent project defined by a project agreement. You complete the bachelor project with a written bachelor report and an individual oral exam.
You can write the bachelor project alone or in groups of up to 5 students.
Learn more about working in groups.
Normally, you write your bachelor project in your 6th semester, as you can see in the contents of your programme overview.

In certain cases - e.g. if you have not been able to pass 30 ECTS each semester - you might have to consider writing the project in another semester. However, you must have passed 120 ECTS before you can register for the bachelor project.
For specific information about the bachelor project (registration, deadlines, supervisor etc.) go to Study Administration / Project work / Bachelor project.

links.text: Study Administration / Project work / Bachelor project

It is an independent project defined by a project agreement. You complete the bachelor project with a written bachelor report and an individual oral exam. You can write the bachelor project alone or in groups of up to 5 students. Learn more about working in groups. Normally, you write your bachelor project in your 6th semester, as you can see in the contents of your programme overview. In certain cases - e.g. if you have not been able to pass 30 ECTS each semester - you might have to consider writing the project in another semester. However, you must have passed 120 ECTS before you can register for the bachelor project. For specific information about the bachelor project (registration, deadlines, supervisor etc.) go to Study Administration / Project work / Bachelor project.

title: How to create your personal profile

headings.text: How to create your personal profile

paragraphs: Here are some examples of how you can create a personal profile in many different ways:
When you have the possibility to chose elective courses, projects and specialisations, you should consider how these will complement or deepen the skills and competencies you have already developed.
Are there for example any areas where you would like to develop your knowledge or practical skills? In terms of elective courses, you can also apply for a course at another university.
Read more about pre-approval for courses here.

Studying abroad is both academically and personally evolving, and can give you a unique academic profile, language skills, intercultural awareness and an international network for life. Many employers value international experience.
Read more about studying abroad here.
Collaborating with a company during your studies is an excellent way to learn about the job market, enhance your network and develop and practice your skills.
Read more about collaborating with companies here.

Are there for example any areas where you would like to develop your knowledge or practical skills? In terms of elective courses, you can also apply for a course at another university. Read more about pre-approval for courses here. Studying abroad is both academically and personally evolving, and can give you a unique academic profile, language skills, intercultural awareness and an international network for life. Many employers value international experience. Read more about studying abroad here. title: Course evaluation

headings.text: What happens after the course evaluation?

paragraphs: Evaluation reportsEach semester, a course evaluation report is made with scores by course and study programme. Reports are published in week 51 (Autumn courses) and 21 (Spring Courses). Find the Course evaluation reports. Your feedback is key to quality assurance and development of courses. Participating in course evaluations is your chance to influence aspects of courses that matter to you. Teachers go carefully through your feedback and use it to adjust courses. Future students attending the course benefit from your feedback - just like you benefit from previous evaluations. The impact of your participation in evaluations reaches far beyond the current semester.
Each semester, a course evaluation report is made with scores by course and study programme. Reports are published in week 51 (Autumn courses) and 21 (Spring Courses).
Find the Course evaluation reports.
The course evaluation process looks like this:

During the first half of a course, teachers invite you and your fellow students to participate in a formative evaluation in class. This is your time to make yourself heard and share your good ideas and suggestions on how to make the course even better. When your share your opinion, the teachers have the possibility to adjust the course while it runs, to help your learning.
Please note that not everything is up for change. This goes for the intended learning objectives and the exam format for example. The teachers have the last word in deciding what to adjust.
The online course evaluation survey contains four questions and a comment box:
Please state your agreement with the following statements from 1 (strongly disagree) to 6 (strongly agree).
Comment box: Please give feedback on the course and your learning experience. Thank you for keeping a civil tone.
Students are anonymous when participating in the online survey. You are not anonymous when participating in the Mutual Alignment of Expectations or a qualitative end-evaluation in class.

Once you have participated in the course evaluation, the follow-up process begins. In the illustration below, you can see how your input becomes part of quality assuring and developing courses at ITU.

paragraphs: Summer University can give you a flexibility in your studies, either pushing a subject from your Spring semester or pulling a course from your Autumn semester to be taken during the summer.
All in all it can help to lighten the weight of your study activities in the surrounding Spring or Autumn semester.
With the right planning ITU Summer University can offer flexibility to your programme!
Have a look at the courses offered for Summer University.
Find the information you need about when the exams will be held, including the re-exams.
Also look here for information about applying for exams on special conditions.
You register for courses at Summer University December 1 - 10 in My Study Activities.
In case that there are seats available we will open for registration again June 1 - June 10.
Please keep updated here about seats available in relation to registering in June. The information will be ready mid May.
We have put together an FAQ, hopefully answering the most common questions.
You are of course welcome to  Student Affairs and Programmes if you still have questions.

title: Illness at exams
paragraphs: ImportantIf you attend and complete your exam, your exam attempt cannot be cancelled based on illness. If you have fallen ill during your exam and cannot complete it, follow the instructions on this page.

If you fall ill during an exam, you can send a notification of illness and request to not use an exam attempt. You must be able to document your illness. If your notification of illness is approved, you will not use an exam attempt. Please note that there is no guarantee that your request will be approved, and that your exam attempt will be cancelled. We will process your request based on an assessment of your specific situation and medical documentation.

It is not a requirement that you send a notification of illness if you fall ill during an exam. You always have three exam attempts to pass an exam. There are slightly different requirements when reporting ill. In every scenario you will need to document your illness.

Illness and group examsWhen it comes to group exams please se this page about illness and group exams where we have outlined different scenarious and what to do. Ill before the examIf you are ill during the semester and cannot prepare for or participate in the exam, you must apply for an exemption to be deregistered from the exam. You must apply before the exam starts, and it is a requirement that you submit documentation of your illness. You can read more about exemptions and how to apply to be deregistered from an exam here. Ill on the day of the examIf you fall ill on the day of the exam before the exam starts, or before the submission deadline for a written exam expires, you can send a notification of illness and request to have the exam attempt cancelled. We can only cancel your exam attempt if you submit documentation of your illness. We recommend that you  your doctor as soon as possible to secure the required documentation. If your notification of illness is approved, you will not use an exam attempt. Use this form to send a notification of illness.Ill during a written exam on premisesIf you fall ill during a written exam on premises, you must notify the exam invigilator that you wish to leave the exam due to illness. You must then send in a notification of illness and request to have the exam attempt cancelled. We can only cancel your exam attempt if you submit documentation that you were ill on the day of the exam. We recommend that you  your doctor as soon as possible to secure the required documentation. If your notification of illness is approved, you will not use an exam attempt. Please note that you cannot have your exam attempt cancelled based on illness if you have submitted something for assessment. Use this form to send a notification of illness.Ill during an oral examIf you fall ill during an oral exam, you must notify the examiners that you wish to interrupt the exam due to illness. You must then send in a notification of illness and request to have the exam attempt cancelled. We can only cancel your exam attempt if you submit documentation of your illness. We recommend that you  your doctor as soon as possible to secure the required documentation. If your notification of illness is approved, you will not use an exam attempt. Use this form to send a notification of illness.Ill during a take-home examIf you fall ill during a take-home exam, you can send a notification of illness and request to have the exam attempt cancelled. We can only cancel your exam attempt if you submit documentation of illness during the period of the take-home exam. We recommend that you  your doctor as soon as possible to secure the required documentation. If your notification of illness is approved, you will not use an exam attempt. Please note that you cannot have your exam attempt cancelled based on illness if you have submitted something for assessment. Use this form to send a notification of illness.
Illness and group exams
If you are ill during the semester and cannot prepare for or participate in the exam, you must apply for an exemption to be deregistered from the exam.
You must apply before the exam starts, and it is a requirement that you submit documentation of your illness.
You can read more about exemptions and how to apply to be deregistered from an exam here.
Ill on the day of the exam

If you fall ill on the day of the exam before the exam starts, or before the submission deadline for a written exam expires, you can send a notification of illness and request to have the exam attempt cancelled. We can only cancel your exam attempt if you submit documentation of your illness. We recommend that you  your doctor as soon as possible to secure the required documentation. If your notification of illness is approved, you will not use an exam attempt.

Use this form to send a notification of illness.

Be aware if you need to re-submit your course exam assignment Go to course re-exams.

full_text: Illness at exams Illness at exams How to document your illness Register for re-exams ImportantIf you attend and complete your exam, your exam attempt cannot be cancelled based on illness. If you have fallen ill during your exam and cannot complete it, follow the instructions on this page. If you fall ill during an exam, you can send a notification of illness and request to not use an exam attempt. You must be able to document your illness. If your notification of illness is approved, you will not use an exam attempt. Please note that there is no guarantee that your request will be approved, and that your exam attempt will be cancelled. We will process your request based on an assessment of your specific situation and medical documentation. It is not a requirement that you send a notification of illness if you fall ill during an exam. You always have three exam attempts to pass an exam. There are slightly different requirements when reporting ill. In every scenario you will need to document your illness. Illness and group examsWhen it comes to group exams please se this page about illness and group exams where we have outlined different scenarious and what to do. Ill before the examIf you are ill during the semester and cannot prepare for or participate in the exam, you must apply for an exemption to be deregistered from the exam. You must apply before the exam starts, and it is a requirement that you submit documentation of your illness. You can read more about exemptions and how to apply to be deregistered from an exam here. Ill on the day of the examIf you fall ill on the day of the exam before the exam starts, or before the submission deadline for a written exam expires, you can send a notification of illness and request to have the exam attempt cancelled. We can only cancel your exam attempt if you submit documentation of your illness. We recommend that you your doctor as soon as possible to secure the required documentation. If your notification of illness is approved, you will not use an exam attempt. Use this form to send a notification of illness.Ill during a written exam on premisesIf you fall ill during a written exam on premises, you must notify the exam invigilator that you wish to leave the exam due to illness. You must then send in a notification of illness and request to have the exam attempt cancelled. We can only cancel your exam attempt if you submit documentation that you were ill on the day of the exam. We recommend that you your doctor as soon as possible to secure the required documentation. If your notification of illness is approved, you will not use an exam attempt. Please note that you cannot have your exam attempt cancelled based on illness if you have submitted something for assessment. Use this form to send a notification of illness.Ill during an oral examIf you fall ill during an oral exam, you must notify the examiners that you wish to interrupt the exam due to illness. You must then send in a notification of illness and request to have the exam attempt cancelled. We can only cancel your exam attempt if you submit documentation of your illness. We recommend that you your doctor as soon as possible to secure the required documentation. If your notification of illness is approved, you will not use an exam attempt. Use this form to send a notification of illness.Ill during a take-home examIf you fall ill during a take-home exam, you can send a notification of illness and request to have the exam attempt cancelled. We can only cancel your exam attempt if you submit documentation of illness during the period of the take-home exam. We recommend that you your doctor as soon as possible to secure the required documentation. If your notification of illness is approved, you will not use an exam attempt. Please note that you cannot have your exam attempt cancelled based on illness if you have submitted something for assessment. Use this form to send a notification of illness. Illness and group exams If you are ill during the semester and cannot prepare for or participate in the exam, you must apply for an exemption to be deregistered from the exam. You must apply before the exam starts, and it is a requirement that you submit documentation of your illness. You can read more about exemptions and how to apply to be deregistered from an exam here. Ill on the day of the exam If you fall ill on the day of the exam before the exam starts, or before the submission deadline for a written exam expires, you can send a notification of illness and request to have the exam attempt cancelled. We can only cancel your exam attempt if you submit documentation of your illness. We recommend that you your doctor as soon as possible to secure the required documentation. If your notification of illness is approved, you will not use an exam attempt. Use this form to send a notification of illness. title: Transcripts and documents
paragraphs: If you need documentation of your enrollment, a transcript of your records or documentation of your graduation, you need to print these from My Study Activities.
Once printed, you can email it to sap@itu.dk or stop by Student Affairs and Programmes (SAP) to get an official stamp and signature, if needed. See opening hours for SAP front here.

If you need documentation concerning something specific, you are welcome to formulate your own text on it, print it and come by to have us check, sign and stamp your information. Of course we can only sign for information we are able to control (i.e. use of exam attempts or that your programme is taught in English etc.).
If necessary, find the ITU letter template here: Danish version or English version.
If you are no longer a student at ITU and you need a transcript, please  sap@itu.dk

Of course we can only sign for information we are able to control (i.e. use of exam attempts or that your programme is taught in English etc.). If necessary, find the ITU letter template here: Danish version or English version. If you are no longer a student at ITU and you need a transcript, please sap@itu.dk

title: Develop your CV while studying

headings.text: What is a relevant student job?
Focus on assignments and the possibility of developing skills

paragraphs: There are many ways to develop relevant skills outside your studies. Skills that are important when you will be applying for jobs after graduation.

Having a relevant student job is vital, but there are also other ways in which you can gain valuable skills on your CV - for example working as a volunteer or engaging in extra curricula activities at the university.
A relevant student job is more than just a financial need: it is also a good investment in your future.
Having a relevant student job will:

A relevant student job is a job where you practice and develop skills that are relevant in relation to your studies. It is a job where you practice your academic competencies in a real work-related context. It is also a job where you develop significant skills that are valuable for your future job situation. To clarify, what is study relevant for you has to do with what you would like to work with after your finish your studies.

It is a good idea to focus on the assignments involved in a job, and not in the job title. Be creative and accept if you have to start with other assignments than those you wish for. When you have entered a company or an organization, it is easier to gain more exiting and relevant assignments in the long run

The good cause or a passionate interest might be the main reason for working as a volunteer. However, volunteering is not only an act of grace, it is also a good way to develop skills, gain work experience and expand your network.

Volunteering can be beneficial for all parties. It is a unique opportunity to do something you are passionate about, have fun and learn a lot. At the same time, it can create professional relationships that might be the path to future employment.
Find volunteering jobs at this website.

Engaging in student organisations or student government work at the IT University is also a very good way to enhance your CV. Sitting on the board in different communities is also positive for your CV, skill development and network.

title: You register for all your study activities yourself

headings.text: You register for all your study activities yourself
When can we see our confirmed registrations?
What courses can you sign up for?
Summer University or Summer Courses outside of ITU

paragraphs: Registration periodsSpring semester You can register from December 1 (midnight) - December 10 (23:59). Autumn semester You can register from June 1 (midnight) - June 10 (23:59). Summer University You can register from December 1 (midnight) - December 10. (23:59) If there are seats available, you are be able to register June 1 (midnight) - June 10. (23:59) Read more about Summer University at ITU.
Spring semester You can register from December 1 (midnight) - December 10 (23:59).
Autumn semester You can register from June 1 (midnight) - June 10 (23:59).
Summer University You can register from December 1 (midnight) - December 10. (23:59)
If there are seats available, you are be able to register June 1 (midnight) - June 10. (23:59)
Read more about Summer University at ITU.
You must register for all your study activities yourself: (all new BSc and MSc students are administratively registered for their first semester)

A limit to your registrations You cannot exceed the registration limit of 37,5 ECTS pr. semester. The only exception is, if for the Spring semester you want to register for 37, 5 ECTS + a Summer University course, then you write sap@itu.dk.
In general, if you have issues making a registration send an e-mail to sap@itu.dk in the registration period, and we will look into it.
Mandatory courses Your registration for a mandatory course on your programme will secure you a seat on the course.

Electives Your registration for elective courses is only a wish. Getting a seat has to do with how many who registered for it and how the seats are allocated. For this reason you should always register a second priority for your electives. Are you pushing courses?If you are considering to push courses and not register for the standard 30 ECTS, please SEE HERE for what to be aware of.
Are you pushing courses?
Specialisation courses Your registration for a specialisation course that is standard to your programme will secure you a seat on the course. This goes for the 2nd (and 3rd) part as well.
A registration for a course that is part of an approved individual specialisation is only a wish. Getting a seat has to do with how many who registered for it and how the seats are allocated.
You can find the principles for the allocation of course seats here.

How to registerYou register in My Study Activities. First and second priorities (Electives only*) The number of courses that you give first priority indicates the number of courses you want to register for, therefore if you need to register for two courses, you should give both courses first priority. Your choice of second priority course will only be taken into consideration, if you are not awarded a seat in the course(s) that you have given first priority. During the period for changing registrations in the beginning of the semester, you cannot prioritise registrations. * For mandatory courses or specialisation courses you do not need to have a second priority.
You register in My Study Activities.

First and second priorities (Electives only*) The number of courses that you give first priority indicates the number of courses you want to register for, therefore if you need to register for two courses, you should give both courses first priority.
Your choice of second priority course will only be taken into consideration, if you are not awarded a seat in the course(s) that you have given first priority.
During the period for changing registrations in the beginning of the semester, you cannot prioritise registrations.
* For mandatory courses or specialisation courses you do not need to have a second priority.

Please be aware If your registration is rejected by the system (afvist, ingen plads, osv.), the registration team will look into it and send you an email if any action is necessary on your part. Often the team will be able to simply fix the registration, but remember to keep an eye on your email during the registration period.
You do not need to notify SAP!
In each registration period, you can see a list of the courses available for your registration on the registration form in My Study Activities.

Approved electivesFind the list in LearnIT. Set the filters to The relevant semester and Elective to and then choose your own study programme.Remember to check if the courses you sign up for are scheduled to run at the same time. In the weeks up until the registration opens, a list of approved courses will be shared for each programme with the courses available to choose from.
Find the list in LearnIT. Set the filters to The relevant semester and Elective to and then choose your own study programme.
Please be aware If you are choosing electives approved for you, but from a different study programme, the course can require specific knowledge you might not have.

The courses facilitated by your own Study Programme should fit in with your acquired knowledge and skills, but do remember to check up on the prerequisites.Special academic prerequisites?For some students their educational background might qualify them for courses outside the course list. Please read more here
Special academic prerequisites?
For some students their educational background might qualify them for courses outside the course list.
Please read more here
You are responsible for ensuring that you meet the prerequisites for a course.

Remember that you have the possibility to take courses during the summer either through Summer University at ITU or Summer courses outside ITU. For courses outside of ITU instead of registering you need to apply for a pre-approval in advance.
You register for a project in My Study Activities similar to registering for courses. This includes bachelor projects and master theses.
Please note, when you register for the project, you will be asked to provide,

Do you have a supervisor? You are responsible for finding a supervisor, however, some programmes have processes to help you find supervisors for bachelor projects and master theses. See for information on finding a supervisor.
If you don’t have a supervisor upon registration, please email sap@itu.dk with the name as soon as you have found one.
For more information about the process and requirements for writing a project or thesis, please see Process for writing projects and theses

How to registerProject codes When you register you choose between different project codes. Each code represents a different project. If you have not registered for a project before you just choose number 1. If writing a second project, you then choose another project code. If you need more attempts concerning a project you have already registered for once, Student Affairs & Programmes will need to handle the registration for you. You then write to sap@itu.dk about the registration. Group projects If you are registering for a group project, only one member of the group has to make the registration and then add the other group member(s) before finalising the registration. The added group members will receive an invitation for the project and it is important that they remember to accept this invitation.

Project codes When you register you choose between different project codes. Each code represents a different project. If you have not registered for a project before you just choose number 1. If writing a second project, you then choose another project code. If you need more attempts concerning a project you have already registered for once, Student Affairs & Programmes will need to handle the registration for you. You then write to sap@itu.dk about the registration. Group projects If you are registering for a group project, only one member of the group has to make the registration and then add the other group member(s) before finalising the registration. The added group members will receive an invitation for the project and it is important that they remember to accept this invitation.

Project page and problem statement Your registration for a project generates a project page in LearnIT. This is where you submit your problem statement and where your supervisor will be added. The project page is also where you later submit the final project.
Read more about the preliminary problem statement here Learn more about getting started with a project here.

FAQI have attended the course before. Can I sign up for the exam only?No. Registration for an exam requires that you register for the course in the registration period. This also means that have to submit mandatory assignments again, and that your exam will be based on the newest curriculum for the course, if the course has changed.  the course manager for the possibility of re-submitting the mandatory assignments from when you attended the course the first time. If the course hasn't changed this could be a possibility.Registering for a 2nd or 3rd exam attempt (courses)1. If, due to cancelled attempts, your "first" exam attempt was in the re-exam period, you must register for the course again in the registration period 2. If your second exam attempt was in the re-exam period, you must register for the course again in the registration period. 3. If your second exam attempt was at the ordinary exam in December/January or May/June, you must register for your third attempt in the re-exam period by sending an email to sap@itu.dk no later than on the 2nd Wednesday of respectively February or July.* *If your grades are released after the above deadline and you discover that you need to register for your third attempt in the re-exam period, please  sap@itu.dk within 3 days of the grade announcement.What if the course is no longer offered?When a course is no longer offered Then in most cases a replacement course is chosen and you must take this instead. You will be able to register for this course by yourself. In very rare cases, no replacement course exists As a rule, you will then get the opportunity to complete the course in the first-coming exam period after the course has been cancelled. However, this may vary from course to course and under certain circumstances, other timeframes may also apply. SAP will  you and inform you about the practicalities. Can I do courses or projects at other Universities?Yes, you can. For this you need a pre-approval of credit transfer from the IT University. Apart from this, you have to follow the admission guidelines for guest students at the specific university.
I have attended the course before. Can I sign up for the exam only?

No. Registration for an exam requires that you register for the course in the registration period. This also means that have to submit mandatory assignments again, and that your exam will be based on the newest curriculum for the course, if the course has changed.
the course manager for the possibility of re-submitting the mandatory assignments from when you attended the course the first time. If the course hasn't changed this could be a possibility.
Registering for a 2nd or 3rd exam attempt (courses)
1. If, due to cancelled attempts, your "first" exam attempt was in the re-exam period, you must register for the course again in the registration period
2. If your second exam attempt was in the re-exam period, you must register for the course again in the registration period.

3. If your second exam attempt was at the ordinary exam in December/January or May/June, you must register for your third attempt in the re-exam period by sending an email to sap@itu.dk no later than on the 2nd Wednesday of respectively February or July.*

*If your grades are released after the above deadline and you discover that you need to register for your third attempt in the re-exam period, please  sap@itu.dk within 3 days of the grade announcement.
What if the course is no longer offered?
Can I do courses or projects at other Universities?
